questions.text: In uncontrolled diabetes, in which of the following cells there is decreased glucose uptake due to insulin deficiency:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Skeletal Muscle

Explanation:

In uncontrolled diabetes, insulin deficiency leads to decreased glucose uptake in cells that rely on insulin for glucose transport. Skeletal muscle cells are insulin-dependent, meaning they require insulin to facilitate the uptake of glucose via glucose transporters (e.g., GLUT4). In the absence of sufficient insulin, glucose uptake in skeletal muscle decreases, leading to elevated blood glucose levels.

 

 

RBC (Option A) RBCs do not depend on insulin for glucose uptake. They use GLUT1 transporters, which allow glucose to enter the cells independently of insulin levels. Therefore, their glucose uptake is not significantly affected by insulin deficiency.

 

Liver (Option C) The liver can take up glucose independently of insulin to some extent, especially under the influence of other hormones like glucagon. While insulin does regulate hepatic glucose uptake and production, the primary effect of insulin deficiency in the liver is increased glucose output (e.g., gluconeogenesis), not a significant decrease in uptake.

 

Brain (Option D) Brain cells primarily use GLUT3 and GLUT1 transporters, which are insulin-independent. The brain can continue to take up glucose even in the absence of insulin.

questions.text: In keratoplasty, the commonly used corneal storage medium and suture material are:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A)MK medium and 10-0 nylon

Explanation:

MK medium and 10-0 nylon (Option A): While MK medium is less common now for long-term storage, 10-0 nylon is definitively the most commonly used suture material. This makes the suture part of this answer very strong.

Moist chamber and Vicryl (Option B ruled out): Neither of these is commonly used for corneal grafts.

Optisol-GS and silk (Option C ruled out): Optisol-GS is the leading modern storage medium, but silk is not the commonly used suture for corneal grafts.

Eusol-C and 6-0 prolene (Option D ruled out): Eusol-C is a valid medium, but 6-0 prolene is too thick for corneal suturing.

questions.text: The following approach is used in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Correcting Dog ear

Explanation:

  • Dog's ear refers to a puckered or folded deformity at the end of a wound or incision, often occurring after elliptical excisions or closures under tension.
  • The approach used to correct a dog's ear involves triangular excision and re-approximation to flatten the skin and ensure a smooth closure.

Keloid excision (Option A) - Typically involves wider excision and adjunct therapies (e.g., steroids, radiation).

Abscess Drainage (Option B) - Requires incision and drainage, not dog-ear correction.

Split thickness skin graft (Option D) - Skin grafts are used to achieve wound closure in situations where the skin defects are too large for primary closure and healing by secondary intention may be inappropriate or lead to an unreasonable delay in complete healing such as burns.

questions.text: Based on the eye movement findings shown in the image below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option B) Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO)

Explanation: The eye on the side of the MLF lesion cannot turn inward (adduct) fully when attempting to look horizontally away from the lesion.

Horizontal Gaze Palsy (Option A ruled out)

  • Definition: Inability to voluntarily move both eyes beyond the midline in one horizontal direction.
  • Eye Movements:
    • Affected Side: Both eyes cannot look towards the involved side.
    • Unaffected Side: Gaze to the opposite side is typically normal.
    • Convergence: Usually preserved.
    • Oculocephalic Reflex: May overcome the palsy (if supranuclear lesion), indicating brainstem integrity.

Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO) (Option B)

  • Definition: Lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), disrupting horizontal gaze coordination.
  • Eye Movements:
    • Ipsilateral Eye (side of lesion): Impaired or slowed adduction (inward movement) when looking away from the lesion.
    • Contralateral Eye (opposite side): Abducting nystagmus (jerking outward movements).
    • Convergence: Crucially preserved.
    • Vertical Gaze: May be affected in bilateral cases.

3rd Nerve Palsy (Oculomotor Nerve Palsy) (Option C ruled out)

  • Definition: Dysfunction of the oculomotor nerve, controlling most eye movements and eyelid elevation.
  • Eye Movements (typically unilateral):
    • Resting Position: Eye is "down and out" (abducted and depressed).
    • Impaired Movements: Cannot adduct, elevate, or depress past the midline.
    • Pupil: Often dilated and unreactive (if parasympathetic fibers involved).
    • Ptosis: Drooping of the eyelid (partial or complete).

Myasthenia Gravis (Option D ruled out)

  • Definition: Autoimmune disorder causing fluctuating weakness of voluntary muscles, including ocular muscles.
  • Eye Movements (highly variable and fatiguing):
    • Ptosis: Common, often asymmetrical, fluctuates (worsens with fatigue, improves with rest).
    • Diplopia: Common, variable, affecting any direction of gaze, often changing.
    • Ophthalmoplegia: Weakness in any eye movement, non-localizing (doesn't fit a specific nerve palsy).
    • Fatigability: Eye movements worsen with sustained effort.
    • Pupils: Always normal.
    • Cogan's Lid Twitch: Brief overshoot of upper eyelid after downward gaze, followed by slow drop.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves gives sensory supply to the orbit?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option B) Trigeminal nerve

Explanation

  • Trigeminal nerve (Cranial Nerve V) (Option B): This nerve is the primary sensory nerve for the face, including the orbit and its contents. Its ophthalmic division (V1) specifically provides sensory innervation to:
    • The eye itself (cornea, conjunctiva, iris, ciliary body)
    • The lacrimal gland
    • The skin of the upper eyelid, forehead, and bridge of the nose
    • Parts of the nasal cavity and sinuses.

Let's look at why the other options are incorrect:

  • Vagus nerve (Cranial Nerve X) (Option A ruled out): Primarily involved in parasympathetic control of internal organs (heart, lungs, digestive system), and provides some sensory input from the ear and pharynx, but not the orbit.
  • Hypoglossal nerve (Cranial Nerve XII) (Option C ruled out): Purely a motor nerve that controls the muscles of the tongue.
  • Oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III) (Option D ruled out): Primarily a motor nerve that controls most of the extraocular muscles (eye movements) and provides parasympathetic innervation to the pupil and ciliary muscle (for accommodation). It has very limited, if any, direct sensory supply to the orbit itself.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a recognised cause of recurrent renal stone formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) ﻿﻿﻿Hypercitraturia

Explanation:

  • Hypercitraturia is not a known cause of recurrent renal stone formation, whereas Hypocitraturia is a common, correctable cause of recurrent stone formation.
  • Risk factors for the formation of Renal Stones:

Risk factors

Description

Dietary factors
  • Low calcium intake can lead to stone formation (low calcium can lead to high oxalate absorption).
  • High oxalate intake
  • High animal protein intake (leads to hypercalciuria and hyperuricosuria)
  • Higher sodium and sucrose intake (hypercalciuria)
  • Dehydration or inadequate fluid intake (leads to volume depletion)
  • Sugar-sweetened beverages

Non-dietary factors
  • More common in middle age group
  • Low urine output (due to a hot environment, lack of access to water or a bathroom)

Urinary factors
  • Hypercalciuria (Option B)
  • Hyperuricosuria (Option D)
  • Hyperoxaluria (Option A)
  • Low urine excretion of citrate (citrate inhibits stone formation)
  • Urinary pH:
    • Acidic: Uric acid stone formation
    • Alkaline: Calcium phosphate stone formation

Associated disorders
  • Idiopathic hypercalciuria (recurrent renal stones)
  • Inflammatory Bowel disease (IBD), especially Crohn’s Disease (calcium oxalate stones)
  • Gastric bypass surgery
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism (calcium oxalate stones)
  • Obesity
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Diabetes mellitus (Type 2)
  • Renal tubular acidosis Type 1 or distal (calcium phosphate stones)
  • Disorders like hypertension, gout, cardiovascular disease, cholelithiasis, reduced bone mineral density, and chronic kidney disease can also increase the risk for stone formation.

Genetic disorders
  • Family history of stones
  • Medullary sponge kidney: A congenital disorder marked by malformations of the papillary collecting ducts in the renal pyramids, leading to microscopic and large medullary cysts, often presenting as renal stones.
  • Cystinuria: Reabsorption of filtered cystine, ornithine, arginine, and lysine caused by mutations in the SLC3A1 amino acid transporter gene, resulting in a high cystine concentration in urine and the formation of cystine stones.
  • Primary hyperoxaluria: It is characterised by excessive endogenous oxalate production by the liver.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions may require a cochlear implant?

A. Congenital deafness

B. Ototoxicity

C. Otosclerosis

D. Congenital Stapes fixation
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - A & B - Congenital deafness and Ototoxicity

Explanation:

Congenital deafness (Option A):

  • This often refers to sensorineural hearing loss present at birth. If the deafness is severe to profound and cannot be adequately managed with hearing aids, cochlear implants are a primary and highly effective treatment for congenital sensorineural deafness, especially when implanted early in life.

Ototoxicity (Option B):

  • This is hearing loss caused by damage to the inner ear or auditory nerve due to certain drugs. If the damage results in severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss, a cochlear implant may be necessary if hearing aids provide insufficient benefit.

Otosclerosis (Option C ruled out):

  • This is a bone growth disorder that typically causes conductive hearing loss by fixing the stapes bone in the middle ear. While otosclerosis primarily causes conductive hearing loss, it can sometimes have a sensorineural component if the disease extends to the cochlea ("cochlear otosclerosis"). In cases of severe mixed hearing loss (with a significant sensorineural component) that is not adequately treated by surgery (stapedectomy) or hearing aids, a cochlear implant might be considered. However, it's not the primary indication for otosclerosis unless the sensorineural component is profound.

Congenital malleus fixation (Option D ruled out):

  • This is a condition where the malleus bone in the middle ear is fixed, leading to conductive hearing loss. This type of hearing loss is usually treated surgically (e.g., ossiculoplasty) or with conventional hearing aids, as the inner ear function (cochlea and auditory nerve) is typically normal. A cochlear implant is generally not indicated for purely conductive hearing loss like isolated malleus fixation, as it bypasses the middle ear.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male presents with a complicated urinary tract infection and is found to be hypotensive. His blood pressure does not respond to intravenous fluids. Which of the following is the most appropriate antibiotic to manage his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Meropenem

Explanation:

Meropenem is the most appropriate antibiotic for a diabetic patient in septic shock due to a complicated UTI, providing necessary broad-spectrum coverage, including for ESBL-producing organisms.

In the given scenario, the patient with a complicated UTI and septic shock is most likely infected with Pseudomonas or Klebsiella, for which the drug of choice is meropenem, a Carbapenem antibiotic.

  • MOA: Inhibits transpeptidase (penicillin-binding protein) and prevents cross-linking.
  • Drugs:
    • Imipenem
    • Meropenem
    • Faropenem
    • Doripenem
    • Ertapenem
  • Uses of carbapenems:
    • Used in nosocomial infections.
      • Meropenem is a reserve drug for the treatment of serious nosocomial infections like septicaemia, febrile neutropenia, intraabdominal and pelvic infections, etc., caused by cephalosporin-resistant bacteria and diabetic foot. (Option C)
    • DOC in
      • Acinetobacter baumannii (Ventilator-associated pneumonia)
      • Klebsiella
      • Burkholderia
      • Serratia
      • Proteus
      • Pseudomonas

Incorrect Options:

Amoxicillin-clavulanate (amoxiclav) (Option A) is ineffective for complicated UTIs with resistant Pseudomonas or ESBL-producing Klebsiella and is unsuitable for severe infections where meropenem is preferred.

Nitrofurantoin (Option B) is effective for uncomplicated lower UTIs but poorly penetrates blood and renal tissue, making it ineffective for complicated UTIs or septic shock. It also lacks activity against Pseudomonas and many Klebsiella strains in severe infections.

Ciprofloxacin (Option D) has broad activity, including against Pseudomonas, but rising resistance in hospital settings limits its use. It is not first-line for critically ill septic patients, where meropenem is preferred.

questions.text: A patient underwent cardiac surgery and was admitted to the ICU. He later developed ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and was started on empirical antibiotics. A few hours later, the patient developed acute kidney injury (AKI). Serum procalcitonin was sent. Which of the following statements regarding procalcitonin is correct?

choices.text: It helps in determining the duration of antibiotic therapy
It helps in identifying which empirical antibiotics to be given
It can be used to confirm source of infection
It is used to differentiate bacterial from fungal cause

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It helps in determining the duration of antibiotic therapy

Explanation:

  • Procalcitonin (PCT) is widely used to guide the duration of antibiotic therapy, especially in ICU settings and conditions like ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Serial PCT measurements help determine when to discontinue antibiotics, usually when PCT falls below 0.25–0.5 ng/mL or decreases by 80–90% from the peak value.

Role of Procalcitonin:

  • Helps detect bacterial infections early and differentiate from non-bacterial causes.
  • Guides when to start or stop antibiotics based on specific cut-off values.
  • Decreases by ~50% every 24 hours after infection control, helping monitor treatment.
  • Differentiates between infectious and non-infectious conditions in various diseases.
  • Reduces unnecessary antibiotic use in respiratory, postoperative, and other conditions.
  • Correlates with severity in sepsis, offering prognostic information.
  • Used in ED and ICU algorithms to manage antibiotic timing and duration.
  • Levels <0.1 ng/mL have high negative predictive value to rule out bacterial infections.

Incorrect Options:

It helps in identifying which empirical antibiotics to be given (Option B): PCT does not identify specific pathogens or recommend particular antibiotics. It only indicates the likelihood of a bacterial infection, not which organisms are involved or their sensitivity patterns. Empirical antibiotic selection is based on clinical judgment, local antibiograms, and patient risk factors.

It can be used to confirm source of infection (Option C): PCT is a non-specific marker of systemic bacterial infection and cannot pinpoint the source (e.g., lungs, urinary tract, blood). Imaging and cultures are needed to confirm the anatomical site of infection.

It is used to differentiate bacterial from fungal cause (Option D): While PCT can help distinguish bacterial from viral infections, it is not reliable in differentiating bacterial from fungal infections. Invasive fungal infections may not always cause elevated PCT levels, limiting its utility in such cases.

questions.text: According to WHO, which of the following is the recommended diagnostic test for spinal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Culture and Sensitivity

Explanation:

  • According to the World Health Organization (WHO), the recommended and definitive diagnostic test for spinal tuberculosis is Culture and Sensitivity.
  • Spinal tuberculosis, also known as Pott’s disease, is a form of extrapulmonary TB that primarily affects the vertebral column.
  • Diagnosing spinal TB is more complex than pulmonary TB because it typically involves deeper tissues and presents with nonspecific symptoms like chronic back pain, fever, weight loss, and neurological deficits in advanced stages.
  • WHO strongly recommends CB-NAAT as a first-line test for extrapulmonary TB, including spinal TB, because it gives results within hours and helps initiate treatment quickly.
  • However, due to its certain limitations, it cannot replace culture as the definitive test. (Option C)

Imaging used for diagnosing Pott’s spine:

MRI:

  • Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
  • IOC for potts spine and potts paraplegia.
  • But doesn't help to visualize bony vertebral destruction.
  • Earlier signs, spinal nerve root, and paraspinal soft tissue are better visualized.
  • The best diagnostic modality for spinal TB.

CT scan: (Option B)

  • The most preferred imaging modality for the assessment of destruction of the vertebral body and sequestrum formation.
  • The pattern of bone damage, including fragmentary, osteolytic, sclerotic, and subperiosteal changes, is clearly visible on CT scans.

X-ray: (Option A)

  • is useful as an initial imaging tool, but it lacks sensitivity and may miss early disease.
  • Findings are:
    • Reduction of disc space- Lateral X-ray is better for the evaluation of disc space.
    • In the early stages- wedging of the vertebrae.
    • In late stages- angular kyphotic deformity.
    • Evidence of cold abscess:
      • Bird nest appearance of cold abscess of the thoracic region showing typical fusiform shape.
    • Rarefaction: There is diffuse rarefaction of the vertebrae above and below the lesion.
    • Types of lesions in the vertebral column are:
      • Paradiscal (most common)
      • Central
      • Anterior
      • Posterior ( pedicle, lamina, spinous process, and transverse process)
    • Signs of healing:
      • Sclerosis
      • Sclerotic bone
      • Bony fusion

questions.text: In a chronic limb ischemia patient, what is the ABI below which gangrene is imminent:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 0.3

Explanation:

An Ankle Brachial Index < 0.3 indicates an imminently threatened leg and requires urgent vascular assessment/revascularisation to prevent major amputation.

Chronic Limb Threatening Ischemia (CLTI) is defined as rest pain or tissue loss (ulcers, or gangrene) supported by ischemia defined by the hemodynamic criteria of low ankle or toe pressures, or low transcutaneous oxygen (TcO2) values. Ankle pressure criteria range from less than 40–70mmHg, toe pressures less than 30–50mmHg, TcO2 less than 20–40mmHg. CLTI is assessed by measuring Ankle Brachial Pressure Index or Ankle Brachial Index (ABPI/ABI).

  • ABPI is measured supine by checking the systolic blood pressure in both upper and lower limbs (brachial, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis arteries). The higher value from each limb is used to calculate the ABPI.
  • This index is calculated as:

ABI = Systolic BP in the Ankle/ Systolic BP in the arm
  • Interpretations are as follows:

Value

Interpretation

0.1 - 0.4

Critical limb ischemia

0.5 - 0.9

Intermittent claudication

1.0 - 1.2

Normal

> 1.2

Calcified vessels (seen in patients with DM, End stage renal disease)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: Cannabis causes minimal physical withdrawal symptoms
Opioid withdrawal rarely results in death
Buprenorphine is used in opioid withdrawal treatment
Flumazenil is used in the long-term treatment of alcohol dependence

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Flumazenil is used in the long-term treatment of alcohol dependence

Explanation:

  • Flumazenil is not used in the long-term treatment of alcohol dependence. It is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist and is used as an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose.
  • Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease characterised by an inability to control alcohol consumption despite adverse social, occupational, or health consequences. Dependence occurs only in heavy and round-the-clock drinking.
  • Management of alcohol dependence:
    • Both psychological and medical supportive measures should be provided.
    • Anti-craving drugs

Anti-craving drugs
 

Drug Name

Mechanism of Action

Notes

FDA-
approved anti-craving drugs

Disulfiram

Inhibits acetaldehyde dehydrogenase ADH

Aversive agent to be used only in highly motivated person by causing unpleasant reactions if alcohol is consumed

Naltrexone

Blocks opioid receptors

Reduces cravings and desire to drink

Acamprosate

Modulates glutamate & GABA systems

Reduces cravings and helps maintain abstinence

Not FDA-
approved (off-label use)

Baclofen

GABA agonist

Helps with alcohol withdrawal symptoms

Gabapentin

& Topiramate

Modulates GABA & glutamate systems

Helps with alcohol withdrawal symptoms

Incorrect Options:

Cannabis causes minimal physical withdrawal symptoms (Option A): Cannabis withdrawal typically includes mild psychological symptoms physical withdrawal is minimal and non-life-threatening.

  • Common symptoms include:
    • Irritability
    • Anxiety
    • Disturbed sleep/dreaming
    • Depressed mood
    • Loss of appetite
    • Cannabis cravings
    • Nervousness
    • Restlessness
  • Less Common Symptoms:
    • Headaches
    • Physical tension
    • Sweating
    • Chills
    • Stomach pain
    • Tremors

Opioid withdrawal rarely results in death (Option B): Although opioid withdrawal can be extremely uncomfortable (nausea, vomiting, cramps, sweating, anxiety), it is rarely fatal, unlike alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal, which can be life-threatening. Opioid withdrawal symptoms include:

  • Muscle and Bone aches, Abdominal cramps
  • Diarrhoea, Lacrimation, Rhinorrhea, Sweating - resembles flu
  • Piloerection/ Gooseflesh ("Cold Turkey" Means Abstinence Syndrome)
  • Frequent yawning, Insomnia
  • Mydriasis
  • Hypertension, Tachycardia
  • Temperature Dysregulation (Hypothermia Or Hyperthermia)
  • Nausea, vomiting, and restlessness

Buprenorphine is used in opioid withdrawal treatment (Option C): Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist used in medication-assisted treatment for opioid withdrawal and maintenance therapy. It helps relieve withdrawal symptoms and cravings with a lower risk of overdose.

questions.text: In statistics, what do centiles and quartiles primarily represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Measures of position

Explanation:

Centiles and quartiles represent Measures of Position.

  • These are statistical tools used to describe the relative location of a data point within a dataset. They help determine where a specific value lies about the rest of the data.
  • It includes: (Option C)
    • Percentiles (Centiles): Divide data into 100 equal parts. For example, the 70th percentile means 70% of the data fall below that value.
    • Quartiles: Divide data into four equal parts

Measures of Central Tendency (Option A): .

  • Most affected by outliers: Mean
  • The best measure of central tendency in skewed observations: Median
  • The least affected measure: Mode

Measures of Dispersion (Option B):

Measures

Definition

Calculation

Standard deviation

Measures the variation or dispersion of a set of values around the mean.

σ = √(∑(x− x̄)2 /n)

Range

The difference between the highest and lowest values in a dataset.

Range = Maximum value - Minimum value

Mean deviation

Measures the average absolute deviation of data points from the mean.

Mean deviation = ∑ X - x̄ / n

Variance

Measures the average of the squared differences from the mean.

Variance = σ2


Measures of correlation (Option D) show how two variables relate, indicating the strength and direction of their association. Pearson’s coefficient (r) ranges from -1 to +1, with values near 0 showing no linear relationship. Unlike position measures, correlation doesn’t indicate individual data ranks and doesn’t imply causation.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Lumbar puncture

choices.text: PDPH is commonly seen in young females
Meningitis is not a common complication of lumbar puncture
Lumbar puncture must be done in patients with SAH with normal NCCT
Lumbar puncture is safe in thrombocytopenia<10k

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lumbar puncture is safe in thrombocytopenia < 10k

Explanation:

  • Lumbar Puncture is contraindicated in patients with Platelet count below 50,000 (plts)/μLas it carries a high risk of spinal/epidural hematoma. (Option D)
  • Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is a well-known complication of LP, more common in young adults, especially females. (Option A)
    • It occurs due to CSF leak following a puncture of the dura mater in procedures involving spinal anesthesia, epidural catheter placement.
  • Meningitis after LP is rare if aseptic technique is followed, hence this statement is correct. (Option B)
    • Introducing a needle into an infected area carries a high risk of spreading the infection to the spinal canal, potentially leading to meningitis or epidural abscess.
  • In suspected subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) the first-line investigation is non-contrast CT (NCCT) of the head and sometimes NCCT can show normal findings.
    • In such cases, LP is mandatory to confirm or rule out SAH, to look for Xanthochromia (yellow discoloration due to breakdown of RBCs) in the CSF. (Option C)
       

Indications of Lumbar Puncture:

  • Meningitis
  • Encephalitis
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)
  • Suspicion of nervous system diseases (like Guillain-Barré syndrome and carcinomatous meningitis)
  • Therapeutic relief of pseudotumor cerebri
  • Encephalitis
  • Dementia
  • Myelitis
  • Leukemia
  • Autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis

Contraindications of Lumbar Puncture:

Absolute Contraindications

Relative Contraindications
  • Presence of infected skin or cellulitis at the site of needle insertion.
  • Evidence of unequal intracranial pressures between the supratentorial and infratentorial compartments
  • Increased ICP
  • Coagulopathy or bleeding disorders
  • Brain abscess

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Thalidomide is correct?

a. It acts as an antimetabolite and is useful as an immunosuppressant

b. It is used in the treatment of multiple myeloma

c. It is used in the management of Type 2 lepra reaction (ENL)

d. It is teratogenic
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) b, c, d

Explanation:

Statements b, c, and d about Thalidomide are accurate

  • It is an anti-inflammatory. cytokine (TNF-alpha, ILs, interferon) modulating drug with anxiolytic, antiemetic properties.
  • MOA: Acts by suppressing TNF-alpha and modulating IL-2.
  • It is highly teratogenic (Statement d)
    • Phocomelia (seal limb): Limbs are severely shortened or absent.
  • Uses:
    • Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) as an alternative to prednisolone. (Statement c)
    • Multiple myeloma (Statement b)
    • Conditions in which cytokine play an important role like cancer-associated cachexia.

questions.text: Gene pool refers to all the alleles in a:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Population

Explanation:

The gene pool consists of all copies of every type of allele at every locus in all members of the population. This definition emphasizes that the gene pool encompasses genetic variation across an entire population, not just an individual or family.

 

Family (Option A) A family represents only a small subset of a population and does not encompass all genetic diversity.

 

Individual (Option B) An individual has only two alleles per gene (diploid), not the entire pool of alleles.

 

Tissue (Option D) Tissue is a group of cells that have similar structure and that function together as a unit.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with bipolar disorder is planning a pregnancy. Which drug is avoided due to neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Valproate

Explanation:

  • Valproate (Valproic acid) is avoided in pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, due to its strong teratogenic potential, most notably:
    • Neural tube defects (NTDs)
    • Other congenital malformations
    • Cognitive and behavioural deficits
  • Lamotrigine is considered one of the safest medications for pregnant individuals with bipolar disorder, with a low risk of fetal malformations and no adverse effects on postpartum cognitive development. (Option C)

Treatment of Bipolar Disorder (BD) in Pregnancy:

  • The safety of pharmacotherapeutic agents for treating bipolar disorder must be considered in terms of the following:
  1. Teratogenicity
  2. Poor neonatal adaptation
  3. Long-term neurobehavioral sequelae

Medication

Potential Fetal/Newborn Risk

Clinical Recommendation

Mood Stabilizers

Lithium

  • Low risk of Ebstein’s anomaly: 1 in 1000 with first-trimester exposure
  • No evidence of behavioural or cognitive problems in children exposed to lithium till 5 years of age
  • Fetal echocardiography
  • Frequent serum lithium monitoring in view of fluid shifts during pregnancy
  • Should be well hydrated to reduce the chances of lithium toxicity

Valproic acid

  • Increased rate of congenital malformations (approximately 10%), including neural tube defects
  • Linked to neurodevelopmental disorders in children with in-utero exposure
  • Must be avoided in favour of safer agents
  • Before conception, women with BD should preferably be shifted to another safer prophylactic agent
  • High-dose folic acid supplementation (4 mg/day) is advised before conception

Carbamazepine
  • Congenital malformations: Around 3%–6%
  • Neural tube defect, cleft palate, fingernail hypoplasia
  • Risk of bleeding diathesis in neonates due to Vitamin K deficiency
  • If possible, use during pregnancy should be avoided
  • High-dose folic acid supplementation (4 mg/day) is advised before conception
  • Oral Vitamin K (20mg/day) supplementation in the last month of pregnancy in women taking carbamazepine
  • Parenteral Vitamin K (1mg IM) supplementation for newborns shortly after birth.

Lamotrigine


 
  • Risk of major congenital malformations (2%–3%)
  • No significant neurobehavioral sequelae
  • Preferred safer agent to use in pregnancy
  • The dose may be increased due to enhanced clearance rates across pregnancy stages

Other Drugs for Bipolar Disorder Safe in Pregnancy
  • First Generation Antipsychotics (FGA): Haloperidol, Trifluoperazine
  • Second Generation Antipsychotics (SGA): Olanzapine, quetiapine, aripiprazole
  • Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs): Fluoxetine, escitalopram, sertraline, fluvoxamine

Oxcarbazepine (Option B) has comparatively low risk, and it has less teratogenic potential than valproate. It can be considered during pregnancy with monitoring, though it may be associated with hyponatremia and a potential risk of minor malformations.

﻿﻿﻿Levetiracetam (Option C) is an antiepileptic drug and is generally considered safe in pregnancy. It is associated with a low risk of major congenital malformations, especially compared to older AEDs like valproate or carbamazepine.

questions.text:
Which protozoans have two morphologic forms?


	Naegleria fowleri
	Acanthamoeba
	Trichomonas
	Giardia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1,2,4

Explanation:

Naegleria fowleri, Acanthamoeba, and Giardia have two morphologic forms.

Naegleria fowleri:

Naegleria is a free-living amoeba commonly found in warm freshwater environments. In nature, it exists in two forms: cysts and trophozoites.

  • Cyst: Round
  • Trophozoite: Can occur in two forms – amoeboid and flagellated forms.

Life cycle:

  • Infective form: Trophozoite.
  • Mode of transmission: Nasal contamination occurs during swimming in fresh, hot water bodies like ponds, rivers, swimming pools, or lakes.
  • CNS invasion: Invades nasal mucosa → Cribriform plate → Olfactory nerve → Brain → Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis.

Acanthamoeba:

These species are free-living amoebae that infect CNS, skin and eye.

  • Morphology: Cyst and trophozoite forms. There is no flagellated form.
  • Infective form: Both cysts and trophozoites.
  • Mode of transmission: Entry through inhalation, ingestion, and cutaneous/ ocular contaminated lens solution.
  • It causes:
    • GAE (granulomatous amoebic encephalitis) in immunocompromised patients.
    • Keratitis among contact lens users.

Trophozoite

Cyst

  • Show spikes (Acantho - Spikes)

  • Double-walled, with an outer wrinkled cyst wall.

Giardia lamblia: The life cycle of Giardia lamblia involves ingestion of cysts from contaminated food or water. These cysts transform into trophozoites in the small intestine, multiply, and eventually form new cysts that are excreted in the feces to infect new hosts. This causes giardiasis.

Trichomoniasis (Option 3) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis, and it does not have two different morphological forms. It typically presents with the frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge with a foul odour, along with vaginal itching and discomfort during urination. The characteristic appearance seen is ‘Strawberry cervix,’ an erythematous and edematous cervical mucosa with characteristic punctate red papules. It is caused by microscopic punctate haemorrhages of the cervix. The standard treatment is Metronidazole 2g PO single dose.

questions.text: A male presents with lesions and a history of unprotected sexual intercourse a few months ago. What is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Serology

Explanation:

The lesions depicted in the image, along with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse, suggest a diagnosis of Secondary Syphilis, which is best confirmed through serological testing.

  • It is the second stage of syphilis, which occurs if primary syphilis is left untreated.
  • It presents a few weeks to several months after the initial chancre has healed.
  • It is marked by systemic manifestations and can affect multiple organ systems.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Diffuse, non-pruritic rash, often reddish-brown macules or papules, that is polymorphous and non-vesicular.
    • Mucous membrane lesions, such as condylomata lata, appear in moist areas like the oral cavity and genitals and are highly infectious.
    • Oral signs may include mucous patches or snail track ulcers.
    • “Moth-eaten" alopecia: A patchy, non-scarring hair loss.
    • Buschke-Ollendorff sign: Deep tenderness over lesions.
    • Painless generalized lymphadenopathy (especially epitrochlear nodes)l.
    • Systemic symptoms include fever, malaise, and fatigue, with rare cases showing neurological or ocular involvement.
  • Diagnosis: By serological testing: (Option A)
    • Non-Treponemal Tests:
      • RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin) and VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) are used for screening.
      • These tests detect nonspecific antibodies and can be positive in other conditions.
    • Treponemal Tests:
      • FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption) confirms the diagnosis by detecting antibodies specific to Treponema pallidum.
  • Treatment:
    • Standard treatment: Benzathine penicillin G.
    • Dosage: 2.4 million units intramuscularly in a single dose.
    • For those allergic to penicillin, alternatives such as doxycycline or tetracycline can be used.
  • Complications: If left untreated, secondary syphilis can progress to the latent stage and eventually tertiary syphilis, which can lead to serious complications, including cardiovascular, neurological, and systemic damage.

Tzanck smear (Option B) is a diagnostic test primarily used for identifying infections caused by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) and Varicella-Zoster Virus. It involves examining cells scraped from a lesion under a microscope. However, this test has no role in diagnosing syphilis, as it does not detect Treponema pallidum, the bacterium responsible for the disease.

KOH preparation (Option C) is commonly employed to diagnose superficial fungal infections such as dermatophytosis or candidiasis. A sample from the skin, hair, or nails is treated with potassium hydroxide, which dissolves keratin and allows for the visualization of fungal elements under a microscope. Since syphilis is a bacterial infection, this test is irrelevant in its diagnosis.


Biopsy (Option D) is used to evaluate suspicious skin lesions when the diagnosis is unclear, and it can sometimes reveal histopathological features suggestive of syphilis. It is invasive and nonspecific, whereas serological tests are more sensitive, specific, and the preferred method for diagnosing secondary syphilis.

questions.text: Based on the given CT finding, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option C) Neurocysticercosis

Explanation-

  • Vesicular: CSF-density cyst with a hyperdense "dot" (scolex). No/minimal edema or enhancement.
  • Colloidal Vesicular: Hyperattenuating cyst fluid, thick/irregular ring enhancement, significant perilesional edema. Most symptomatic stage.
  • Granular Nodular: Shrinking cyst forming an enhancing nodule. Decreasing edema.
  • Nodular Calcified: Small, punctate hyperdense (bright) calcification. No edema or enhancement.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features of the Bezold-Jarisch reflex?


	Hypopnea
	Bradycardia
	Hypotension
	Tachycardia
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option a) A,B and C

Feature

Bezold–Jarisch Reflex

Area Involved

Chemosensitive vagal C fibers located in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g., alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, pulmonary artery).

Pathophysiology

Triggered by conditions affecting the heart or blood volume, such as myocardial ischemia, exposure to toxic chemicals or radio-contrast, or as a protective response in vasovagal and postural syncope.

Response

It leads to hypotension (decreased blood pressure), profound bradycardia (slow heart rate), and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid, shallow breathing.
