  • Sporothrix

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with complaints of lower abdominal pain, and passage of blood mixed with stools for the past 3 months. Based on his radiological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option A) Ulcerative colitis

Explanation

Option A - Ulcerative Colitis (UC) - Symptoms:

  • Lower abdominal pain: Common in UC, often colicky or cramping.
  • Passage of blood mixed with stools: A cardinal symptom of UC, as the inflammation primarily affects the superficial mucosal lining, leading to friability and bleeding.
  • 3 months duration: Fits the chronic, relapsing-remitting nature of IBD.
  • 26-year-old male: UC commonly presents in young adults.

Ulcerative Colitis (UC) - Xrays

  • Loss of haustral markings ("lead pipe" or "garden hose" appearance): This is a classic sign of chronic UC due to continuous inflammation and fibrosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pseudomembranous Colitis (PMC) - X-rays:

  • Often non-specific in early or mild cases.
  • Colonic dilatation: Can be diffuse or segmental.
  • Nodular haustral thickening / "Thumbprinting": This is a relatively classic finding, representing prominent edema and thickening of the haustral folds, and is often more pronounced than in UC. It can also be seen in ischemic colitis.

Option C - Crohn's Disease - X-rays:

  • Often normal.
  • Dilated loops of small bowel with air-fluid levels: Suggestive of small bowel obstruction, a common complication due to strictures.
  • "String sign": Severe narrowing of a segment of bowel, often the terminal ileum, appearing as a thin, continuous string of barium. This indicates a stricture.
  • "Skip lesions": Inflamed areas separated by normal bowel, a characteristic feature. Difficult to see on plain X-ray, more apparent on barium studies.

Option D - Intestinal Tuberculosis (TB) - X-rays:

  • Often non-specific.
  • Ascites: Can be present, especially in peritoneal TB.
  • Absence of gas shadows in the right iliac fossa: Due to thickened, matted bowel loops in the ileocecal region.

questions.text:
What are the correct timings for intrauterine device (IUD) insertion?


	Immediate postpartum
	Up to 48 hours postpartum
	Within 5-7 days of the menstrual cycle
	5-7 days before the next menstrual cycle
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A, B, C

Explanation:

Inserting an Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD) 5–7 days before the next menstrual cycle is not a standard or recommended practice, as it carries a higher risk of undetected pregnancy at the time of insertion.

  • They are small, T-shaped devices used for long-acting reversible contraception. They work through several mechanisms:
    • Prevention of Sperm Motility and Viability: IUCDs induce a local inflammatory response in the uterus, producing leukocytes and prostaglandins that hinder sperm motility and viability.
    • Alteration of Cervical Mucus: Hormonal IUCDs release progestin, which thickens cervical mucus, obstructing sperm entry into the uterus.
    • Inhibition of Ovulation: In hormonal IUCDs, progestin may suppress ovulation in some women, providing additional contraceptive effects.
    • Prevention of Implantation: IUCDs modify the endometrial lining, making it less conducive to implantation, though this is a secondary mechanism.

 

Timing of IUD insertion

Ideal time
  • During menstruation or within the first 10 days of the start of period (Point C)

Preferred time
  • Postpartum (immediate postpartum): Post-placenta insertion; Has a higher rate of expulsion (Point A)
  • Late postpartum: Within 48 hours of delivery or up to 1 week (Point B)

Other times
  • Post-puerperal: After 6-8 weeks of delivery
  • Post-coital: Up to 3-5 days after unprotected intercourse.
  • Post-abortion: After 1st trimester loss.
    • Not recommended after a 2nd trimester abortion.

questions.text: Gastric lavage treated with silver nitrate gives a black colour in poisoning with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aluminium phosphide

Explanation:

  • Aluminium phosphide (ALP) is a pesticide and upon ingestion, it with hydrochloric acid in the stomach to release phosphine gas (PH₃), which is the primary toxic agent.
  • When silver nitrate (AgNO₃) is added to the gastric lavage or exposed to the gas emitted from the stomach contents, phosphine gas reduces silver nitrate to metallic silver, which appears black.
  • If phosphine gas is present, the silver nitrate paper turns black, due to reduction of silver ions to elemental silver. This is a classical bedside test for confirming ALP poisoning.

Malathion (Option A) is a organophosphate and it does not interact with silver nitrate.

﻿﻿﻿Mercury (Option B): though it is associated with dark precipitates in other tests, mercury does not produce a black color with silver nitrate in gastric aspirate.

﻿﻿﻿Barbiturates (Option D) do not have any chemical reaction with silver nitrate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and a fever. On examination, the left breast appears as shown in the image below. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side and the contralateral breast is normal. Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover were unsuccessful. A USG done showed fluid collection. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Incision and drainage

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario described suggests that the patient may have developed a breast abscess.
  • Breast abscesses are typically caused by bacterial infection and are more common in lactating women due to the increased risk of bacterial colonization of the breast ducts.
  • The presence of fever, pain, and fluid collection seen on ultrasound are also consistent with a breast abscess.
  • Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover have been unsuccessful, suggesting that the abscess is not resolving with conservative management alone. Therefore, the next best step in the management of this patient would be incision and drainage of the abscess.
  • Incision and drainage is the most effective way to treat a breast abscess, as it allows for the complete removal of the infected material and helps to prevent recurrence.

Breast Abscess

Definition
  • Pus-filled cavity within breast tissue.

Types
  • Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding.
  • Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis.

Causes and Risk Factors
  • Lactation:
    • Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers.
    • Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings).
    • Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts.
  • Non-Lactation:
    • Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation.
    • Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis.
    • Smoking and diabetes as risk factors.

Signs and symptoms

Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography:
    • Detects cellulitis, liquefaction necrosis.
    • Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation.

Treatment
  • Lactational Mastitis:
    • Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin).
    • Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping.
    • Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia.
    • Drainage: Ultrasound-guided preferred over surgical incision.
    • Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews, culture-based antibiotic modification.
  • Non-Lactational Mastitis:
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections.
    • Needle aspiration for abscess drainage.
    • Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula.

Broad-spectrum antibiotics (Option B) may be used in conjunction with incision and drainage to treat the infection, but antibiotics alone are not sufficient for the management of a Breast abscess.

Breast conservation surgery (Option C) typically involves the removal of a breast lump or tumor. Thus, breast conservation surgery is not appropriate management option for a breast abscess.

Punch biopsy (Option C) is a diagnostic procedure used to obtain a tissue sample for analysis.

questions.text: IGF-1 and IGF-2 (Insulin-like Growth Factors) are structurally most similar to which of the following molecules?
questions.solution:
Correct answers- Option A) Insulin

 

Insulin-like Growth Factors (IGF-1 and IGF-2) are structurally most similar to Insulin (Option A)

Explanation: All three molecules share a similar protein fold and have significant sequence homology, meaning they share a large portion of their amino acid sequence.

Why other options are incorrect:

 

Proinsulin (Option B ruled out)
While proinsulin is the precursor to insulin, it is structurally closer to the mature insulin molecule than to IGFs. Proinsulin contains the A, B, and C peptides, which are all eventually cleaved to form mature insulin. IGFs, on the other hand, are single-chain proteins and do not undergo the same processing.

 

C peptide (Option C ruled out)
The C peptide is a part of proinsulin that is cleaved off during the maturation process to form insulin. Since IGFs are structurally different from proinsulin, they also have no structural similarity to the C peptide.

 

Preproinsulin (Option D ruled out)
Preproinsulin is the precursor to proinsulin, containing a signal peptide in addition to the A, B, and C peptides. While IGFs share structural similarities with insulin, they are not precursors to it and thus not structurally most similar to preproinsulin

questions.text: Which investigation is most useful for visualizing the individual layers of the retina?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option B) Optical Coherence Tomography

Explanation

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) (Option B):

  • Most useful.
  • Provides high-resolution, cross-sectional images.
  • Allows detailed visualization and measurement of individual retinal layers (e.g., nerve fiber layer, photoreceptor layers).
  • Essential for diagnosing and monitoring retinal diseases.

Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA) (Option A ruled out):

  • Visualizes retinal and choroidal blood vessels.
  • Highlights leakage, non-perfusion, or abnormal vasculature.
  • Does not provide layer-by-layer retinal images.

USG B-scan (Ultrasound B-scan)(Option C ruled out):

  • Uses sound waves; useful when view is obscured (e.g., hemorrhage).
  • Detects gross abnormalities (e.g., detachment, tumors).
  • Resolution not sufficient to see individual retinal layers.

Slit lamp examination(Option D ruled out):

  • Clinical tool for magnified, stereoscopic view of the retina.
  • Good for overall integrity and surface observation.
  • Does not provide cross-sectional, layer-by-layer resolution like OCT.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to a PHC for a routine check-up. His blood pressure readings on two separate occasions are 148/90 mmHg and 152/96 mmHg. He is asymptomatic and has no known comorbidities. What is the most appropriate next step in management according to current hypertension guidelines?

choices.text: Initiate treatment only if BP exceeds 160/100 mmHg
Start Amlodipine 5 mg once daily and advise follow-up in 1 month
Refer to a higher center for further evaluation
Start the patient on IV anti-hypertensive drugs

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Start Amlodipine 5 mg once daily and advise follow-up in 1 month

Explanation:

  • The patient is in Stage 1 Hypertension (140–159/90–99 mmHg) confirmed on two occasions, and since no compelling comorbidities are present, monotherapy with a calcium channel blocker (e.g., Amlodipine) is an appropriate first-line treatment. Follow-up in 1 month is standard to assess BP response and adherence.

ACC/AHA Guidelines for Hypertension Management

Indications for Use of antihypertensives

Secondary prevention of recurrent CVD events in patients with clinical CVD (defined as CHD, CHF, stroke) and BP ≥130/≥80 mmHg

Primary prevention in patients with an estimated 10-year ASCVD risk ≥10% and BP ≥130/≥80 mmHg

Primary prevention of CVD and low CVD risk in patients with BP ≥140/ ≥90 mmHg

Blood Pressure Goal in Treating Hypertension

BP target < 130/80 mmHg for adults with confirmed hypertension and known CVD or 10-year ASCVD event risk ≥10%

Exceptions to Therapeutic Target of <130/80 mmHg

Age >80 years

Blood pressure <140/90 mmHg in previously untreated hypertensive patients who experience an ischemic stroke or TIA

Acute therapy for most hypertensive urgencies and emergencies

Abbreviations:

  • ASCVD - atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease
  • CHD - coronary heart disease
  • CHF - congestive heart failure
  • CVD - cardiovascular disease

Patient type

First Drug

Add a Second Drug If Needed to Achieve the target BP

If a Third Drug is Needed to Achieve the target BP

Black patients (African ancestry): All ages

CCB or thiazide diuretic

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Combination of CCB + ACE inhibitor or ARB + thiazide diuretic

White and other non-black Patients: Younger than 60 years

ARB or ACE inhibitor

CCB or thiazide diuretic

White and other non-black patients: 60 years and older

CCB or thiazide diuretic

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Abbreviations:

  • CCB - Calcium channel blocker
  • ACE - Angiotensin converting enzyme
  • ARB - Angiotensin receptor blocker

Hypertension with other associated conditions

Initial drug of choice

Hypertension and diabetes

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Hypertension and chronic kidney disease

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Note: in black patients, good evidence for the renal protective effects of ACE inhibitors

Hypertension and clinical coronary artery disease

β-Blocker plus ARB or ACE inhibitor

Hypertension and stroke history

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Hypertension and heart failure

Regardless of blood pressure, ARB or ACE inhibitor + β-blocker + diuretic + spironolactone. A dihydropyridine CCB can be added if needed for BP control.

Pneumonic: ABDS

Incorrect Options:

Initiate treatment only if BP exceeds 160/100 mmHg (Option A): Older guidelines used this threshold for initiating therapy in asymptomatic patients without comorbidities, but current guidelines recommend starting antihypertensive therapy at ≥140/90 mmHg if confirmed on two separate occasions, even in low-risk individuals. Lifestyle changes + medications are appropriate here.

Refer to a higher center for further evaluation (Option C): There is no need for referral at this point. The patient has uncomplicated hypertension and can be managed at the primary health center (PHC) level with basic antihypertensive therapy and lifestyle advice.

Start the patient on IV anti-hypertensive drugs (Option D): IV antihypertensives are used for hypertensive emergencies (e.g., BP >180/120 mmHg with end-organ damage). This patient is stable and asymptomatic, with no signs of acute target organ damage — oral therapy is appropriate.

questions.text: All of the following are clinical uses of Magnesium Sulphate (MgSO₄), except:

choices.text: Decreases the incidence of placental abruption
Reduces the incidence of seizures in preeclampsia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Decreases the incidence of placental abruption

Explanation:

Magnesium Sulfate (MgSO₄) does not reduce the risk of placental abruption.

 

Aspect

Details

MOA
  • NMDA Receptor Blockade
  • Calcium Channel Blockade: reduces calcium influx into neurons.
  • Vasodilation: Improves cerebral blood flow and reduces cerebral edema, dilates uterine arteries, increases endothelial prostacyclin production and inhibits platelet activation. (Option D ruled out)

Uses
  • Prevent seizures in severe preeclampsia and eclampsia. Prevent recurrent seizures in eclampsia. (Option B ruled out)
  • Tocolytic effect (delaying preterm labor)
  • Neuroprotective -Protects the preterm baby's brain from damage by reducing the risk of cerebral palsy (Option C ruled out)

Therapeutic Range
  • To control fits the optimum serum magnesium is 4.8–8.4 mg/dL (4–7 mEq/L). Deep tendon reflex loss at 9 mg/dL (>7 mEq/L).

C/I
  • Myasthenia gravis, hypocalcemia, moderate-to-severe renal failure, cardiac ischemia, heart block, myocarditis.
  • Avoid if alternatives are justified.

Administration and Dosage
  • Administer: Intravenously or intramuscularly.
  • Loading dose: 4–6 g IV over 20–30 minutes. (Zuspan or Sibai regimen)
  • Maintenance: 1–2 g/hour IV. Monitor urine output and reflexes.

Dosage Adjustment
  • Adjust for renal dysfunction.

Adverse Effects
  • Primarily smooth muscle relaxant: Respiratory depression (at 12 mg/dL) and cardiac arrest (at 30 mg/dL).
  • Manage with calcium gluconate 10% and furosemide if needed.

questions.text: Which of the following psychoactive substances is a new, rapidly acting antidepressant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ketamine

Explanation:

  • Ketamine is a new, rapidly acting antidepressant that has gained significant attention in recent years, especially for patients with treatment-resistant depression (TRD) and suicidal ideation.
  • Ketamine is a NMDA receptor antagonist.
  • MOA: Blocks NMDA receptors on GABAergic interneurons → disinhibits glutamate neurons → glutamate burst.
    • It works by increasing glutamate, synaptic plasticity, and BDNF-mediated pathways.

Incorrect Options:

﻿﻿﻿Bupropion (Option B) is a atypical antidepressant used for depression and smoking cessation. It has a standard delayed onset of antidepressant action

﻿﻿﻿Haloperidol (Option C) belongs to the class of first-generation antipsychotic medications, also known as typical antipsychotics, primarily used for schizophrenia and acute psychosis. Not used for depression.

﻿﻿﻿Cannabinoids (Option D) do not have approved (FDA approval) or evidence-based use as antidepressants and are not rapid-acting.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a history of diarrhea associated with blood in stool for several weeks. On examination, the patient is febrile and has abdominal distension and tenderness. A CT scan (coronal view) shows a grossly dilated colon with loss of haustrations. Laboratory investigations reveal leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers. Based on the clinical and radiological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ulcerative colitis

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and CT findings are suggestive of Toxic megacolon, which is a severe complication most commonly associated with Ulcerative colitis.
  • It is a potentially life-threatening condition characterised by rapid dilation of the colon, systemic toxicity, and risk of perforation.
  • Ulcerative colitis is a type of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) that presents with abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and rectal bleeding as it primarily affects the colon and almost always involves the rectum with broad areas of ulceration.
  • Skip lesions, bowel wall thickening, and perianal manifestations like fissures and granulomas are uncommon in Ulcerative colitis.

Complications of Ulcerative Colitis

Complications of Crohn’s disease

(Option B)
  • Toxic megacolon
  • Intestinal perforation
  • Anaemia
  • Colonic malignancy (UC is a premalignant condition)
  • Perianal fistula
  • Abscess
  • Malabsorption syndrome
  • Strictures
  • Intestinal obstruction

Colonic carcinoma (Option C) usually presents with weight loss, anaemia, and change in bowel habits, but not commonly with acute febrile illness or diffuse colonic dilatation.

﻿﻿﻿Intestinal tuberculosis (Option D) commonly affects the ileocecal region, presents with chronic symptoms like abdominal pain, weight loss, and sometimes obstruction, but not normally with toxic megacolon.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath and B/L pedal edema. He is compliant with his antihypertensive medications, and blood pressure is well controlled. ECG reveals an ejection fraction of 60%, concentric left ventricular hypertrophy, left atrial enlargement, and grade 2 diastolic dysfunction. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to improve his condition?

choices.text: Perform coronary angiography to rule out ischemic cardiomyopathy
Initiate loop diuretics and SGLT2 inhibitors for management of HFpEF
Start digoxin to enhance myocardial contractility
Initiate ivabradine to reduce heart rate and improve diastolic filling

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Initiate loop diuretics and SGLT2 inhibitors for management of HFpEF

Explanation:

This 62-year-old man presents with sudden shortness of breath and bilateral pedal edema, classic signs of heart failure. His echocardiogram findings show:

  • Ejection fraction (EF) of 60% → Preserved systolic function
  • Concentric left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Left atrial enlargement
  • Grade 2 diastolic dysfunction

These findings support a diagnosis of Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF), which is often related to diastolic dysfunction, especially in older adults with hypertension-induced hypertrophy.

  • Loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide) help relieve volume overload symptoms like dyspnea and edema.
  • SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., empagliflozin, dapagliflozin) have been shown in recent trials to reduce hospitalization and improve quality of life in HFpEF, regardless of diabetes status.
  • This is the most appropriate and guideline-recommended management.

Types of heart failure:

  • HFrEF: Systolic dysfunction, may present acutely.
  • HFpEF: Diastolic dysfunction, usually present as chronic heart failure.

Management of CHF:

First line drugs used in chronic Heart failure: (mortality-reducing drugs)
  • ARBs/ACE-Inhibitors
  • Beta blockers (2nd gen- cardioselective)
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors (Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin)
  • Anti-aldosterone (Spironolactone)

Acute cases with Pulmonary edema:
  • Oxygen: Secure airway and supplement O2
  • Loop diuretics: IV Furosemide 20-80 mg, reduces preload and systemic venous congestion
  • IV Morphine: if patient is in severe pain/distress, can cause respiratory depression
  • IV Nitroglycerin infusion: reduce afterload

Acute decompensated with cardiogenic shock: (low BP)
  • Vasopressors: Norepinephrine, Dobutamine, Dopamine
  • Inodilators: Milrinone & Amrinone
  • Levosimendan: Ca2+ channel sensitizer
  • Omecamtiv mecarbil: Direct myosin activator

Non-pharmacological treatment:
  • Implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICD)
  • Coronary revascularisation: in Coronary artery disease patients
  • Ventricular assist devices
  • Cardiac transplantation

Incorrect Options:

Perform coronary angiography to rule out ischemic cardiomyopathy (Option A): Coronary angiography is appropriate if ischemic heart disease is strongly suspected. However, this patient has preserved EF and concentric LVH, which more strongly points toward hypertensive heart disease and HFpEF, not ischemic cardiomyopathy. This is not the most appropriate first step.

Start digoxin to enhance myocardial contractility (Option C): Digoxin is not indicated in HFpEF, especially when EF is preserved and there is no indication of systolic dysfunction or atrial fibrillation needing rate control. It is not helpful here.

Initiate ivabradine to reduce heart rate and improve diastolic filling (Option D): Ivabradine is indicated in HFrEF with EF ≤35% and sinus rhythm with heart rate ≥70 bpm, despite beta-blockers. It does not have a proven role in HFpEF.

questions.text:
Which of the following helminth is known to show autoinfection?


	H. nana
	Ascaris lumbricoides
	Ancylostoma duodenale
	Strongyloides stercoralis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 4

Explanation:

Among the given options, Hymenolepis nana and Strongyloides stercoralis shows Autoinfection.

  • Few intestinal parasites may infect the same person by contaminated hand (external autoinfection) or by reverse peristalsis (internal autoinfection).
  • Parasites that show Autoinfection in humans
    • Strongyloides stercoralis (Statement 4)
    • Enterobius vermicularis
    • Toxocara
    • Giardia lamblia
    • Ascaris lumbricoides
    • Schistosoma mansoni
    • Cryptosporidium spp.
    • Hymenolepis nana (Statement 1)

Ascaris lumbricoides (Option B) is a large roundworm that requires its eggs to develop in soil before becoming infective. Since it depends on external environmental conditions for development, it does not exhibit autoinfection.

Ancylostoma duodenale (Option C), a hookworm, requires external development in soil. The larvae infect humans by penetrating the skin, and like Ascaris, it does not undergo autoinfection within the host.

questions.text:
In a given population,

The number of individuals aged 0-14 years = 6,000

The number of individuals aged 15-59 years = 12,000

The number of individuals aged 60 years and above = 2,000

What is the dependency ratio of this population?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 0.66

Explanation:

The given population has a Dependency Ratio of 0.66.

  • It is the average number of economically dependent individuals per 100 economically productive individuals in a specific country, territory, or geographic area at a given time.
  • To calculate the dependency ratio, we use the formula:

In the given question,

The number of individuals aged 0-14 years = 6,000

The number of individuals aged 60 years and above = 2,000

The number of individuals aged 15-59 years = 12,000

 

Dependency Ratio: (6000 + 2000)/12000

= (8000/12000)

= 0.6667 per 100 economically productive individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an aneuploidy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bloom syndrome

Explanation:

  • Aneuploidy refers to a numerical abnormality in chromosomes — gain or loss of whole chromosomes.
  • Normal human chromosome number: 46 (2n)
    • Trisomy = 2n + 1 (47 chromosomes)
    • Monosomy = 2n – 1 (45 chromosomes)

Bloom Syndrome:

  • Genetic defect: Mutation in BLM gene on chromosome 15.
  • Autosomal recessive disorder caused by loss-of-function mutations in a DNA helicase that is required for homologous recombination repair in DNA repair.
  • Result: Defective DNA repair → Chromosomal instability → Predisposition to cancer.
  • Chromosome number is normal (46) - it’s a chromosomal instability disorder, not a numerical abnormality.

Condition

Description

Chromosome Count

Aneuploidy Type

Trisomy 13 (Option B)

Patau syndrome

47

2n + 1

Trisomy 21 (Option C)

Down syndrome

47

2n + 1

Klinefelter syndrome (Option D)

47,XXY (extra X chromosome in males)

47

2n + 1 (sex chromosome)

questions.text: Which of the following brain regions is primarily associated with the processing of explicit memory?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- a) Hippocampus

The brain region primarily associated with the processing of explicit memory is the hippocampus.

Explicit memory, also known as declarative memory, involves the conscious recollection of facts and events. This includes episodic memory (personal experiences) and semantic memory (general knowledge).

 

Amygdala (Option B): Primarily involved in processing emotions and attaching emotional significance to memories, particularly fear. While it influences memory, it's not the primary site for forming or retrieving explicit factual memories.

 

Insular cortex(Option C): Involved in a wide range of functions including interoception (awareness of internal bodily states), emotion, taste, and some aspects of recognition memory, but not the primary hub for explicit memory formation.

 

Prefrontal cortex(Option D): Crucial for working memory, executive functions, decision-making, and the retrieval and organization of long-term memories, but the hippocampus is the key structure for the initial formation and indexing of new explicit memories. Long-term storage of explicit memories is thought to ultimately reside in the neocortex, with the hippocampus playing a critical role in their consolidation and retrieval.

questions.text: The area marked by the arrows in the given histopathological image can influence the surrounding cells by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Paracrine effect

Explanation:

  • The area marked in the image is the Islet of Langerhans, located in the pancreas.

  • These hormones can act locally to influence nearby cells within the islet before reaching systemic circulation — this is known as a paracrine effect.

Paracrine Mechanism in the Islets:

Cell Type

Hormone Secreted

Paracrine Effect On

β cells

Insulin

Inhibits α cells (↓ glucagon)

α cells

Glucagon

Stimulates β cells (↑ insulin)

δ cells

Somatostatin

Inhibits both α and β cells

Portal Vasculature (Option A) - Not involved in direct local cell-to-cell signaling.

Nerve mediated (Option C) - Islet regulation is mostly hormonal, not neural.

Epitheliomesenchymal transition (Option D) - An epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) is a biologic process that allows a polarized epithelial cell, which normally interacts with basement membrane via its basal surface, to undergo multiple biochemical changes that enable it to assume a mesenchymal cell phenotype, which includes enhanced migratory capacity, invasiveness, elevated resistance to apoptosis, and greatly increased production of ECM components.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) TP53 - Mucosal Neuroma

  • TP53 is not associated with mucosal neuroma.

Gene

BRCA1

BRCA2 (Option D ruled out)

questions.text:
A patient presents with a progressive and asymptomatic lesion over the neck region and no systemic symptoms. Which of the following investigations would be helpful?




	KOH preparation
	Skin biopsy
	Chest X-ray (TB workup)
	HIV testing
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2,3

Explanation:

In a patient with a progressive, asymptomatic lesion over the neck, clinically suggestive of Lupus Vulgaris (a form of cutaneous tuberculosis), the most helpful investigation would be skin biopsy and TB workup.

  • It is a chronic, progressive, paucibacillary (not multibacillary) form of cutaneous tuberculosis.
  • Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous TB seen in adults (M/C in females).
  • Causative organisms: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium bovis.
  • Pathogenesis :
    • Route of spread: Endogenous spread or from exogenous inoculation.
    • It occurs in a previously sensitized individual with an increased cell-mediated immunity to tuberculin.
  • Clinical features:
    • Presents as a single or a group of erythematous violaceous annular plaques with central scarring and atrophy with active margins.
    • The periphery shows erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as apple jelly nodules.

  • Most commonly seen in the buttocks, upper extremities, and face.
  • Papules may recur within scarred areas, enlarging and coalescing into large, firm, elevated plaques.
  • Treatment: Antitibercular therapy.
  • Complication: Secondary scarring and squamous cell carcinoma may develop rarely.

KOH preparation (Option 1) is used to detect superficial fungal infections like tinea or candidiasis by identifying fungal elements in skin scrapings. Since lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, KOH is not helpful for its diagnosis.

HIV testing (Option 4) is useful in immunocompromised patients or atypical infections, but this patient has a localized, slow-growing lesion without systemic signs. It doesn't directly help diagnose lupus vulgaris and isn't a first-line test.

questions.text: Which is the most common HPV serotype associated with cervical carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HPV types 16 and 18

Explanation:

HPV types 16 and 18 are the most common HPV serotypes associated with cervical carcinoma.

Types of HPV

 

Cutaneous involvement

HPV 1, 2, 3 (low risk)
  • Filiform wart
  • Verruca Plantaris

HPV 5, 8 (high risk)
  • Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis

 

Mucosal involvement

HPV 6, 11 (low risk)
  • Condyloma Acuminatum
  • Recurrent laryngeal papillomas

HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 35 (high risk)
  • Squamous cell carcinoma
  • Clinically, HPV are divided into 2 types:
    • Low risk HPV (6 & 11) cause nearly all genital warts, laryngeal papillomas and are rarely oncogenic. (Option B ruled out)
    • High risk HPV (16 & 18) cause approximately 95% of cervical cancers. HPV 16 is the most oncogenic in high risk HPV types. (Option A)

Cutaneous involvement

Benign Warts
  • Common Skin Warts (Verruca Vulgaris): Small, hard, rough growths on the skin; commonly seen in children (associated with serotypes 2, 4, 27, 57).
  • Flat Warts (Verruca Plana): Also prevalent among children.
  • Plantar Warts (Verruca Plantaris): Benign lesions commonly found in adolescents (linked to serotype 1).

Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis
  • Rare autosomal recessive conditions may progress to squamous cell carcinoma, especially in sun-exposed areas.
  • Associated with serotypes 5 , 8, 9, 12, 17, 20, 36, and 47.

Mucosal involvement

Anogenital Warts
  • It is also known as Condyloma Acuminatum.
  • A sexually transmitted infection in adults, associated with HPV serotypes 6 and 11.

Head and Neck Lesions
  • Benign: Recurrent laryngeal papillomas, especially in children (serotypes 6, 11).
  • Malignant: Laryngeal and esophageal carcinomas (serotypes 16, 18)

Carcinoma Cervix
  • Mainly squamous cell carcinoma linked to high-risk serotypes like 16, 18, 31, 33, and others (16 and 18 m/c)
  • Serotype 16 alone accounts for ~50% of cases, while serotypes 16 & 18 together cause ~70% of cervical cancers.

questions.text: The RMNCH+A strategy by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India, aims to provide comprehensive healthcare across various life stages. Which of the following population groups is not a target of the RMNCAH+N strategy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Geriatric population:

Explanation:

  • The geriatric population is not included as a target group under the Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn, Child, and Adolescent Health (RMNCAH+N) initiative, which is a component of the National Health Mission launched in 2013.

Components of RMNCAH+N:

questions.text: Which imaging modality is being used in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option B) X-ray Defecography

Explanation

X-ray defecography (or defecating proctography) is a dynamic fluoroscopic study using barium paste to visualize anorectal function during simulated defecation.

Key X-ray Findings:

  • Anorectal Angle (ARA): Measured between the rectum and anal canal. Normally widens (becomes more obtuse) during defecation. Anismus shows paradoxical narrowing.
  • Perineal Descent: Downward movement of the pelvic floor. Excessive descent indicates laxity/weakness.
  • Rectal Emptying: Assesses completeness of barium expulsion. Incomplete emptying suggests obstruction.
  • Prolapse:
    • Rectocele: Anterior rectal bulging into the vagina.
    • Intussusception: Rectal wall telescoping into the lumen.
    • Rectal Prolapse: Rectum extending into or outside the anal canal.
    • Enterocele: Small bowel herniating into the rectovaginal space.
  • Anal Canal: Assesses opening during evacuation and closure during contraction.

questions.text: Identify the following immunoglobulin.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) IgA

Explanation:

The structure illustrated above represents IgA (Immunoglobulin A).

  • Two types – IgA1 and IgA2
  • Major immunoglobulin in colostrum, saliva, and tears
  • Two Forms: Monomeric serum IgA and dimeric secretory IgA
  • Secretory IgA:
    • Two monomer units joined together at their carboxy terminals by a glycopeptide termed the J chain
    • Produced by plasma cells near mucosal or glandular epithelium
    • Secretory piece or secretory component in the IgA protects IgA from bacterial proteases, especially in areas with abundant bacterial flora (e.g., intestines)
    • Role in Local Immunity: Concentrated in secretions, it forms an "antibody paste" on mucosal surfaces to protect against respiratory and intestinal pathogens.
    • Resistance: Relatively resistant to digestive enzymes and reducing agents
    • Activates the alternative complement pathway.

Immunoglobulin

Properties

Structure

IgA

Found in mucous, saliva, tears and breast milk.

Protects against pathogens.

IgD

Part of the B cell receptor

Activates basophils and mast cells.

IgE

Protects against parasitic worms.

Responsible for allergic reactions.

IgG

Secreted by plasma cells in the blood.

Able to cross the placenta into the fetus.

IgM

May be attached to the surface of a B cell or secreted into blood.

Responsible for early stages of immunity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effective treatment for amblyopia?

choices.text: Use of video games for visual stimulation

questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option C) Strabismus surgery

Explanation

Correction of refractive errors (Option A ruled out): This is a fundamental and often the first step in amblyopia treatment. Uncorrected significant refractive errors (like high farsightedness, nearsightedness, or astigmatism) can prevent clear image formation and lead to amblyopia. Correcting these errors with glasses or contact lenses allows the brain to receive a clear image, which is essential for visual development. This is an effective treatment.
 

Occlusion therapy (patching) (Option B rule out): This is a cornerstone of amblyopia treatment. It involves covering the stronger, non-amblyopic eye for specific periods each day, forcing the brain to use and develop the weaker, amblyopic eye. This is a highly effective and widely used treatment.
 

Strabismus surgery (Option C): Strabismus (misalignment of the eyes) is a common cause of amblyopia. While strabismus surgery can align the eyes, it primarily addresses the cosmetic and functional alignment issue. It does not directly treat the amblyopia itself, which is a brain-based vision deficit. However, aligning the eyes before or during amblyopia treatment can sometimes improve the chances of success, especially in preventing suppression. It is not a direct or primary treatment for the amblyopia deficit itself, but for its cause.
 

Use of video games for visual stimulation (Option D rule out): There has been research into using specially designed video games (often dichoptic, where each eye sees different parts of the game) to stimulate both eyes simultaneously and improve visual acuity in amblyopia. While this is a newer and emerging area of research, it has shown promise as an adjunctive or alternative therapy, particularly in older children or those who don't tolerate patching well. This is considered an emerging and potentially effective treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common inherited bleeding disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Von Willebrand Disease

Explanation:

Von Willebrand Disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder.

  • Types:

vWD type 1

vWD Type 2

vWD Type 3

  • Autosomal dominant.
  • The most common type.
  • Mild to moderate vWF deficiency.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • point substitutions prevent the vWF protein from maturing or cause it to leave the plasma quickly

 
  • Autosomal dominant.
  • Qualitative defect.


Types: 2A, 2B, 2M, 2N

  • 2A (Most common) - Decrease in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9 missense mutations cause faulty multimer formation → the most active forms of vWF, i.e. large- and intermediate-sized multimers are absent.
  • 2B - Increase in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9
  • 2M - VWF dependant platelet adhesion is decreased. There is impairment of VWF binding to platelets. Type 2M VWD typically has mild to moderate mucocutaneous bleeding
  • 2N - There is marked decline in the binding affinity for factor VIII. The level of factor VIII is lower when compared to the VWF:Ag. This led to misdiagnosis as haemophilia A
  • Autosomal recessive.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • produced by frameshift mutations or deletions affecting both alleles (autosomal recessive), which produce little or no vWF.
  • Factor VIII levels are also lowered because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the blood, and the resulting bleeding condition is severe.

 

Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) (Option B) is an acquired (not inherited), secondary condition due to systemic activation of the clotting cascade (e.g., in sepsis, trauma, malignancy).

Factor V Deficiency (Option C) is a rare inherited bleeding disorder, also known as parahemophilia. Far less common than vWD.

Hemophilia (A or B) (Option D) is an inherited X-linked recessive disorder involving Factor VIII (A) or Factor IX (B) deficiency. More common in males but still less prevalent than von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: A biopsy of a patient presenting with painful vesicular lesions and superficial erosions in the genital area is shown. What treatment would you initiate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acyclovir

Explanation:

  • The biopsy image, along with the presence of painful vesicular lesions and superficial erosions in the genital area, is indicative of Genital Herpes, most commonly caused by the Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV). The appropriate treatment for this condition is acyclovir.

Treatment:

First line

  • Acyclovir (topical/oral) (Option A)
  • Hydrocolloid dressing
  • Topical penciclovir

Second line

  • Long-term prophylactic acyclovir

Third line
  • IV acyclovir
  • Penciclovir
  • Foscarnet
  • IV cidofovir
  • Topical imiquimod

Incorrect Options:

Steroids (Option B) are not suitable for treating genital herpes because they suppress the immune response. While steroids can be useful in managing inflammatory or autoimmune conditions, using them during an active viral infection like herpes simplex virus (HSV) can worsen the condition.

Penicillin (Option C) is an antibiotic used primarily to treat bacterial infections, such as syphilis. Syphilis typically presents with a painless ulcer (chancre), in contrast to the painful vesicular lesions and superficial erosions seen in genital herpes.

Azithromycin (Option D) is another antibiotic, commonly used to treat bacterial sexually transmitted infections (STIs) such as chlamydia and, in some cases, gonorrhea. However, like penicillin, azithromycin has no antiviral activity and is ineffective against HSV.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)?

choices.text: a. Increase absorption of urea in medullary duct
Increase absorption of urea in descending loop of Henle
Decrease absorption of NaCl in ascending loop of Henle
Increase water permeability in the collecting ducts

questions.solution:
Correct answer-

  • a. Increase absorption of urea in medullary duct: TRUE. ADH increases the permeability of the inner medullary collecting duct to urea, primarily by upregulating urea transporters (UT-A1 and UT-A3). This is crucial for maintaining the medullary osmotic gradient, which is essential for water reabsorption.
     
  • b. Increase absorption of urea in descending loop of Henle: FALSE. The descending limb of the loop of Henle is highly permeable to water but relatively impermeable to urea. Urea is actually secreted into the thin ascending limb of the loop of Henle as part of the urea recycling process, not absorbed in the descending limb under ADH influence.
     
  • c. Decrease absorption of NaCl in ascending loop of Henle: FALSE. ADH actually increases NaCl reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. It does this by increasing the expression and activity of the Na-K-2Cl cotransporter (NKCC2). This action contributes to the countercurrent multiplication mechanism, further concentrating the medullary interstitium and facilitating water reabsorption in the collecting ducts.
     
  • d. Increase water permeability in the collecting ducts: TRUE. This is a primary and most well-known action of ADH. ADH binds to V2 receptors on the principal cells of the collecting ducts (and late distal tubule), leading to the insertion of aquaporin-2 (AQP2) water channels into the apical membrane. This greatly increases the water permeability of these segments, allowing water to be reabsorbed from the filtrate back into the hypertonic medullary interstitium, thus concentrating the urine.
     

Based on this analysis, the statement that is not a mechanism of action of ADH is:

b. Increase absorption of urea in descending loop of Henle c. Decrease absorption of NaCl in ascending loop of Henle

Both b and c describe actions that are opposite to or not characteristic of ADH's known effects. However, usually, questions like this have only one definitively incorrect option.

Let's re-evaluate more strictly:

  • ADH does increase urea reabsorption, but specifically in the medullary collecting duct, not the descending loop of Henle. So (b) is definitively incorrect regarding location.
  • ADH increases NaCl reabsorption in the thick ascending limb, so (c) stating "decrease absorption" is definitively incorrect.

Between (b) and (c), both are incorrect statements about ADH's mechanism. However, (c) describes an action that is the opposite of what ADH does to NaCl reabsorption in that segment, while (b) describes a location where ADH doesn't primarily act on urea reabsorption. In multiple-choice questions seeking the "not a mechanism," the statement that is factually opposite is often the intended answer.

Therefore, the most definitively incorrect statement as a mechanism of action of ADH is c. Decrease absorption of NaCl in the ascending loop of Henle.

questions.text: Which investigation is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option A) CT scan

Explanation

  • CT scans (Option A) use X-rays, which are a form of ionizing radiation. In early pregnancy, radiation exposure, especially during organogenesis (weeks 3-8 post-conception), can lead to teratogenic effects (e.g., congenital anomalies), increased risk of miscarriage, or even fetal growth restriction.

Incorrect Options:

MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) (Option B ruled out): MRI uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves, not ionizing radiation.

Ultrasound (Option C ruled out): Ultrasound uses high-frequency sound waves to create images.

Doppler (Option D ruled out): Doppler ultrasound is a specific type of ultrasound that measures blood flow.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is contraindicated in a child with immunodeficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella):

Explanation:

  • MMR is a live attenuated vaccine and is generally contraindicated in immunocompromised individuals, whereas Hepatitis B, DPT, and IPV are inactivated vaccines and are considered safe for them.

Category

Recommendations

HIV+ Individuals
  • Inactivated Vaccines: Most are recommended, but effectiveness may vary based on immune deficiency.
  • Live Vaccines: Generally contraindicated, with exceptions:
    • MMR: Administer if asymptomatic or with mild symptoms (CD4+ ≥ 15%).
    • Varicella: Consider if CD4+ ≥ 15%; MMRV is not recommended.
    • Yellow Fever: Contraindicated for severely immunocompromised under 6; specific precautions for others.
  • Other Vaccines:
    • Pneumococcal: PCV13 and PPSV23 are recommended.
    • Meningococcal: MCV4 is recommended for children ≥ 2 months.
    • Hib: Recommended if not given during infancy.

Immunocompromised
  • General Principles: Vaccination varies by condition, severity, risk, and vaccine type.
  • Live Vaccines: Typically contraindicated; exceptions based on condition and vaccine. (Option C)
  • Inactivated Vaccines: Effective but may be reduced based on immune deficiency. (Option A, B, D ruled out)

Preterm Infants
  • General Recommendations: Vaccinate based on chronological age, similar to full-term infants.
  • Hepatitis B Vaccine:
    • For ≥ 2 kg and stable: Birth dose within 24 hours.
    • For < 2 kg: Birth dose deferred until 1 month or hospital discharge (if HBsAg-negative mother). All preterm, low-birthweight infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers should receive HBIG and hepatitis B vaccine within 12 hours of birth, with three additional doses starting at 1 month.

Vaccination in elderly
  • Influenza (flu): Annual vaccination, especially with high-dose or adjuvanted vaccines, helps protect against flu complications such as pneumonia and organ failure.
  • Pneumococcal vaccine: A one-time vaccine against bacterial infections that can cause severe pneumonia.
  • Shingles: A two-dose series to prevent shingles and its complications, like postherpetic neuralgia.
  • Tdap (Tetanus, Diphtheria, Pertussis): Booster shots every 10 years to maintain immunity.
  • RSV (Respiratory Syncytial Virus): Newly approved for older adults, especially those with heart or lung conditions.

questions.text: The triad of abrasions, contusions, and lacerations is most diagnostic of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ﻿﻿﻿Bomb blast injury

Explanation:

  • Marshall's triad, that is contusion, abrasion and punctate laceration indicates a secondary blast injury.
  • Blast Injury: Blast injuries are complex physical traumas resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion, leading to sudden changes in atmospheric pressure.

[1]

Classification of Blast Injuries

Type

Mechanism

Features

Primary Injury

It results from blast waves and is often internal with no external signs.
  • Ears: Tympanic membrane rupture or inner ear disruption.
  • Lungs: Alveolar-capillary membrane haemorrhage (blast lung), most common cause cause of death in survivors.
  • GIT: Injuries to gas-filled organs are more common in underwater blasts.

Secondary Injury

It is resulting from shrapnel, debris & flying objects (propelled by explosion).
  • Penetrating trauma.
  • The characteristic Marshall triad, which includes bruises, abrasions, and punctate lacerations, is evident.
  • Commonly cause severe thoracic injuries, including lacerations of the heart and great vessels.

Tertiary Injury

Victims are thrown against solid objects by blast winds.
  • Blunt/Penetrating trauma.
  • Includes bone fractures and coup-contrecoup injuries.

Quaternary Injury

Encompass all other injuries not classified above
  • Flash burns from extreme heat.
  • Crush injuries and falls due to explosions.
  • Respiratory injuries from toxic dust, gases, or radiation exposure.
  • Psychiatric issues, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), may affect individuals even if they are physically unharmed.


Firearm injury (Option A) Presents with entry/exit wounds, possible burns or tattooing (based on the type of injury). Lacerations and contusions may occur, but not all three components consistently.

Road Traffic Accident (RTA) (Option C): Abrasions, contusions, and lacerations can occur, but patterned injuries, fractures, and internal organ damage are more prominent. The triad might be possible, but not common, diagnostic or specific.

﻿﻿﻿Strangulation (Option D) It is characteriwed by ligature marks, petechiae, facial congestion, and neck muscle hemorrhage. Abrasions may be present around the neck, but the full triad is not typical.

FM080

questions.text: A patient underwent a bone marrow transplant without HLA matching. In which of the following disorders transplant rejection does not occur:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bare lymphocyte syndrome

Explanation:

  • Bone marrow transplant (BMT) rejection is mediated by recipient T lymphocytes recognizing donor HLA antigens as foreign. Therefore, the integrity and function of recipient T cells (especially CD8⁺ cytotoxic T cells) are crucial for mounting a rejection response.

Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome (BLS):

  • It is a type of MHC class II deficiency, and in some forms, MHC class I expression is also defective.
  • Because of absent or defective HLA expression, CD4⁺ (helper) and sometimes CD8⁺ (cytotoxic) T cells are profoundly dysfunctional or absent.
  • Result: These patients are immunologically unable to recognize or reject transplanted tissue, even in the absence of HLA matching.

Hence, rejection does not occur in BLS due to lack of HLA molecule expression and impaired T cell function.

Chediak-Higashi Syndrome (Option B) is an autosomal recessive condition with defect in lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST), leading to defective neutrophil function.

T and B cell immunity is relatively intact — rejection is possible.

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (Option C) X-linked disorder with combined immunodeficiency, characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infection. It is caused by mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP). Although T-cell dysfunction is present, it is not severe enough to completely prevent rejection.

Job’s Syndrome (Hyper-IgE syndrome) (Option C) Impaired Th17 pathway with eosinophilia and recurrent infections. T cell immunity is abnormal but not absent, so rejection can occur.

Syndrome

T Cell Function

Graft Rejection Expected?

Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome

Severely impaired/absent

❌ No rejection

Chediak-Higashi Syndrome

Mostly intact

✅ Yes

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome

Impaired, not absent

✅ Possible

Job's Syndrome

Impaired Th17 cells

✅ Possible

questions.text: What is the primary action of the muscle originating from this structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option A) Protracts and depresses the mandible

Explanation

  • The lateral pterygoid muscle plays a unique and crucial role among the muscles of mastication because it is the only one that primarily participates in depressing (Option A) the mandible (opening the mouth).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is incorrect?

choices.text: 70% of patients with MS develop optic neuritis during course of illness
Oral steroids are given for acute relapses
Loss of color perception and depth perception is proportional to visual loss
Examination of fundus can be normal and can show papillitis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Loss of color perception and depth perception is proportional to visual loss

Explanation:

  • In optic neuritis (often seen in MS), color vision (especially red) and depth perception can be disproportionately affected compared to overall visual acuity. A patient may have mild visual acuity loss but significant dyschromatopsia (color desaturation) or depth perception difficulties.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) Clinical features:

  • Abrupt or insidious onset of symptoms

Sensory symptoms
  • Paresthesias: tingling, prickling sensations, “pins and needles,” or painful burning.
  • Hypesthesia: reduced sensation, numbness, or a “dead” feeling.
  • Unpleasant sensations: feelings that body parts are swollen, wet, raw, or tightly wrapped.
  • Pain is a common symptom of MS.

Optic neuritis (ON)

  • Diminished visual acuity.
  • Decreased colour perception in the central field of vision.
  • May progress to severe visual loss.
  • Periorbital pain.
  • Fundoscopic examination: normal or optic disc swelling (papillitis), pallor of the optic disc (optic atrophy).

Weakness of the limbs
  • Loss of strength, speed, dexterity, and gait disturbance.
  • Exercise-induced weakness is a characteristic symptom of MS.
  • Upper motor neuron type weakness accompanied by other pyramidal signs.

Facial weakness
  • Lesion in the pons may resemble idiopathic Bell’s palsy.

Spasticity
  • Spontaneous and movement-induced muscle spasms.
  • Painful spasms.

Visual blurring
  • Due to ON (optic neuritis) or diplopia.
  • Diplopia is caused by internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) or palsy of the sixth cranial nerve.
  • Bilateral INO is particularly suggestive of MS.
  • Other gaze disturbances in MS:
    • Horizontal gaze palsy
    • One-and-a-half syndrome (horizontal gaze palsy plus an INO)
    • Acquired pendular nystagmus

Ataxia
  • Cerebellar tremors.
  • Cerebellar dysarthria.

Vertigo
  • Lesion in the brainstem.

 

Ancillary symptoms

Paroxysmal symptoms

Brief duration (10s to 2 min), high frequency (5–40 episodes per day), no change of consciousness or change in background electroencephalogram during episodes, and a self-limited course.

Lhermitte’s symptom

An electric shock-like sensation that radiates down the back into the legs.

Typically induced by flexion or other movements of the neck.

Trigeminal neuralgia, hemifacial spasm, and glossopharyngeal neuralgia

Demyelinating lesions involve the root entry or exit zone of the fifth, seventh, and ninth cranial nerve, respectively.

Facial myokymia

Persistent rapid flickering contractions of the facial musculature

Slow spread of contraction across the face.

Heat sensitivity

Uthoff symptoms: Neurological symptoms develop from heat exposure, such as steam baths and saunas.

Bladder dysfunction

Present in >90% of MS patients.

Detrusor hyperreflexia.

Detrusor sphincter dyssynergia - hesitancy, urinary retention, overflow incontinence, and recurrent infection.

Bowel dysfunction

Constipation, faecal urgency or bowel incontinence.

Cognitive dysfunction

Memory loss.

Impaired attention.

Psychiatric symptom

Depression.

Fatigue

90% of patients experience fatigue.

It causes work-related disability.

Incorrect Options:

70% of patients with MS develop optic neuritis during course of illness (Option A): Optic neuritis is a common presenting symptom and complication of MS. Around 70% of patients develop it at some point during the disease. It often causes painful vision loss, especially on eye movement.

Oral steroids are given for acute relapses (Option B): High-dose intravenous steroids (e.g., methylprednisolone) are preferred for acute relapses, but oral steroids (like oral prednisolone or tapering doses after IV) can also be used in certain cases. So, oral steroids are indeed part of acute relapse management, especially during recovery or tapering phases.

Examination of fundus can be normal and can show papillitis (Option D): In optic neuritis, retrobulbar neuritis often shows a normal fundus because the inflammation is behind the globe. However, in some cases, papillitis (optic disc swelling) may be seen. Both scenarios are possible in MS-related optic neuritis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a history of cyanosis since infancy. Which of the following is a component of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option B) Infundibular pulmonary stenosis

Explanation:

Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect characterized by four distinct anomalies:

  1. Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): A hole between the right and left ventricles.
  2. Pulmonary Stenosis: Narrowing of the pulmonary outflow tract. This can be subvalvular (infundibular, below the valve), valvular (at the valve), or supravalvular (above the valve). Infundibular pulmonary stenosis is a common and characteristic component.
  3. Overriding Aorta: The aorta (the main artery carrying oxygenated blood to the body) is positioned directly over the VSD, receiving blood from both ventricles.
  4. Right Ventricular Hypertrophy (RVH): The right ventricle thickens due to the increased workload of pumping blood against the narrowed pulmonary artery and into the aorta.

The options provided

  • Inter atrial septal defect (ASD) (Option A ruled out): While an ASD can coexist with TOF (forming Pentalogy of Fallot), it is not a primary component of the classic Tetralogy of Fallot.
  • Infundibular pulmonary stenosis(Option B): This is a core component of Tetralogy of Fallot. The narrowing in the outflow tract of the right ventricle is often in the infundibular region.
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH)(Option C ruled out): In TOF, it's the right ventricle that undergoes hypertrophy due to the increased pressure load. Left ventricular hypertrophy is not a typical feature.
  • Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)(Option D ruled out): TGA is a completely separate and distinct complex congenital heart defect where the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. It is not a component of TOF.

questions.text: A woman with a strong family history of breast and ovarian cancer is being evaluated for BRCA1/BRCA2 mutations. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to detect multiple mutations at different codons in these genes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Next-generation sequencing (NGS)

Explanation:

The most appropriate test to detect multiple mutations at different codons in BRCA1/BRCA2 genes is Next-generation sequencing (NGS) or Digital Droplet PCR.

  • It is a revolutionary method for rapid, high-throughput DNA and RNA sequencing.
  • Enables massive parallel sequencing of hundreds to thousands of genes or whole genomes.
  • Significantly faster and more comprehensive than traditional methods like Sanger sequencing.
  • Integrates:
    • Advanced sequencing chemistries
    • Diverse sequencing platforms
    • Robust bioinformatics tools
  • Widely used for:
    • Disease diagnosis and prognosis
    • Therapy selection
    • Patient monitoring

 

qPCR (Option A) measures gene expression levels, not specific DNA mutations.
 

RT-PCR (Option B) detects RNA-level changes, limited for comprehensive mutation scanning.
 

Northern blot (Option C) analyzes RNA expression, not DNA mutations.

questions.text: Which of the following cancers is NOT related to obesity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Meningioma

Explanation:

  • Meningiomas are typically benign central nervous system tumors arising from the meninges. Although some observational studies have noted a possible link between obesity and meningioma (particularly in women), this association is not considered well established or causal.
  • Obesity is a well-established risk factor for numerous malignancies, particularly those influenced by chronic inflammation, insulin resistance, and hormonal imbalances. The cancers most strongly linked to obesity include:
    • Endometrial
    • Breast (postmenopausal)
    • Colorectal
    • Esophageal (adenocarcinoma)
    • Pancreatic (Option C)
    • Renal cell carcinoma
    • Gallbladder
    • Liver
    • Gastric (cardia type) (Option B)
    • Multiple myeloma (Option D)
  • These associations are supported by robust epidemiological data and acknowledged by major health organizations (e.g., IARC, WHO, CDC).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of TNM stage T4b breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inflammatory carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Inflammatory carcinoma is classified separately as T4d in the TNM staging, but not stage T4b.

 

TNM staging for breast cancer

Stage

Description

Tumor size (T)

TX

Primary tumor cannot be assessed

T0

No evidence of primary tumor

Tis

Carcinoma in situ (DCIS, LCIS, or Paget's disease)

T1

Tumor ≤ 2 cm

T1mi

Tumor ≤ 1 mm

T1a

Tumor > 1 mm but ≤ 5 mm

T1b

Tumor > 5 mm but ≤ 10 mm

T1c

Tumor > 10 mm but ≤ 20 mm

T2

Tumor > 2 cm but ≤ 5 cm

T3

Tumor > 5 cm

T4

Tumor of any size with direct extension to chest wall or skin

T4a

Extension to chest wall

T4b

Ulceration or skin nodules (Option A, B & D)

T4c

Both T4a and T4b

T4d

Inflammatory breast cancer (Option C)

Node (N)

NX

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastases to movable ipsilateral level I, II axillary lymph nodes

N2

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes or clinically apparent internal mammary nodes

N2a

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes that are clinically fixed or matted

N2b

Metastasis to internal mammary nodes without axillary lymph node involvement

N3

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes or infraclavicular nodes, or to supraclavicular nodes

N3a

Metastasis to infraclavicular nodes

N3b

Metastasis to internal mammary nodes

N3c

Metastasis to supraclavicular nodes

Metastasis (M)

MX

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis present

 

Stage Grouping

Stage 0: Tis N0 M0

Stage IA: T1/T1mi N0 M0

Stage IB: T0 N1mi M0; T1/T1mi N1mi M0

Stage IIA: T0 N1 M0; T1 N1 M0; T2 N0 M0

Stage IIB: T2 N1 M0; T3 N0 M0

Stage IIIA: T0 N2 M0; T1 N2 M0; T2 N2 M0; T3 N1 M0

Stage IIIB: T3 N2 M0

Stage IIIC: T4 N0 M0; T4 N1 M0; T4 N2 M0; Any T N3 M0

Stage IV: Any T Any N M1

questions.text:
Rotterdam criteria include:


	Obesity
	Hirsutism
	Delayed cycles
	Insulin resistance
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) B and C

Explanation:

Among the given options, the Rotterdam Criteria include hirsutism and irregular or delayed menstrual cycles.

  • It is used to diagnose PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome).
  • Any 2 of the following 3 should be present to make a provisional diagnosis for PCOS:
    • Increased androgen levels: Hyperandrogenism/Hirsutism: PCOS is associated with elevated androgen levels, which can manifest as clinical signs (like hirsutism and acne) or biochemical findings (elevated testosterone). (Option B)
    • Ovulatory dysfunction: Oligomenorrhea/Amenorrhea- Irregular menstrual cycles (oligomenorrhea) or absence of menstrual periods (amenorrhea) are common features of PCOS due to ovulatory dysfunction. (Option C)
    • On USG: 1 or both ovaries >12 follicles with 2-9mm in size (<1cm) and/or Ovarian volume >=10 cm3- One of the diagnostic criteria for PCOS is the presence of polycystic ovarian morphology, which is confirmed by ultrasound showing multiple cysts on the ovaries.

 

USG: Necklace pattern ovarian cyst arranged towards the periphery.

Excessive stromal component in centre-producing androgens

 

Obesity (Option A) and Insulin Resistance (Option D) are common associated features of PCOS but are not part of the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: In a hospital, patients are classified into three groups based on disease severity: mild, moderate, and severe. One patient is randomly selected from each group for a study. What type of sampling method is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Stratified random sampling:

Explanation:

  • This study employs Stratified Random Sampling by dividing patients into mild, moderate, and severe disease groups and randomly selecting individuals from each, ensuring adequate representation of all subgroups.

Random Probability Sampling Methods

Sampling Method

Description

Example

Simple Random Sampling

(Option A ruled out)

Selecting units purely by chance, ensuring each unit has an equal probability of being chosen.

Drawing names using random number generators or drawing lots.

Systematic Random Sampling

(Option B ruled out)

Selecting every nth unit from the population after a random starting point.

From a list of 1000 people and need a sample of 100, select every 10th person on the list after choosing a random starting point between 1 and 10.

Stratified Random Sampling

(Option C)

Dividing the population into subgroups (strata) and randomly sampling from each subgroup.

Dividing a population into age groups (e.g., 18-29, 30-49, 50+) and randomly sampling individuals from each age group

Cluster Random Sampling

(Option D ruled out)

Dividing the population into clusters and randomly selecting entire clusters to be included.

Dividing a city into neighborhoods (clusters) and randomly selecting a few neighborhoods. All residents in the selected neighborhoods are then included in the sample.

Multi-Stage Sampling

Combining several sampling methods in stages.

First, randomly select districts (simple random sampling), then within selected districts, randomly select schools (second stage), and finally, within selected schools, randomly select students (third stage)

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient, such as one with HIV/AIDS, presents with dysphagia and odynophagia. On upper GI endoscopy, white plaques are seen over the esophageal mucosa. A biopsy is taken for microscopic examination. What is the most likely finding on microscopy?

choices.text: Multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Yeast cells with pseudohyphae

Explanation:

  • An immunocompromised patient, such as one with HIV/AIDS, presenting with dysphagia, odynophagia, and white plaques on esophageal endoscopy, is showing classic signs of esophageal candidiasis, most commonly caused by Candida albicans; microscopic examination (via biopsy or KOH prep) typically reveals diagnostic yeast cells with pseudohyphae.

CDC-AIDS defining conditions:

  • Candidiasis of the bronchi, trachea, oesophagal or lungs. (Option A)
  • Cryptosporidiosis with diarrhoea (for longer than 1 month)
  • Cytomegalovirus disease (other than liver, spleen, or nodes), beginning when older than one month
  • Herpes simplex: chronic ulcers (lasting longer than 1 month); or bronchitis, pneumonitis, or esophagitis (beginning when older than one month)
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Lymphoma, primary, of brain
  • Mycobacterium avium complex (type of bacterial infection) or M. kansasii, disseminated or extrapulmonary
  • Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP)
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Toxoplasmosis of the brain, beginning when older than one month

Acid-fast bacilli (Option B) are typically associated with infections caused by Mycobacterium species, such as tuberculosis or Mycobacterium avium complex. Their clinical presentation and diagnostic approach differ significantly; diagnosis relies on acid-fast staining of tissue or bodily fluids, rather than endoscopic findings of white esophageal plaques, which are more characteristic of fungal infections like candidiasis.

Branching septate hyphae at a 45-degree angle (Option C) is a hallmark of Aspergillus species, a type of mold that most commonly infects the lungs or sinuses, especially in immunocompromised individuals. Additionally, when Aspergillus does infect mucosal tissues, it does not produce the white plaque-like lesions seen in esophageal candidiasis.

Multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions (Option D) are classic histological findings in Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) esophagitis, another opportunistic infection seen in immunocompromised patients. It presents with multiple small, well-defined "punched-out" ulcers in the esophagus, not the white, plaque-like lesions characteristic of Candida albicans.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of multinodular goitre undergoes a CT angiogram with iodinated contrast for suspected pulmonary embolism. Two weeks later, she presents with palpitations, heat intolerance, and weight loss. Her thyroid function tests show suppressed TSH and elevated T3 and T4. Which of the following best explains this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Jod-Basedow effect

Explanation:

  • The patient shows features of hyperthyroidism, which occurred after receiving iodinated contrast during a CT angiogram. This Iodine-induced hyperthyroidism is called the Jod-Basedow effect, which occurs due to increased iodine trapping leading to Increased T4, T3 production.

Wolff Chaikoff effect & Jod Basedow effect

Feature

Wolff-Chaikoff Effect

Job-Basedow Effect

Definition

Temporary inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis in response to high iodine exposure

Iodine-induced hyperthyroidism

Mechanism

High iodine levels inhibit thyroid peroxidase, reducing T3 and T4 production

Excess iodine stimulates autonomous thyroid hormone production in susceptible individuals

Duration

Temporary (usually resolves in 1-2 weeks)

Can persist until treated

Thyroid Function Tests

Initially decreased T3 and T4, increased TSH

Increased T3 and T4, decreased TSH

At-risk Population

Normal thyroid glands

Pre-existing thyroid disease (e.g., multinodular goiter, Graves' disease)

Clinical Presentation

Usually asymptomatic or mild hypothyroid symptoms

Symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g., palpitations, heat intolerance, weight loss)

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with a progressively increasing swelling over the tibia along with fever. Radiological examination reveals a Codman triangle and sunburst appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Osteosarcoma

Explanation:

  • Based on the presentation and the radiological findings of codman triangle and sunburst appearance, the most likely diagnosis is Osteosarcoma.

Osteosarcoma:

  • It is the most common primary malignant tumour of bone and accounts for approximately 20% of bone cancers.
  • Age distribution: Bimodal.
  • Tumours usually arise in the metaphyseal region of the long bones; almost 50% are near the knee in the distal femur or proximal tibia.
  • Genetic associations:
    • RB gene (most common): 70%.
    • TP53.
    • CDKN2A (also known as INK4a).
    • MDM2 and CDK4.
  • Morphology:
    • Osteosarcomas are bulky, gritty, grey-white tumours that often contain haemorrhage and cystic degeneration.
    • Osteosarcomas demonstrate pleomorphism, large hyperchromatic nuclei, bizarre tumour giant cells, and abundant mitoses.
    • Extensive necrosis and intravascular invasion are also common.
    • Diagnosis of osteosarcoma requires the presence of malignant tumour cells producing unmineralised osteoid or mineralised bone.
  • Osteosarcoma metastasises hematogenously to the lungs, bones, brain, and other sites.
  • X-ray findings of osteosarcoma:
    • Area of irregular destruction in the metaphysis. The cortex overlying the lesion is eroded.
    • Sun-ray or Sun burst appearance (aggressive periostitis): As the tumor grows into the overlying soft tissues new bone is laid down centrifugally along the blood vessels within the tumor.

  • Codman's triangle: Elevation of periosteum by the growing tumor in the form of a triangle

Ewing sarcoma (Option B) is the second most common in children and young adults and its radiology shows onion-skin appearance, not Codman triangle or sunburst pattern.

Giant cell tumour (Option C) is a benign but locally aggressive tumour characterised by numerous multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells. It occurs in the third to fifth decades of life. Radiology shows soap bubble appearance, which is lobulated lytic lesions with narrow zones of transition

﻿﻿﻿Chondrosarcoma (Option C) is a malignant cartilage-producing tumour. It is the second most common malignant matrix-producing tumour of the bone and affects individuals usually in their 40s or older. They commonly arise in the axial skeleton, especially the pelvis, shoulder, and ribs. It does not show Codman triangle or sunburst pattern in a X-ray.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true statements:


	Widal test is positive in the first week of illness
	Microscopic agglutination test is done for leptospira
	Weil-Felix test is done for typhus fever
	Standard agglutination test is done for Brucellosis
	Catalase positive is seen in Streptococcus
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2,3,4

Explanation:

The correct statements are:

  1. Microscopic agglutination test is done for Leptospira - it is the gold standard test.
  2. Weil-Felix is a heterophile agglutination test used for Rickettsial infections including Typhus.
  3. The Standard Tube Agglutination (STA) test is the most commonly used test to diagnose brucellosis.

The incorrect statements are:

  1. Catalase positive is seen in Streptococcus - Staphylococci are catalase-positive, while Streptococci are catalase-negative.
  2. Widal test is positive for Typhoid in the first week of illness - In the first week, blood culture is the investigation of choice. Widal test becomes positive only in the second week due to the time required for antibody formation.

questions.text: Which type of pulse is based on the Frank-Starling law?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C. Pulsus alternans

Explanation:

  • Pulsus alternans shows alternating strong and weak pulse beats, often seen in severe left ventricular dysfunction. One proposed mechanism involves the Frank-Starling law, where a weak contraction leads to increased end-diastolic volume, boosting the next beat's strength. This cycle repeats, causing alternating pulse amplitudes. Another theory involves abnormal calcium cycling in cardiac myocytes.
  • The Frank-Starling law of the heart describes the relationship between the volume of blood filling the heart (end-diastolic volume) and the force of contraction during the next heartbeat (stroke volume).

Mechanism:

  • Preload: Increased venous return leads to increased end-diastolic volume.
  • Myocardial Stretch: Greater end-diastolic volume stretches the myocardial fibers.
  • Force of Contraction: The stretched fibers generate a more forceful contraction due to the optimal overlap of actin and myosin filaments (length-tension relationship).

Incorrect Options:

Pulsus bisferiens (Option A): Characterised by a double systolic peak; seen in aortic regurgitation or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy—not related to Frank-Starling.

Pulsus paradoxus (Option B): An exaggerated decrease in systolic BP during inspiration, typically seen in cardiac tamponade or severe asthma, not explained by Frank-Starling law.

Pulsus parvus (Option D): A small, weak pulse seen in aortic stenosis; related to obstruction, not preload or contractility.

questions.text: What is the primary action of this muscle attached to the area marked?
questions.solution:
Correct answer

Option A) Abduction of the thigh

Explanation

Piriformis Muscle

Attachments:

  • Origin: Anterior sacrum (3 parts), gluteal surface of ilium near posterior inferior iliac spine, sacroiliac joint capsule.
  • Insertion: Medial upper border of the greater trochanter of the femur.

Key Features: Fills most of the greater sciatic foramen, acting as a crucial landmark.

Associated Structures:

  • Superior: Superior gluteal nerve and vessel.
  • Inferior: Inferior gluteal nerve and vessels, sciatic nerve, posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh, nerves to quadratus femoris and obturator internus, internal pudendal vessels, pudendal nerve.

Vascular Supply: Primarily by the superior gluteal artery; also by gemellar branches of internal pudendal, inferior gluteal, and lateral sacral arteries.

Innervation: Superior gluteal nerve and ventral rami of S1 and S2.

Actions: Laterally rotates the extended thigh and abducts the flexed thigh.(Option A)

Testing: No isolated test; dysfunction assessed by abducting thighs in a seated position, looking for buttock pain.
