questions.text: All are correct about toxoplasma gondii except:

choices.text: Infection is more common in third trimester than in first trimester
Can be cultured in peritoneal cavity of mice

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Oocysts in stool are infective

Explanation:

  • The freshly passed oocyst of Toxoplasma is not infectious. They undergo sporulation in the soil with formation of two sporocysts, each containing four sporozoites. The sporulated oocyst is infective.

Toxoplasma gondii

Host (Option B)
  • Definitive host: Cat and other cat species (family Felidae)
  • Intermediate host: Humans and animals like sheep, rodents, pigs etc

Infective stages
  • Sporulated oocyst
  • Tachyzoites
  • Bradyzoites (tissue cyst)

Modes of transmission

Infective form

Blood Transfusion

 

Tachyzoites

Mother to child

Undercooked or raw meat

Sporulated Oocyst

Ingestion of contaminated products

Bradyzoites

 

Toxoplasmosis in pregnancy

Mother

Usually asymptomatic but can transmit the disease to the infant.

Infective form

Trophozoite crosses the placenta to infect the neonate.

Risk of transplacental infection based on time of infection of the mother

Transplacental infection can occur at any time during the pregnancy, but the gestational age influences the risk of transmission.

  • As the gestational age increases, the risk of transmission increases, but the severity of neonatal disease decreases.

Pre-pregnancy

  • Very low chance of transmission (immunocompromised mother)

 

First trimester

  • Minimal risk of transmission.
  • If transmitted, it results in more severe fetal complications.

Third trimester

  • Maximum risk of transmission. (Option A)
  • If transmitted, it is usually asymptomatic in newborns.

 

Diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis

Antenatal

USG

  • Done at 20-24 weeks of gestation and repeated every 2-4 weeks
  • It helps detect lesions of congenital infection, such as
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Cerebral calcifications
    • Ascites

Serology

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) or IFA (Immunofluorescence Assay) is done using maternal serum to detect IgM and IgG

PCR
  • Amniotic fluid can be used to detect Toxoplasma DNA, which can confirm the diagnosis.
  • It is not done routinely as it is invasive and expensive, and other safer options are available.

Postnatal diagnosis

Serology

Newborn Sera and maternal sera are both used to detect

  • IgG >= 1000: Possible infection
  • IgM >= 1:4 after 2 weeks of age: Indicates probable diagnosis
  • IgA: Disappears within 10 days of birth; thus, persistence indicates postnatal infection

Sabin-Feldman test - Complement fixation test

Other tests

  • Animal inoculation (no longer done for clinical diagnosis) (Option D)
  • Skin test of Frenkel
  • Microscopy of samples to detect tachyzoites using Giemsa or PAS

questions.text: A child presents with petechiae, purpura, and a platelet count of 10,000/µL. Bone marrow examination reveals increased megakaryocytes.Which of the following is the drug of choice (DOC) for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option c) Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

Explanation

This clinical presentation (petechiae, purpura, platelet count of 10,000/µL, and increased megakaryocytes in bone marrow) is characteristic of Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP), also previously known as Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura. In ITP, the immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys platelets, leading to a low platelet count. The bone marrow, in an attempt to compensate for the rapid destruction, produces more megakaryocytes (the precursor cells to platelets), which is why their number is increased on bone marrow examination.

  • Bone marrow transplant (Option A ruled out): This is a very aggressive and high-risk procedure. It is not a first-line treatment for ITP. It might be considered in very rare, refractory cases of severe, chronic ITP that haven't responded to multiple other treatments, but it's far from the drug of choice.
  • Methotrexate (Option B ruled out): This is an immunosuppressant and chemotherapy agent. While some immunosuppressants might be used in refractory chronic ITP (e.g., rituximab, cyclosporine, azathioprine), methotrexate is not a standard first-line drug of choice for acute severe ITP in children.
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)(Option C): This is a primary drug of choice for acute, severe ITP, especially when a rapid increase in platelet count is desired due to significant bleeding or very low counts. It's often used alongside or as an alternative to corticosteroids.
  • Aspirin (Option D ruled out) Aspirin is an antiplatelet agent that inhibits platelet function. Giving aspirin to a patient with a critically low platelet count and bleeding (petechiae, purpura) would be highly contraindicated as it would worsen bleeding.

questions.text: Mitral stenosis murmur corresponds to which wave of ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C. P wave

Explanation:

​The murmur of mitral stenosis is a diastolic rumbling murmur that follows the opening snap of the mitral valve. It is best heard at the apex and is associated with left atrial contraction.

  • The P wave on ECG represents atrial depolarization.
  • Since mitral stenosis involves obstruction to left ventricular filling during atrial contraction, the murmur is timed with and follows the P wave.
  • In severe mitral stenosis, a loud first heart sound and presystolic accentuation of the murmur (due to atrial contraction) are commonly observed, directly relating to the P wave.
  • Mitral stenosis (MS) causes left atrial enlargement, which typically appears on ECG as Broad, bifid P waves, especially in lead II → “P mitrale.”

P Wave in ECG:

Feature

Normal P Wave

Right Atrial Enlargement (P Pulmonale)

Left Atrial Enlargement (P Mitrale)

Cause

Normal atrial depolarization
  • Pulmonary disease
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Tricuspid valve disorders
  • Mitral valve disease
  • Left ventricular failure

 

Amplitude

< 2.5 mm

> 2.5 mm (in leads II, III, aVF, sometimes V1)

May be increased but less prominent than in RAA

Duration

< 0.12 sec (120 ms)

Normal (< 0.12 sec)

Prolonged > 0.12 sec (broad P wave)

Shape

Smooth, upright

Tall, peaked, narrow

Lead II Appearance

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding breastfeeding technique is/are incorrect?

A) The infant’s lower lip should be inverted during latching

B) The infant’s cheeks should appear full during effective suckling

C) A greater portion of areola should be covered above the breast than below

D) The infant’s chin should make contact with the breast during feeding
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A and C only

Explanation

  • A) The infant's lower lip should be inverted during latching: This statement is incorrect. For a proper latch, the infant's lower lip should be everted (flanged outwards), not inverted. An inverted lower lip indicates a shallow latch and can lead to nipple pain for the mother and inadequate milk transfer for the baby.
  • B) The infant's cheeks should appear full during effective suckling: This statement is correct. When an infant is effectively suckling and getting milk, their cheeks should appear full and rounded, indicating that their mouth is well-filled with breast tissue and they are creating good suction. Dimpling of the cheeks often suggests a shallow latch or ineffective suckling.
  • C) A greater portion of areola should be covered above the breast than below: This statement is incorrect. For an effective latch, a greater portion of the areola should be covered BELOW the nipple than above it. This allows the infant to take in more breast tissue from the underside, which is crucial for compressing the milk ducts and extracting milk efficiently.
  • D) The infant's chin should make contact with the breast during feeding: This statement is correct. The infant's chin should be tucked into the breast, making good contact. This position helps the baby to open their mouth wide and take in a good amount of breast tissue, facilitating a deep and effective latch.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding snake bites?

a.  Elapidae is myotoxic

b. Viperidae is vasculotoxic

c. Hyaluronidase is secreted by all snake toxins

d. Toxins travel through lymphatics and superficial veins
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) b, c and d

Explanation:

The Elapidae family (e.g., cobra, krait) venom is primarily neurotoxic, not myotoxic.

Neurotoxins act at neuromuscular junctions, causing paralysis. (Option a)

Myotoxicity is more commonly associated with sea snakes and some viper venoms.

Viperidae (e.g., Russell’s viper, saw-scaled viper) venom causes vasculotoxic effects -

Damages endothelium, causes hemorrhage, leading to DIC, shock, and local tissue necrosis. (Option b)

Hyaluronidase is secreted by all snake toxins,it breaks down connective tissue matrix and facilitates diffusion of venom into tissues. It is present in the venom of most (nearly all) snakes across families. (Option c)

Venom predominantly spreads through the lymphatic system and superficial veins, especially in low-pressure systems like limbs. (Option d)

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the mechanism of breast milk jaundice?

choices.text: Increased bilirubin production due to red blood cell breakdown
Inhibition of bilirubin conjugation by substances such as non-esterified fatty acids and beta-glucuronidase, in breast milk
Hepatocellular injury caused by maternal hormones

questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option B) Inhibition of bilirubin conjugation by substances such as non-esterified fatty acids and beta-glucuronidase, in breast milk

Explanation

  • Breast milk jaundice is a type of prolonged unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that typically appears after the first week of life in otherwise healthy, exclusively breastfed infants.
  • The exact mechanism is not fully understood, but it's believed that certain factors in breast milk interfere with the normal processing and excretion of bilirubin.
  • Beta-glucuronidase is an enzyme present in breast milk that can deconjugate bilirubin in the infant's intestine. This deconjugated bilirubin can then be reabsorbed into the bloodstream (enterohepatic circulation), leading to elevated bilirubin levels.
  • Non-esterified fatty acids (also called free fatty acids), which are released from breast milk triglycerides by the action of lipase, can also inhibit the enzyme in the liver (glucuronyl transferase) responsible for conjugating bilirubin. Conjugation is a crucial step for bilirubin to be excreted from the body.

Other Options ruled out

  • Increased bilirubin production due to red blood cell breakdown(Option A ruled out): This is the primary mechanism for physiologic jaundice (which occurs in the first few days of life) and hemolytic jaundice (due to conditions like ABO incompatibility). While newborns naturally have increased RBC breakdown, breast milk jaundice specifically refers to the prolonged jaundice due to breast milk factors, not primarily increased production.
  • Hepatocellular injury caused by maternal hormones(Option C ruled out): While some early theories suggested certain maternal hormones (like pregnane-3α,20β-diol) in breast milk might play a role, this mechanism is not as strongly supported or understood as the role of beta-glucuronidase and free fatty acids. Hepatocellular injury is also not the defining feature of breast milk jaundice.
  • Decreased intestinal absorption of bilirubin(Option D ruled out): This is the opposite of what happens. Breast milk jaundice is thought to involve increased enterohepatic circulation, meaning more bilirubin is reabsorbed from the intestine, not less.

questions.text:
A child presents with fatigue and hepatomegaly. Liver enzymes (ALT, AST) are elevated. Ketosis was significant. Liver biopsy shows excess glycogen accumulation. After feeding, blood glucose levels rise, but there is no rise in glucose after overnight fasting.

Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glucose-6-phosphatase

Explanation:

The child’s presentation—fatigue, hepatomegaly, elevated liver enzymes, marked ketosis, glycogen accumulation in the liver, fasting hypoglycemia with normal postprandial glucose—strongly points toward a Glucose-6-phosphatase (G6PD) deficiency

Von Gierke's Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I)

 

Cause

Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme

Pathophysiology

Inability to convert glucose-6-phosphate to glucose; leads to accumulation of glycogen, lactate, and triglycerides

Symptoms
  • Severe hypoglycemia
  • Hepatomegaly and Renomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hyperuricemia and Hyperlipidemia

Diagnosis
  • Biochemical tests (hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia)
  • Genetic testing

Management
  • Frequent feedings with slow-release carbohydrates
  • Blood glucose monitoring
  • Medications for associated conditions
  • Liver transplantation (in severe cases)

 

Liver phosphorylase (GSD VI – Hers disease) (Option B) causes mild hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly, but symptoms are less severe. Gluconeogenesis is intact, so fasting hypoglycemia and ketosis are not as pronounced as in glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency.

 

Muscle phosphorylase (GSD V – McArdle disease) (Option C) affects only skeletal muscle. Presents with exercise intolerance and muscle cramps, not fasting hypoglycemia or hepatomegaly.

 

Phosphofructokinase (GSD VII – Tarui disease) (Option D) involves muscle and red blood cells. Causes muscle pain and hemolysis, but does not affect the liver or cause fasting hypoglycemia.

Learning Objectives:

 

Glycogen Storage Disease

Enzyme Deficiency

Type 0

Glycogen synthase deficiency

Type I (von Gierke's Disease)

Glucose-6-phosphatase

Type II (Pompe's Disease)

Acid α-glucosidase (acid maltase)

Type III (Cori's Disease)

Debranching enzyme (amylo-1,6-glucosidase)

Type IV (Andersen's Disease)

Branching enzyme

Type V (McArdle's Disease)

Muscle phosphorylase (myophosphorylase)

Type VI (Hers' Disease)

Liver phosphorylase

Type VII (Tarui's Disease)

Phosphofructokinase (muscle type)

questions.text: A 2 year old child presents with leg pain, difficulty walking and easy fatiguability. Which is the unusual diagnosis for this ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Metastatic retinoblastoma

Explanation:

Metastatic Retinoblastoma is the most unusual cause of a 2-year-old child presenting with leg pain, difficulty walking, and easy fatigability because of the following reasons:

  • Retinoblastoma primarily affects the eyes and most commonly presents with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex), strabismus, or vision loss.
  • Metastasis occurs late and usually spreads to the CNS (brain/spine), bones (skull), or lymph nodes—not typically long bones (legs).
  • Leg pain and difficulty walking are rare as initial symptoms of retinoblastoma.

Ewing Sarcoma (Option A) A bone tumor that frequently affects the femur/pelvis in children, causing bone pain, limping, and pathological fractures.

Metastatic Renal Clear Cell Sarcoma (Option B) A rare kidney tumor that metastasizes to bones (including legs), causing bone pain and mobility issues.

Metastatic Neuroblastoma (Option C) Commonly metastasizes to bones (especially femur, pelvis) and presents with bone pain, limping, and fatigue due to bone marrow infiltration.

questions.text:
Which among the following are incorrect about tension pneumothorax?


	Occurs due to improper dressing of open wound
	Blunt trauma with simple pneumothorax can never convert to tension pneumothorax
	Most common cause is due to positive pressure in mechanical ventilation
	Can be caused due to spinal injury
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 2,3

Explanation:

Statements 2 and 3 are incorrect while 1 and 4 are correct.

  • A tension pneumothorax develops when a ‘one-way valve’ air leak occurs either from the lung or through the chest wall.
  • Open (sucking) chest wounds can act as a one-way valve when improperly dressed. Air enters during inspiration but cannot exit during expiration, causing a valve mechanism, leading to tension pneumothorax. (Statement 1)
  • High cervical spinal injuries may result in diaphragmatic paralysis or respiratory failure, predisposing to pneumothorax due to barotrauma from mechanical ventilation or reduced clearance. Though indirect, spinal injury can be associated with tension pneumothorax. (Statement 4)

 

TENSION PNEUMOTHORAX

Pathophysiology
  • D/t ‘one-way valve’ air leaks from the lung or chest wall.
  • Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any escape, collapsing and compressing the affected lung.
  • The mediastinum shifts to the opposite side, reducing venous return and compressing the opposite lung, leading to decreased cardiac output and function. This can result in sudden death.

Causes
  • Penetrating Chest Trauma.
  • Blunt Chest Trauma with parenchymal lung injury and persistent air leak. (Statement 2)
  • Iatrogenic Lung Injury (e.g., central venepuncture)
  • Mechanical Positive-Pressure Ventilation. (Statement 3)

Clinical Features
  • Tachypnea and Tachycardia
  • Hyper-resonance and Decreased/Absent Breath Sounds
  • Resonant Percussion with severe mediastinal/tracheal shift
  • Cyanosis and Hypotension
  • Chest Pain
  • Distended Neck Veins

Emergency Management
  • Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed by waiting for radiological confirmation.
  • Immediate Thoracocentesis (needle): Wide bore needle (typically a 20- or 22-gauge) in the 5th intercostal space in the safety triangle.
  • Decompression should be performed in the "safe triangle."
  • Safe Triangle Boundaries:
    • Posterior: Latissimus dorsi
    • Anterior: Lateral border of the pectoralis major
    • Inferior: A line drawn perpendicularly from the nipple to the back, just anterior to the mid-axillary line.

  • In critical situations, a finger thoracostomy can be done in the same location.
  • Nasal Oxygen for support.
  • Intercostal Tube Placement (ICT) once stable and confirmed by chest X-ray.

Additional Care

  • Antibiotics and analgesics for treatment.
  • Ventilator Support with IPPV in severe cases.

questions.text: All of the following is a contraindication to Breast Conservation surgery except ?

choices.text: Previous history of radiation to the chest
Persistent positive margins even after resection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tumor involving single quadrant

Explanation:

  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS), also known as lumpectomy or wide local excision (WLE), is contraindicated in certain conditions where it may compromise oncological safety or cosmetic outcomes. BCS is feasible if the tumor is confined to a single quadrant and is aimed at removing the tumour along with a 1-cm margin of normal breast tissue. All patients with BCS receive radiotherapy. BCS together with radiotherapy is called breast conservation therapy (BCT): BCS + RT = BCT

BCS is avoided in patients with:

  1. Multicentric tumour
  2. Diffuse microcalcifications on a mammogram
  3. Large tumour-to-breast ratio
  4. Two times positive surgical margins after re-excision
  5. History of previous breast or chest wall radiation
  6. Systemic lupus erythematosus or other collagen vascular disease (these patients have a high risk of a radiation reaction), or ankylosing spondylitis
  7. Severe orthopnea (as the patient cannot lie on the radiation table)

Previous history of radiation to the chest (Option A) Prior radiation to the chest (e.g., for Hodgkin’s lymphoma) increases the risk of radiation-induced toxicity and poor wound healing, making BCS unsafe.

Scleroderma (Option C) Scleroderma (a connective tissue disorder) impairs wound healing and increases radiation toxicity, making BCS + radiotherapy risky.

Persistent positive margins even after resection (Option D) Patients with involved margins will have to undergo a revision of margins called a ‘cavity shave’.

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the development of hyponatremia in a hypovolemic patient with diarrhea?

choices.text: Decreased reabsorption of sodium from kidney
Decreased sodium absorption from the intestine

questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option c) Non-osmotic release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)

 

Explanation-

Hyponatremia in a hypovolemic patient with diarrhea is a common and important clinical scenario. Let's analyze the options:

  • a. Decreased reabsorption of sodium from kidney: In hypovolemia, the body's compensatory mechanisms (like the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system) actually increase sodium reabsorption from the kidney to try and conserve volume. So, this is unlikely to be the primary cause of hyponatremia in this context.
     
  • b. Decreased secretion of aldosterone: Aldosterone secretion is increased in hypovolemia as part of the body's attempt to conserve sodium and water. Decreased aldosterone would lead to sodium loss, but it's not the normal response to hypovolemia.
     
  • c. Non-osmotic release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH): This is the most likely and best explanation. In significant hypovolemia (even if plasma osmolality is normal or low), the body prioritizes maintaining circulating volume. This triggers a non-osmotic release of ADH from the posterior pituitary. This ADH then acts on the kidneys to increase water reabsorption, leading to dilution of existing sodium and thus hyponatremia. Despite having diarrhea (which causes loss of both water and electrolytes), if the patient is rehydrated with hypotonic fluids (e.g., plain water) or if the ADH-induced water retention is significant, hyponatremia can develop.
     
  • d. Decreased sodium absorption from the intestine: Diarrhea primarily involves increased fluid and electrolyte loss from the intestine, not necessarily decreased absorption of sodium (though absorption can be impaired). While the loss of sodium contributes to the overall electrolyte imbalance, the dilutional aspect caused by inappropriate water retention is critical for hyponatremia in the setting of hypovolemia and ADH release.
     

Therefore, the best explanation for the development of hyponatremia in a hypovolemic patient with diarrhea is c. Non-osmotic release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). The body's overwhelming drive to restore blood volume overrides the normal osmotic regulation of ADH, leading to excessive water retention relative to sodium.

questions.text: At a PHC, a medical officer provides treatment and counselling to diabetic patients. Their body weights are recorded before the intervention and again 6 months later, using the health register. Which of the following statistical tests is most appropriate to analyze the change in weight in this group?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Paired t-test:

Explanation:

  • The most appropriate statistical test to analyze the change in weight in the same group of diabetic patients before and after the intervention is the paired t-test, which compares the means of two related measurements from the same individuals.

  • Types of Parametric tests:

Parametric Test

Description

Paired Student's t-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in paired data from the same group of individuals before and after an intervention. (Option B)

Unpaired Student's t-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in two different groups of individuals. The Z-test is a variant of the unpaired Student's t-test used when the sample size is > 30.

ANOVA

Used to compare means (± SD) in more than two different groups of individuals. (Option C ruled out)

Pearson correlation coefficient

Measures the linear association between two variables and can range from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Types of Non-parametric tests

  • Chi-square test (Option A) is used to assess the association between two categorical variables. Since body weight is a continuous variable and we are comparing means, this test is not appropriate.
  • Independent t-test (Option D) is used to compare the means of two separate, unrelated groups. In this case, the same individuals are being measured at two different points in time, so the groups are not independent.

questions.text: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), which of the following best defines blindness?

choices.text: Best corrected visual acuity <6/60 in the better eye
Best corrected visual acuity <3/60 in the better eye
Uncorrected visual acuity <6/60 in any eye
Uncorrected visual acuity <3/60 in any eye

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Best corrected visual acuity <3/60 in the better eye:

Explanation:

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as having a best corrected visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye

 

WHO Classification of Visual Impairment

The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as "visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent". (Option B)

The International Classification of Disease 11 (2018) classifies vision impairment into distance and near-presenting vision impairment

Classification

Visual Acuity

Mild Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12

Moderate Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18

Severe Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60

Blindness

Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60

Near Vision Impairment

Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or M0.8 at 40 cm with existing correction

 

NPCB Classification of Visual Impairment

The National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India defines blindness as "visual acuity of <3/60 in a better eye with best possible correction" and central visual field <10 degrees. The NPCB further categorizes visual impairment as:

Classification

Visual Acuity

Visual Impairment

Visual acuity of less than 6/18 in the better eye with available correction

Low Vision

Visual acuity of less than 6/18 to 6/60

Economic Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 6/60 to 3/60

Social Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 3/60 to 1/60

Manifest Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 1/60 to the perception of light

Absolute Blindness

No perception of light

questions.text:
Which of the following causes acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis:


	Polio virus
	Coxsackie A
	Coxsackie B
	Enterovirus 70
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 3,4

Explanation:

Acute Hemorrhagic Conjunctivitis

  • A highly contagious eye infection characterized by conjunctival redness, swelling, pain, photophobia, and subconjunctival hemorrhages.
  • It is caused by specific viral pathogens that can spread rapidly in crowded settings.
  • Pathogens: Enterovirus 70 and Coxsackievirus A
  • Occurs in the pandemic form of violent inflammatory conjunctivitis
  • Clinical Features:
    • Lacrimation
    • Photophobia
    • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
    • Enlarged preauricular lymph nodes
    • Cornea is usually affected

Non-viral agents of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis:

  1. Pneumococci
  2. Neisseria species
  3. Haemophilus species
  4. Chlamydia

Polio virus (Option 1) RNA virus, belonging to family Picornavirus, under genera Enterovirus, usually affecting the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, causing either an inapparent infection, abortive poliomyelitis, paralytic poliomyelitis or non-paralytic poliomyelitis. It does not cause hemorrhagic conjunctivitis

Coxsackie B virus (Option 3) RNA virus, belonging to family Picornavirus, under genera Enterovirus, Epidemic myalgia or pleurodynia, also known as Bornholm disease, Myocarditis and pericarditis in the newborn, Juvenile diabetes, Orchitis, post-viral fatigue syndrome. Transplacental and neonatal transmission causes a serious disseminated disease that may in

questions.text: Caspase-1 is primarily involved in which type of programmed cell death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pyroptosis

Explanation:

Caspase-1 plays a central role in Pyroptosis, a form of programmed cell death associated with inflammation.

  • It is a form of apoptosis in which there is release of the fever-inducing cytokine IL-1.
  • Microbial products entering infected cells are recognized by cytoplasmic receptors,
  • activating the multiprotein complex inflammasome.
  • This complex activates caspase 1 which converts the inactive IL-1 to active IL-1, causing fever, inflammation and leucocyte recruitment. (Option B)
  • Pyroptosis is the mechanism by which some microbes cause the death of infected cells and trigger local inflammation.

 

Apoptosis (Option A) is a controlled, non-inflammatory cell death involving caspases-8, -9, -3, and -7, but not caspase-1, and serves to remove damaged cells without triggering an immune response.

Necroptosis (Option C) is a programmed inflammatory cell death triggered when apoptosis is blocked, involving RIPK1, RIPK3, and MLKL—but not caspase-1, distinguishing it from pyroptosis.

Necrosis (Option D) is an uncontrolled, non-programmed cell death due to injury (e.g., trauma or ischemia), causing inflammation without involving caspases, including caspase-1.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of cardiac failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Non-pulsatile elevation of JVP

Explanation:

  • Cardiac failure (heart failure) presents with a range of symptoms depending on whether it is right-sided, left-sided, or both.
  • Elevated JVP is a feature of right-sided heart failure, but it is typically pulsatile, reflecting right atrial pressure transmitted through the jugular vein.
  • Non-pulsatile JVP elevation suggests an alternative cause like superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction, not heart failure.

Congestive Heart Failure - Clinical Features

  • Cardiac output decreased
  • Stroke volume decreased
  • Heart rate increased
  • Increased sympathetic drive leading to palpitations and diaphoresis
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

Clinical Features of Left-Sided vs. Right-Sided Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)

Left-Sided Heart Failure

Right-Sided Heart Failure

Causes:

  • Ischemic heart disease (myocardial infarction).
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • Aortic or mitral valve disease.

Causes:

  • Left-sided heart failure (most common cause).
  • Chronic lung diseases (COPD, pulmonary hypertension).
  • Pulmonary embolism.
  • Right ventricular infarction.

In left-sided heart failure, the left ventricle cannot effectively pump blood to the body, leading to a backup of blood into the lungs.

 

Clinical features:

This primarily results in pulmonary symptoms.

  • Dyspnea
  • Exertional dyspnea).
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

Pulmonary Congestion:

  • Crackles (rales) heard on auscultation due to fluid in the alveoli.
  • Cough
  • Wheezing (cardiac asthma).
  • Fatigue and Weakness
  • Decreased Exercise Tolerance
  • Limited physical activity due to breathlessness and fatigue.
  • S3 Gallop
  • Cool Extremities: Reduced cardiac output may cause poor peripheral circulation, leading to cold, pale skin.

In right-sided heart failure, the right ventricle fails to pump blood effectively into the pulmonary circulation, leading to systemic venous congestion. It is often secondary to left-sided heart failure or conditions affecting the lungs (cor pulmonale).

 

Clinical Features:

  • Peripheral Edema
  • Jugular Venous Distension (JVD)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • B/L pitting pedal edema
  • Kussmaul sign: JVP elevation on inspiration
  • Ascites
  • Nocturia
  • Weight Gain
  • Anorexia and Nausea

Incorrect Options:

Right hypochondriac pain (Option A) is a symptom of right-sided heart failure due to liver congestion.

Orthopnea (Option C) is a classic symptom of left-sided heart failure, caused by pulmonary congestion when lying flat.

Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND) (Option D) is a common symptom of left-sided heart failure, due to fluid redistribution at night causing sudden breathlessness.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a feed-forward mechanism?

choices.text: Increase in heart rate on standing from supine position
Increased cardiac output in response to anemia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option D) Temperature Regulation

Feedforward

  • Description: Anticipates a change and initiates responses before the change fully occurs.
  • Examples:
    • Cephalic phase of gastric secretion (e.g., salivating when you see food).
    • Temperature regulation (e.g., shivering before body temperature drops significantly).
    • Anxiety leading to tachycardia (heart rate increase).

 

Vasoconstriction in response to cooling:
Feedforward Component: As discussed previously, the anticipation of a core temperature drop based on skin cooling provides a crucial feedforward element, allowing for a rapid, preemptive response.

 

Increase in heart rate on standing from a supine position:
Feedforward Component: The combined effect of increased heart rate, contractility, and vasoconstriction helps to restore blood pressure to near normal levels, maintaining adequate blood flow to the brain.

 

Increased cardiac output in response to anemia:
Feedforward Component: The increased cardiac output (achieved through increased heart rate, stroke volume, and reduced afterload) attempts to deliver more blood, and thus more oxygen, to the oxygen-deprived tissues. This is a compensatory mechanism to maintain oxygen delivery despite the reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.

questions.text: Which of the following Acts is primarily concerned with the protection of personal medical data and privacy in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - DPDP Act

Explanation:

The Digital Personal Data Protection Act (DPDP), 2023, is concerned with the protection of personal medical data and privacy in India.

  • An Act to provide for the processing of digital personal data in a manner that recognises both the right of individuals to protect their personal data and the need to process such personal data for lawful purposes and for matters connected therewith or incidental thereto.

Incorrect Options: 

PNDT Act (Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques Act) (Option A): This Act is designed to prevent female foeticide by regulating the use of prenatal diagnostic techniques. It aims to prohibit sex selection before or after conception but does not deal with the protection of personal medical data or privacy.
 

HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act) (Option C): HIPAA is a United States federal law that protects the privacy and security of individuals’ medical information. Although it is widely recognized for safeguarding health data, it is not applicable in India.
 

MTP Act (Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act) (Option D): This Act governs the legal termination of pregnancies in India, setting conditions under which abortion is permitted. It does not address data privacy or the protection of personal medical information.

questions.text: Cancer cells take up excess glucose because?

choices.text: Lactate is produced even in the presence of Oxygen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lactate is produced even in the presence of Oxygen

Explanation:

Cancer cells demonstrate the Warburg Effect by favoring the conversion of glucose to lactate even in the presence of adequate oxygen, a process known as aerobic glycolysis.

  • The phenomenon in cancer cells where, even in the presence of oxygen, glucose is primarily converted to lactate through aerobic glycolysis. (Option A)
  • Significance:
    • This allows faster ATP production and provides intermediates for neoplastic cell growth and multiplication.
    • It increases NADPH production, protecting neoplastic cells from oxidative stress.

 

High NADH/NAD ratio (Option B): Although the NADH/NAD⁺ balance affects cellular metabolism, it is not the primary reason cancer cells take up excess glucose. The Warburg effect drives increased glucose uptake regardless of NADH levels.
 

High GLUT2 (Option C): GLUT2 is a glucose transporter mainly found in liver, pancreatic beta cells, and kidney, not commonly involved in cancer cell glucose uptake. Cancer cells typically overexpress GLUT1 or other transporters to increase glucose intake.
 

Absence of Oxygen (Option D): While low oxygen (hypoxia) can stimulate glucose uptake, many cancer cells continue to produce lactate and consume large amounts of glucose even when oxygen is plentiful, which is the hallmark of aerobic glycolysis, not simply hypoxia-induced metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is/are supplied by the superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve?

  • The tibialis anterior (Option C ruled out) muscle is supplied by the deep fibular nerve (also known as the deep peroneal nerve).

questions.text: A lung biopsy from a post-renal transplant patient shows an infection. Which of the following stains is least useful in identifying the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Congo red

Explanation:

In a post-renal transplant patient with a lung infection, the presence of 45-degree branching hyphae on histology suggests Aspergillus infection. Stains like PAS, Gomori Methenamine Silver (GMS), and Fontana-Masson are useful for identifying fungal organisms. However, Congo red is not helpful in this context, as it is used to detect amyloid deposits (apple-green birefringence).

  • Culture: Colonies have a velvety to powdery surface and are characteristically coloured:
    • A.fumigatus - dark green ;
    • A.niger - black ;
    • A.flavus - yellow-green ;
    • A.terreus - beige coloured colonies.
  • Histopathology
    • Stain used - Lactophenol cotton blue
    • It demonstrates septate hyphae and acute angled (<45°) / Dichotomous branching.

  • Presence of galactomannan
  • Tissue sections: Biopsy (stained with GMS/PAS) (Option B, C ruled out)

questions.text: A male presents with lesions and a history of unprotected sexual intercourse a few months ago. What is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Serology

Explanation:

The lesions depicted in the image, along with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse, suggest a diagnosis of Secondary Syphilis, which is best confirmed through serological testing.

  • It is the second stage of syphilis, which occurs if primary syphilis is left untreated.
  • It presents a few weeks to several months after the initial chancre has healed.
  • It is marked by systemic manifestations and can affect multiple organ systems.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Diffuse, non-pruritic rash, often reddish-brown macules or papules, that is polymorphous and non-vesicular.
    • Mucous membrane lesions, such as condylomata lata, appear in moist areas like the oral cavity and genitals and are highly infectious.
    • Oral signs may include mucous patches or snail track ulcers.
    • “Moth-eaten" alopecia: A patchy, non-scarring hair loss.
    • Buschke-Ollendorff sign: Deep tenderness over lesions.
    • Painless generalized lymphadenopathy (especially epitrochlear nodes)l.
    • Systemic symptoms include fever, malaise, and fatigue, with rare cases showing neurological or ocular involvement.
  • Diagnosis: By serological testing: (Option A)
    • Non-Treponemal Tests:
      • RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin) and VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) are used for screening.
      • These tests detect nonspecific antibodies and can be positive in other conditions.
    • Treponemal Tests:
      • FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption) confirms the diagnosis by detecting antibodies specific to Treponema pallidum.
  • Treatment:
    • Standard treatment: Benzathine penicillin G.
    • Dosage: 2.4 million units intramuscularly in a single dose.
    • For those allergic to penicillin, alternatives such as doxycycline or tetracycline can be used.
  • Complications: If left untreated, secondary syphilis can progress to the latent stage and eventually tertiary syphilis, which can lead to serious complications, including cardiovascular, neurological, and systemic damage.

Incorrect Options:

Tzanck smear (Option B) is a diagnostic test primarily used for identifying infections caused by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) and Varicella-Zoster Virus. It involves examining cells scraped from a lesion under a microscope. However, this test has no role in diagnosing syphilis, as it does not detect Treponema pallidum, the bacterium responsible for the disease.

KOH preparation (Option C) is commonly employed to diagnose superficial fungal infections such as dermatophytosis or candidiasis. A sample from the skin, hair, or nails is treated with potassium hydroxide, which dissolves keratin and allows for the visualization of fungal elements under a microscope. Since syphilis is a bacterial infection, this test is irrelevant in its diagnosis.

Biopsy (Option D) is used to evaluate suspicious skin lesions when the diagnosis is unclear, and it can sometimes reveal histopathological features suggestive of syphilis. It is invasive and nonspecific, whereas serological tests are more sensitive, specific, and the preferred method for diagnosing secondary syphilis.

questions.text: According to recent NACO guidelines, which of the following groups is no longer classified as a high-risk group (HRG) for HIV transmission?

choices.text: Men who have sex with men (MSM)

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Truck drivers

Explanation:

  • As per the latest guidelines from the National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO), truck drivers are no longer classified as a high-risk group (HRG) for HIV transmission.

Sentinel Surveillance for HIV:

HIV Sentinel Surveillance

HIV sentinel surveillance tracks missing cases and monitors HIV infection trends in specific groups and regions to understand epidemic dynamics and guide public health interventions.

Objectives
  • Monitor HIV infection trends & emerging pockets of HIV infection.
  • Estimate HIV prevalence in general population as well as high-risk groups and burden in the country and high-risk groups across states.
  • Provide data for program evaluation and improvement.

Key Features
  • Focus on High-Risk Groups: Commercial sex workers (CSW), men who have sex with men (MSM), injecting drug users, and transgender individuals. (Option A, B, D ruled out)
  • Antenatal Women as Proxies: Includes data from antenatal women to estimate HIV prevalence in the general population.

Key Uses
  • Resource Allocation: Helps direct resources and interventions to the most affected areas and populations.
  • Program Evaluation: Tracks trends to evaluate the effectiveness of HIV/AIDS control programs.
  • Early Warning System: Acts as an early warning for emerging outbreaks or changes in transmission patterns.

Frequency and Timing

Conducted biennially, with the most recent surveillance in India done in 2021

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common clinical feature observed during the progression of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C. Arthralgia & myalgia

Explanation:

  • Musculoskeletal involvement is the most common clinical feature in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).
  • Arthralgia (joint pain) and myalgia (muscle pain) occur in the majority of patients, often as initial symptoms.
  • SLE commonly presents with polyarthritis or polyarthralgia that resembles rheumatoid arthritis, but is typically non-erosive.

 

Systemic Involvement in SLE

System

Manifestations

Pulmonary system

 
  • Pleuritis (most common): Prevalence (30 - 50%)
  • Pneumonitis
  • Atelectasis
  • Reduced lung volume and
  • Pulmonary ﬁbrosis
  • Shrinking lung syndrome, (< 5%)
  • Intra-alveolar hemorrhage
  • Pulmonary HTN (< 5 %)
  • Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) (< 5%)

Musculoskeletal system

 
  • It is the most commonly involved system
  • Polyarthritis (symmetrical)
  • Polyarthralgia
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Myositis
  • Jaccoud arthropathy is a reversible deformity caused by ligament laxity, capsule fibrosis, and muscular imbalance.
  • Axial skeletal involvement is uncommon. ​

 

Renal system

 
  • Lupus nephritis (most common)
  • Proteinuria
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Rarely End-stage Renal Disease (ESRD)

Nervous system

 
  • Headache, Seizures, Stroke, Polyneuropathy, TIA, Acute confusional state, Movement disorder, Aseptic meningitis, Myelopathy, Psychosis and Mood disorders.

Cardiovascular system

 

 Coronary artery disease - common cause of death
  • Pericarditis
  • Coronary vasculitis
  • Myocarditis
  • Libman sacks endocarditis
  • Accelerated atherosclerosis

 

Hematological manifestations

 

  
  • Anemia of chronic disease
  • Leucopenia
  • Lymphopenia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Autoimmune Hemolytic anemia-MCC of anemia in SLE
  • Splenomegaly

 

GI involvement

 
  • Abdominal pain
  • Nausea, diarrhoea
  • Abnormal liver enzymes

 

Ocular manifestation

 
  • Sicca syndrome: Dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia).
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Episcleritis
  • Vasculitis

questions.text: Identify the condition associated with the MRI finding shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option A) Pantothenate Kinase deficiency

Explanation

  • Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN), formerly Hallervorden-Spatz disease(Option A): The classic MRI finding is the "eye-of-the-tiger" sign in the globus pallidus. This is characterized by bilateral, symmetric hypointensity (darker) on T2-weighted images with a central area of hyperintensity (brighter). This pattern is due to iron accumulation and neuronal loss.

Incorrect Options:

Wilson's disease(Option B ruled out): MRI findings in Wilson's disease can be varied but often involve the basal ganglia (especially the putamen and globus pallidus), brainstem, and thalami. Common findings include bilateral, symmetrical hyperintensities on T2-weighted images in these areas. There can also be atrophy and cavitations in chronic stages.

Krabbe's disease (Globoid cell leukodystrophy)(Option C ruled out): This is a white matter disease. MRI typically shows diffuse, symmetric white matter hyperintensities on T2-weighted images, often beginning in the posterior cerebral white matter and progressing anteriorly. There can also be involvement of the thalami and brainstem. In later stages, cerebral atrophy may be seen.

Huntington's chorea(Option D ruled out): The characteristic MRI finding in Huntington's disease is bilateral atrophy of the caudate nuclei and putamen. This can be seen as widening of the frontal horns of the lateral ventricles due to the loss of caudate head volume. Generalized brain atrophy may also be present in later stages.

questions.text: Sodium thiopentone is regarded as an ultrashort-acting drug due to (true or false)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rapid redistribution

Explanation:

  • Sodium thiopentone (Thiopental) is a barbiturate used for induction of anesthesia. It is classified as an ultrashort-acting agent, and this characteristic is due to its rapid redistribution

  • Thiopental sodium has a rapid onset due to its high lipid solubility and high nonionized fraction, allowing for quick redistribution from the bloodstream to the brain.

Thiopentone Sodium:

  • Use: Intravenous induction agent.

  • Prepared concentration: 2.5% solution

  • Form: Yellowish-white crystalline powder or pale greenish hygroscopic powder

  • Odor: Garlic-like odor.

  • Formulation: Thiopental sodium for injection is a sterile mixture of thiopental sodium and anhydrous sodium carbonate (buffer).

  • Should not be reconstituted with lactated Ringer’s solution or mixed with acidic solutions, as this reduces alkalinity and may cause precipitation of the drug as free acid.

  • pH: 11

  • Melting Point: The free acid (thiopental) melts at 158–160°C.

  • Solubility:

    • Water: Soluble in 1.5 parts of water at 20°C.

    • Alcohol: Partially soluble.

    • Insoluble: Practically insoluble in ether, benzene, and petroleum ether.

  • Pharmacokinetics:

    • Higher potency.

    • Rapid onset and short duration of action.

    • Dose: 3-6 mg/kg

    • Duration of onset: 15-20 seconds

    • Duration of action: 6-10 minutes

    • Elimination T1/2: 12 hours (Option D)

    • Exhibits first-order kinetics.

    • Unique property: Duration of induction dose is determined by redistribution.

    • Metabolism: Liver (plays a role in elimination, not in the rapid offset of action) (Option B)

    • Excretion site: Kidney, (renal excretion is also slow and doesn't affect the immediate duration of action) (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is contraindicated in a patient diagnosed with Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option D) Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR)

  • Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR): This is a live-attenuated viral vaccine. It contains weakened measles, mumps, and rubella viruses. Giving this vaccine to a patient with SCID would pose a significant risk of causing severe, disseminated measles, mumps, or rubella infection, which could be fatal. Therefore, the MMR vaccine is contraindicated in a patient with SCID.

Explanation

  • Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) is a life-threatening primary immunodeficiency characterized by a severe defect in both cellular (T-cell) and humoral (B-cell, indirectly) immunity. Patients with SCID are highly susceptible to infections.
  • The general rule for vaccinating immunocompromised individuals, especially those with severe immunodeficiencies like SCID, is to avoid live-attenuated vaccines. Live-attenuated vaccines contain weakened forms of the virus or bacteria, which can replicate in the body and, in a severely immunocompromised person, can cause the full-blown disease rather than a protective immune response.

Other options ruled out

  • Hepatitis B(Option A ruled out): This is an inactivated (killed) vaccine. Inactivated vaccines do not contain live pathogens and are generally safe for immunocompromised individuals, although their immune response might be blunted.
  • Tetanus, Diphtheria, and Pertussis (Tdap)(Option B ruled out): This is a toxoid and inactivated vaccine (diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, and inactivated pertussis components). It is safe for immunocompromised individuals.
  • Inactivated Poliovirus (IPV)(Option C ruled out): As the name suggests, this is an inactivated (killed) vaccine. It is safe for immunocompromised individuals. (Note: The Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) is a live-attenuated vaccine and would be contraindicated).

questions.text:
According to the Drugs and Cosmetics Rules, match the following medications with their corresponding schedules.


	
		
			
			Medication 
			
			
			Schedule
			
		
		
			
			1. Insulin
			
			
			A. Schedule H
			
		
		
			
			2. Hepatitis B vaccine
			
			
			B. Schedule Z
			
		
		
			
			3. Morphine
			
			
			C. Schedule G
			
		
		
			
			4. Veterinary drugs
			
			
			D. Schedule X
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

Explanation:

Medication

Schedule

Insulin

Schedule G

Hepatitis B vaccine

Schedule H

Morphine

Schedule X

Veterinary drugs

Schedule Z

 

Schedules of drugs as per the Drugs and Cosmetics Act of India:

Schedule

Description

Biological and Special Products: Includes sera, vaccines, toxins, antitoxins, insulin, etc.

Schedule D

Drugs: Extends to diagnostic kits and reagents including various biotechnological products.

Schedule E

questions.text: In the given glycine titration curve, calculate or identify the pH at which molecules exist in a zwitter ion form?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 6

Explanation:

In the given glycine titration curve, the pH at which the molecules predominantly exist in their zwitterionic form is 6.

 

Isoelectric pH

  • It is the pH at which a molecule carries no net electrical charge.
  • For proteins and amino acids, this is the pH where the molecule exists as a “zwitter ion” with equal numbers of positive and negative charges, resulting in a net zero charge and no migration in an electric field.
  • The isoelectric pH (pI) for monoamino monocarboxylic amino acids can be calculated:

  • In the above question, it will be = (2.2 + 9.6)/2 = 5.9 ≃ 6.

questions.text: After how many cycles of PCR, are we expected to have half the number of copies as found after 26 cycles?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 25

Explanation:

If PCR goes through ‘n’ number of cycles,

Number of products formed: 2n

Half the number of copies compared to after 26 cycles will be: 25

Steps of PCR:

Step 1- Denaturation

The double-stranded DNA is heated to around 95°C to separate into 2 single strands.

 

Step 2- Annealing

  • Addition of two primers, which anneals the flanking sequence of the desired fragments.
  • An optimal temperature (5 degrees less than the average melting temperature of the primers) should be maintained to avoid non-specific amplification.

 

Step 3- Elongation

  • The enzyme used is thermostable Taq (Thermus Aquaticus) DNA polymerase.
  • DNA polymerase elongates new strands in 5’3’ direction and the optimal temperature required for elongation is 72°C.
  • If PCR goes through ‘n’ number of cycles, then ‘2n’ number of products are formed.

questions.text: For medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), the opinion of two doctors is required at which gestational age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 20-24 weeks

Explanation:

According to the MTP Act, medical termination of pregnancy between 20-24 weeks of gestation requires the opinion of two registered medical practitioners.

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act:

  • The original act was passed in 1971 and amended in 2021.
  • Indications:
    • Maternal Risk
    • Fetal Risk: Spina bifida, Down syndrome.
    • Eugenic Conditions: Risks to both mother and fetus.
    • Humanitarian Cause: Pregnancy resulting from rape.
    • Contraceptive Failure.
  • Qualifications:
    • MBBS, MD/DNB/DGO
    • MBBS who has trained in gynaecology for 6 months
    • MBBS who has performed 25 MTPs under supervision
    • ASHA and AYUSH cannot perform MTP.
  • Additions of 2021 amendment:
    • Abortions allowed up to 20-24 weeks.
    • <20 weeks - Single doctor’s decision; 20-24 weeks - 2 doctors. (Option A)
    • Extension of abortion rights to single, unmarried females.
    • Inclusion of marital rape under the MTP Act.
    • Abortions >24 weeks in cases of significant fetal anomalies with no gestational upper limit, are to be decided by a state medical board (gynecologist, pediatrician, radiologist).

 

Gestational Age

Abortive method

Up to 7 weeks

Medical Abortion. (99% success rate if done before 7 weeks)

 

Up to 9 weeks

Up to 10 weeks
  • Medical Abortion
  • Suction evacuation

Up to 12 weeks
  • Suction evacuation
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)

12-20 weeks

Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)

20-24 weeks
  • Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Prostaglandin Induction.

>24 weeks

Hysterotomy

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant presents with a history of non-bilious, non-projectile vomiting starting at 3 weeks of age. The infant's abdominal examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option B) Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

Explanation: A 6-week-old infant with non-bilious, non-projectile vomiting starting at 3 weeks and a normal abdominal exam most likely has Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). (Option B)

  • Pyloric stenosis would typically feature projectile vomiting and potentially a palpable mass. (Option A ruled out)
  • Cow Milk Protein Allergy often presents with other symptoms like stool changes or rash. (Option C ruled out)
  • Intestinal obstruction would likely cause abdominal distension or bilious vomiting. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 65-year-old known case of Parkinson's disease presents with oropharyngeal dysphagia and recurrent episodes of aspiration pneumonitis, complaints of excessive respiratory secretions. Chest imaging reveals bilateral bronchiectasis. What is the most appropriate long-term management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C. PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) tube

Explanation:

  • In Parkinson's disease, oropharyngeal dysphagia is common due to impaired coordination of swallowing muscles. This leads to aspiration of food, liquids, and saliva, resulting in recurrent pneumonitis and long-term complications like bronchiectasis.
  • PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) tube helps bypass the oropharyngeal route for nutrition, reducing the risk of aspiration pneumonia and supporting nutritional status. It serves as a long-term management strategy that directly addresses the underlying cause—oropharyngeal dysfunction and aspiration.

Incorrect Options:

High-frequency chest wall oscillation therapy (Option A) is useful in conditions like cystic fibrosis or bronchiectasis to help clear mucus, but it does not address aspiration or dysphagia, which are the primary issues in this patient.

Nebulized N-acetylcysteine (NAC) (Option B) may help thin mucus, but it can irritate the airways and potentially increase secretions, without addressing the core problem of aspiration.

Macrolide therapy (Option D) can be used in non-CF bronchiectasis for its anti-inflammatory effects; however, it targets only secondary inflammation and not the primary issue of aspiration.

questions.text: A patient presents with ascites and omental caking. Imaging reveals solid components in an adnexal mass, and there is a long-standing history of symptoms. CA-125 is positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Serous ovarian tumor

Explanation:

  • The presence of ascites, omental caking, a solid adnexal mass, elevated CA-125, and chronic vague symptoms strongly points to serous ovarian tumor.

Types of Epithelial Ovarian Tumor:

Type of Epithelial Ovarian Tumor

Characteristics

Clinical Presentation

Serous Tumors

 

Serous Cystadenoma: Benign, unilateral, cystic spaces with serous epithelium.

Large cystic mass, unilateral.

 

Serous Cystadenocarcinoma: Malignant, often bilateral, cystic and solid components.

Bilateral involvement in 30%, elevated CA-125.

Mucinous Tumors

Mucinous Cystadenoma: Benign, unilateral, filled with mucinous fluid.

Large, unilateral mass.

 

Mucinous Cystadenocarcinoma: Malignant, unilateral, mucinous epithelial lining.

May rupture and spread to the peritoneum.

Endometrioid Tumors (Option C ruled out)

Endometrioid Carcinoma: Arises from endometrial-like tissue, solid and cystic.

Solid and cystic components, associated with endometriosis.

Clear Cell Tumors

Clear Cell Carcinoma: Clear cytoplasm due to glycogen accumulation.

Advanced stage, associated with endometriosis.

Brenner Tumors (Transitional Cell)

Brenner Tumor: Transitional epithelial cells resembling urinary tract epithelium.

Rare, usually benign.

Mucinous ovarian tumor (Option B) typically presents as a large, unilateral, multiloculated cystic mass and is less commonly associated with peritoneal spread or omental caking. CA-125 elevation is not as prominent unless the disease is advanced, and it lacks the classic imaging and spread pattern seen in serous carcinoma.

Granulosa cell tumors (Option D) are sex cord-stromal tumors that secrete estrogen and often cause hormonal symptoms like abnormal uterine bleeding; they rarely cause ascites or omental caking, and CA-125 is typically not elevated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker presents with complaints of dyspnea. Pulmonary function tests reveal an FEV1/FVC ratio of 65% and an RV/TLC ratio of 141%. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology?

choices.text: Air trapping with hyperinflation of lungs

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Air trapping with hyperinflation of lungs

Explanation:

  • Given the history of chronic smoking, symptoms of dyspnea and Obstructive pattern on PFTs, this presentation is most consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), especially emphysema, which is characterized by destruction of alveolar walls, air trapping, and lung hyperinflation.
  • Smoking leads to inflammation and destruction of elastic fibers in the lungs, resulting in reduced airway recoil, premature airway closure, and gas trapping, which are hallmarks of emphysema.

Pathogenesis of COPD

Risk Factors

  • Cigarette Smoking: Primary risk, correlates with amount and duration.
  • Environmental Factors:
    • Indoor air pollution (e.g., biomass fuel use in confined spaces).
    • Occupational exposures (e.g., coal dust, silica, cadmium).
  • Developmental Factors:
    • Low birth weight and impaired lung growth from infections or maternal smoking.
  • Infections:
    • Recurrent infections accelerate lung decline.
    • Persistent adenovirus may alter inflammatory responses, leading to damage.
  • Genetic Factors:
    • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. (Option B ruled out)
    • Airway hyper-reactivity.

Components of COPD

Pulmonary Components

Description

Mucus hypersecretion

Enlargement of mucus glands and goblet cells → chronic bronchitis (cough + sputum for ≥3 months/year).

Emphysema

Alveolar destruction by proteases and oxidants → permanent enlargement of distal airspaces.

Airflow Limitation

Loss of elastic tissue + inflammation → premature airway closure, gas trapping, and hyperinflation.

This is the primary mechanism for the airflow limitation.

Pulmonary vascular remodeling

Structural changes in pulmonary vessels.eventually causing PAH.

 

Systemic Components

Description

Weight Loss

Altered fat metabolism.

Skeletal Muscle Dysfunction

Muscle impairment reduces physical capacity.

Peripheral Edema

Impaired kidney function → salt and water retention.

Osteoporosis

Decreased bone density.

Increased Inflammatory Markers

Elevated systemic inflammation contributes to complications.

Incorrect Options:

Decreased lung compliance (Option B): Seen in restrictive lung diseases (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis). COPD/emphysema features increased, not decreased, compliance due to alveolar wall destruction.

Restrictive lung disease (Option C): Would show normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio and decreased lung volumes, not increased RV/TLC.

Increased lung compliance (Option D): True for emphysema, but A (air trapping with hyperinflation) better encapsulates the specific pathophysiologic hallmark presented in this question.

questions.text: Which of the following best defines blindness ?

choices.text: Visual acuity less than 6/60 in the better eye
Visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye after best possible correction
Visual field less than 10 degrees from fixation in the better eye
Inability to perceive light in both eyes

questions.solution:
Correct Option B -Visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye after best possible correction

Visual acuity less than 6/60 in the better eye (Option A ruled out): This level of visual acuity (or 20/200 in feet) is often referred to as legal blindness in many countries, including the United States, and is a criterion for eligibility for certain services. However, the international definition of blindness is typically more severe.
 

Visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye after best possible correction (Option B): This is the definition of blindness according to the World Health Organization (WHO) and is widely adopted for international comparison. 3/60 means a person can see at 3 meters what a person with normal vision can see at 60 meters. This is the best definition of blindness among the choices.
 

Visual field less than 10 degrees from fixation in the better eye (Option C ruled out): A restricted visual field can also define blindness, particularly "tunnel vision." The WHO definition of blindness includes "or corresponding visual field loss," which for blindness is typically a visual field of 10 degrees or less from fixation in the better eye. This is also a valid criterion for blindness.
 

Inability to perceive light in both eyes(Option C ruled out): This is known as "No Light Perception" (NLP) and represents total blindness. While this is indeed a form of blindness, it is the most severe form. The general definition of "blindness" encompasses a broader range of severe visual impairment where some light perception or very limited vision might still be present.

questions.text: Which of the following is one of the earliest presenting symptoms in a patient with Multiple Sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A. Sensory disturbances

Explanation:

  • Sensory disturbances such as paresthesias (tingling, “pins and needles”), hypesthesia (numbness), and dysesthetic sensations (e.g., burning, swelling, tight wrapping) are among the most common and earliest symptoms in MS.
  • They reflect demyelination in the sensory pathways and can appear abruptly or insidiously.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) Clinical features:

  • Abrupt or insidious onset of symptoms

Sensory symptoms
  • Paresthesias: tingling, prickling sensations, “pins and needles,” or painful burning.
  • Hypesthesia: reduced sensation, numbness, or a “dead” feeling.
  • Unpleasant sensations: feelings that body parts are swollen, wet, raw, or tightly wrapped.
  • Pain is a common symptom of MS.

Optic neuritis (ON) (Option C ruled out)
  • Diminished visual acuity.
  • Decreased colour perception in the central field of vision.
  • May progress to severe visual loss.
  • Periorbital pain.
  • Fundoscopic examination: normal or optic disc swelling (papillitis), pallor of the optic disc (optic atrophy).

Weakness of the limbs
  • Loss of strength, speed, dexterity, and gait disturbance.
  • Exercise-induced weakness is a characteristic symptom of MS.
  • Upper motor neuron type weakness accompanied by other pyramidal signs.

Facial weakness
  • Lesion in the pons may resemble idiopathic Bell’s palsy.

Spasticity
  • Spontaneous and movement-induced muscle spasms.
  • Painful spasms.

Visual blurring
  • Due to ON (optic neuritis) or diplopia.
  • Diplopia is caused by internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) or palsy of the sixth cranial nerve. (Option D ruled out)
  • Bilateral INO is particularly suggestive of MS.
  • Other gaze disturbances in MS:
    • Horizontal gaze palsy
    • One-and-a-half syndrome (horizontal gaze palsy plus an INO)
    • Acquired pendular nystagmus

Ataxia
  • Cerebellar tremors.
  • Cerebellar dysarthria.

Vertigo
  • Lesion in the brainstem.

 

Ancillary symptoms

Paroxysmal symptoms

Brief duration (10s to 2 min), high frequency (5–40 episodes per day), no change of consciousness or change in background electroencephalogram during episodes, and a self-limited course.

Lhermitte’s symptom (Option A ruled out)

An electric shock-like sensation that radiates down the back into the legs.

Typically induced by flexion or other movements of the neck.

Trigeminal neuralgia, hemifacial spasm, and glossopharyngeal neuralgia

Demyelinating lesions involve the root entry or exit zone of the fifth, seventh, and ninth cranial nerve, respectively.

Facial myokymia

Persistent rapid flickering contractions of the facial musculature

Slow spread of contraction across the face.

Heat sensitivity

Uthoff symptoms: Neurological symptoms develop from heat exposure, such as steam baths and saunas.

Bladder dysfunction

Present in >90% of MS patients.

Detrusor hyperreflexia.

Detrusor sphincter dyssynergia - hesitancy, urinary retention, overflow incontinence, and recurrent infection.

Bowel dysfunction

Constipation, faecal urgency or bowel incontinence.

Cognitive dysfunction

Memory loss.

Impaired attention.

Psychiatric symptom

Depression.

Fatigue

90% of patients experience fatigue.

It causes work-related disability.

Incorrect Options:

Ataxia (Option B): Usually appears later due to cerebellar involvement, not a common early symptom.

Vertigo (Option C): Caused by brainstem lesions, but not an early presenting symptom in MS.
Facial palsy (Option D): Results from pontine lesions, but is rare as an initial symptom.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with seizures was prescribed carbamazepine & erythromycin. A few days later, she developed ataxia. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Carbamazepine toxicity

Explanation:

Erythromycin inhibits CYP3A4, the enzyme that metabolizes Carbamazepine, leading to elevated carbamazepine levels and resulting in toxicity, with ataxia being a common symptom.

  • MOA: Inhibits high-frequency neuronal discharges and modulates voltage-gated sodium channels.
  • Uses:
    • Trigeminal neuralgia
    • GTCS (generalized tonic clonic seizures)
    • Partial seizures
    • Bipolar disorder.
  • Interactions:
    • Metabolism of carbamazepine is induced by phenobarbitone, phenytoin, and vice versa.
    • Erythromycin, fluoxetine, and isoniazid inhibit the metabolism of carbamazepine. (Option A)

Adverse Effects

Description

Neurotoxicity

Sedation, dizziness, vertigo, diplopia, and ataxia

Gastrointestinal Effects

Vomiting and diarrhoea occur with higher doses.

Acute Intoxication

Coma, convulsions, cardiovascular collapse.

Haematological

Agranulocytosis, aplastic anaemia.

Hypersensitivity Reactions

Rashes, photosensitivity, hepatitis, lupus-like syndrome.

Water Retention and Hyponatremia

Due to enhanced antidiuretic hormone (ADH) action, it is more common in the elderly.

Teratogenicity

Increased incidence of minor fetal malformations.

Incorrect Options:

Erythromycin toxicity (Option B) is not the cause, as it rarely causes ataxia. Its main role here is as a CYP3A4 inhibitor, which increases carbamazepine levels and leads to toxicity.

Worsening of the underlying disease (Option C) can cause ataxia, but the timing after starting erythromycin points to a drug interaction, making this less likely.

A separate, unrelated neurological condition (Option D) is unlikely, as the timing with carbamazepine and erythromycin use suggests a drug interaction rather than a new, unrelated diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best investigation for detecting ureteric calculi?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option A) NCCT

Explanation

  • NCCT (Option A) is the gold standard for stone detection due to its high accuracy. It finds all stone types, including those not visible on X-ray, and gives crucial details like size, location, and signs of obstruction. It's fast and widely available.

Incorrect Options:

Ureteroscopy (Option B ruled out) offers direct visualization, it's an invasive procedure, typically used for treatment, not initial diagnosis.

X-ray (KUB) (Option C ruled out) is limited; it only shows radiopaque stones, often misses others, and can be obscured by bowel contents. It's mainly for monitoring known stones.

CT scan (Option D ruled out) as a general term implies NCCT for stone detection, as contrast is usually avoided.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia says, "Hanuman ji is celibate. I am also celibate, so I am Hanuman." This statement is an example of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Autistic behaviour

Explanation:

  • The given statement is a example of Austictic behaviour, as it is a illogical thinking, based entirely on the patient's inner mental world, disconnected from external logic or reality
  • This is common in schizophrenia, where patients may draw bizarre and illogical conclusions that make sense only to them.
  • According to Eugen Bleuler, the diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia include (4 ‘A’s):
    • Affect (emotional expression) disturbances : Patients often exhibit diminished emotional expression, which can be observed through a lack of facial expressions and emotional responsiveness.
    • Association (thought processes) disturbances: refers to disorganised thinking, where patients may form unusual or illogical connections in their thoughts, such as catastrophic beliefs about the world.
    • Autism (social withdrawal) refers to detachment from reality, evident in patients who may appear silent around others and frequently engage in self-directed conversation.
    • Ambivalence (mixed feelings): Patients experience conflicting emotions or attitudes, which can lead to indecisiveness and difficulty making choices.

Incorrect Options:

Neologism (Option A) is creation of entirely new, made-up words or ordinary words used in a new way, are often linked to schizophrenia.

  • Example: A patient says, "I need to go to the flibberflam store to get some boozleberries." These words are not real and have meaning only to the speaker.

Word salad (Option B) is incoherent, incomprehensible mixture of words and phrases, often seen in advanced schizophrenia.

﻿﻿﻿Loosening of association (Option D) involves shifting from one idea to another with weak connections, but here the thoughts are tightly focused on one theme.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrectly matched concerning basic statistical concepts?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mean and median - Dispersion:

Explanation:

Mean and median are Measures of Central Tendency, not dispersion

  • Most affected by outliers: Mean
  • The best measure of central tendency in skewed observations: Median
  • The least affected measure: Mode

Measures of Dispersion

Measures

Definition

Calculation

Standard deviation

Measures the variation or dispersion of a set of values around the mean.

σ = √(∑(x− x̄)2 /n)

Range

The difference between the highest and lowest values in a dataset.

Range = Maximum value - Minimum value

Mean deviation

Measures the average absolute deviation of data points from the mean.

Mean deviation = ∑ X - x̄ / n

Variance

Measures the average of the squared differences from the mean.

Variance = σ2

Standard error (Option A) provides a measure of the precision of sample estimates. A smaller SE indicates less variability in sample means, suggesting more precise estimates.

Standard error of the mean

Standard error of proportion

Quantifies the variability of sample means around the true population mean.

Measures how much sample proportions vary around the population proportion

SE mean = σ/√N

SE proportion = √(pq/N)

The ​​​​​​​Correlation Coefficient (Option B) measures the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables.

Moments (Option D) (especially the third moment) are used to measure skewness, which indicates the asymmetry of a distribution

questions.text: Which is the most common HPV serotype associated with cervical carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HPV types 16 and 18

Explanation:

  • HPV types 16 and 18 are the most common HPV serotypes associated with cervical carcinoma.

Human Papillomavirus (HPV):

  • HPV, a dsDNA virus, causes almost all cervical cancers.
  • HPV vaccine is against L1 capsid protein.
  • Viral replication is carried out by E1 and E2 protein
  • It primarily infects human squamous cells or metaplastic epithelial cells.
  • HPV has a epitheliotropic effect which leads to the formation of Koilocytes
  • Koilocytes are epithelial cells characterised by perinuclear haloes surrounding condensed nuclei and are commonly present in cervical intraepithelial neoplasia.
  • Clinically, HPV are divided into 2 types:
    • Low risk HPV (6 & 11) cause nearly all genital warts, laryngeal papillomas and are rarely oncogenic. (Option B ruled out)
    • High risk HPV (16 & 18) cause approximately 95% of cervical cancers. HPV 16 is the most oncogenic in high risk HPV types. (Option A)

Koilocytes in epithelium

Types of HPV

Cutaneous involvement

HPV 1, 2, 3 (low risk)
  • Filiform wart
  • Verruca Plantaris

HPV 5, 8 (high risk)
  • Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis

Mucosal involvement

HPV 6, 11 (low risk)
  • Condyloma Acuminatum
  • Recurrent laryngeal papillomas

HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 35 (high risk)
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with complaints of burning micturition. Prostatic examination was normal. Urinalysis shows >50 pus cells per high power field, but urine culture shows no growth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Sterile pyuria

Explanation:

  • Sterile pyuria is defined as the presence of >10 WBCs/mm³ or >3 WBCs/HPF in unspun urine, or a positive dipstick for leukocyte esterase/nitrites, without significant bacteriuria (i.e., <10⁵ CFU/mL on culture).
  • It is the presence of pus cells in urine without bacterial growth on culture. It can result from non-bacterial infections (e.g., tuberculosis), inflammatory conditions, or prior antibiotic use. A normal prostate exam and no bacterial growth despite significant pyuria support this diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Chronic bacterial prostatitis (Option A): Typically shows positive urine culture and may have prostatic tenderness.

Acute bacterial prostatitis (Option B): Presents with fever, painful prostate on DRE, and positive culture.

Granulomatous prostatitis (Option C): Rare, often associated with tuberculosis, would show prostatic abnormalities.

questions.text: A four-year-old child presents with difficulty in walking, a broad-based gait, and inability to perform heel-to-toe walking. The child was clingy towards his mother. On examination, the child is hyperreflexic and Babinski sign is positive. What could be the probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cerebral Palsy

Explanation:

The child’s chronic spasticity, hyperreflexia, and gait abnormalities align with Cerebral Palsy, a static motor disorder due to early brain injury. The absence of acute-onset or sensory deficits rules out GBS, ADEM, or spinal cord lesions.

  1. Motor Symptoms:
    • Difficulty walking, broad-based gait, and inability to perform heel-to-toe walking are classic signs of spastic diplegia, a common form of CP. Spastic diplegia primarily affects the lower limbs, leading to gait disturbances.
    • Hyperreflexia and a positive Babinski sign indicate upper motor neuron (UMN) involvement, which is characteristic of CP.
  2. Age and Development:
    • CP is a non-progressive disorder caused by early brain injury (prenatal, perinatal, or postnatal). Symptoms typically manifest in early childhood, as seen in this 4-year-old.
  3. Behavioral Observation:
    • The child being clingy may reflect associated behavioral or cognitive impairments, which are common in CP.

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) (Option A) GBS presents with areflexia and ascending paralysis, not hyperreflexia or spasticity. It is also acute-onset, unlike CP.

ADEM (Option C) ADEM is a post-infectious demyelinating disorder with acute-onset encephalopathy (e.g., seizures, mental status changes), not a chronic gait disorder.

Spinal cord lesion (Option D) While spinal cord lesions can cause UMN signs, they are typically acquired (e.g., trauma, tumor) and would not explain the chronic, non-progressive nature of CP.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs are used in the treatment of acute mania?


	Haloperidol
	Valproate
	Lithium
	Amitriptylline
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1,2, and 3

Explanation:

  • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). It is not used in mania; in fact, it can worsen mania by inducing mood elevation and rapid cycling.
  • It should be avoided in bipolar disorder, especially in the manic phase.
