  • Acute mania is a psychiatric emergency requiring rapid mood stabilization and behavioral control. When monotherapy is insufficient for managing acute mania, combination therapy is preferred, it involves drugs from the following main classes
    • Antipsychotics
    • Mood stabilizers
    • Benzodiazepines

Pharmacologic Treatment of Acute Mania

First line

Monotherapy: Lithium, divalproex, and atypical antipsychotics such as olanzapine, risperidone, quetiapine, aripiprazole, cariprazine, asenapine, paliperidone, iloperidone, ziprasidone.

Adjunctive therapy with lithium or divalproex:

Risperidone, quetiapine, olanzapine, aripiprazole, asenapine

Second line

Monotherapy: Carbamazepine, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), haloperidol.

Combination therapy: Lithium + divalproex

Third line

Monotherapy: Chlorpromazine, Clozapine, Tamoxifen

Combination therapy: lithium or divalproex + haloperidol, lithium + carbamazepine, adjunctive tamoxifen
  • Mood stabilizers:
    • Lithium: It remains a cornerstone in mood stabilization, with therapeutic levels ranging from 0.6 to 1.2 mEq/L. However, due to its side effects and the need for frequent monitoring, newer drugs are often preferred in acute settings.
    • Anticonvulsants:
      • Valproate (divalproex) is now more commonly used than lithium for acute mania.
      • Carbamazepine

questions.text: A patient presents with low back pain. Bone scan reveals the characteristic "Honda H" sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bilateral sacral insufficiency fracture

Explanation:

  • The “Honda H” sign on a Bone scan refers to a specific pattern of fracture lines seen in the sacrum, which is suggestive of Bilateral sacral insufficiency fractures.
  • Bilateral sacral insufficiency fractures typically occur in elderly patients or those with osteoporosis, chronic steroid use, or other metabolic bone diseases. It can also happen in patients with Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • These fractures are caused by normal or physiological stress on weakened bone.

Acute osteomyelitis (Option A) would typically show localized bone marrow edema with possible abscess formation but does not produce the “Honda H” sign.

Marrow edema (Option B) is a non-specific finding that can result from trauma, infection, or inflammation but lacks the specific fracture pattern of the “Honda H” sign.

Metastatic sacral lesion (Option D) usually appears as destructive or infiltrative lesions on MRI, not the bilateral linear fracture pattern of the “Honda H” sign.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with hepatosplenomegaly and cherry-red spots on the retina. The child exhibits a normal startle reflex but shows developmental regression. Based on these clinical features, which of the following enzymes is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option b) Sphingomyelinase

Explanation

  • Hexosaminidase A (Deficient in Tay-Sachs disease):(Option A ruled out)
    • Features: Cherry-red spot, developmental regression, exaggerated startle reflex (hyperacusis), progressive neurodegeneration, no hepatosplenomegaly.
    • Fit with case: The presence of hepatosplenomegaly and normal startle reflex rules out classic Tay-Sachs.
  • Sphingomyelinase (Deficient in Niemann-Pick disease Types A and B):(Option B)
    • Features: Hepatosplenomegaly, developmental regression (especially in Type A), cherry-red spots (in Type A), interstitial lung disease, foam cells in bone marrow. The startle reflex is typically normal or not exaggerated.
    • Fit with case: This aligns very well with all the described symptoms: hepatosplenomegaly, cherry-red spots, developmental regression, and a normal startle reflex. Niemann-Pick Type A is the severe neurovisceral form.
  • Glucocerebrosidase (Deficient in Gaucher disease):(Option C ruled out)
    • Features: Hepatosplenomegaly, bone crises, pancytopenia, varying neurological involvement (Type 2 has severe neurodegeneration, Type 1 is non-neuropathic, Type 3 has progressive neurological features). Cherry-red spots are rare or absent.
    • Fit with case: The presence of cherry-red spots makes Gaucher disease less likely.
  • Arylsulfatase A (Deficient in Metachromatic Leukodystrophy):(Option D ruled out)
    • Features: Progressive demyelination leading to neurological symptoms (ataxia, spasticity, regression), peripheral neuropathy. Hepatosplenomegaly and cherry-red spots are typically absent.
    • Fit with case: This does not fit the hepatosplenomegaly or cherry-red spot findings.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female diagnosed with septic shock presents with a blood pressure of 58/630 mmHg. After receiving 30 ml/kg of crystalloid fluid, her mean arterial pressure (MAP) remains 58 mmHg. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B. Start noradrenaline

Explanation:

  • Noradrenaline (norepinephrine) is the vasopressor of choice in septic shock due to its potent alpha-1 effects (vasoconstriction) and minimal beta effects, improving MAP without excessive tachycardia.

Septic Shock Management:

1. Source Control

  • Start broad-spectrum antibiotics within 1 hour.
    Remove infected/ necrotic tissue or devices if they are the source.

2. Shock Management (within 6 hours)

  • Fluids: Crystalloids (NS/albumin) up to 80 mL/kg.
  • Target: CVP 8–12 mmHg, MAP ≥65 mmHg, ScvO₂ ≥70%.
  • Use norepinephrine (warm shock) or epinephrine (cold shock) as first-line vasopressors if fluid therapy fails.
  • Dopamine is no longer preferred due to adverse hormonal effects.

3. Enhancing Host Response

  • Steroids if shock is vasopressor-refractory or cortisol is low.
  • Vasopressin can be added in refractory shock.

Drug of Choice in Shock:

  • Anaphylactic shock: Adrenaline.
  • Cardiogenic shock: Noradrenaline or dopamine.
  • Distributive shock: Noradrenaline or phenylephrine.
  • Hypovolemic shock: Crystalloids or fluids.
  • Secondary shock: Prazosin.
  • Shock with oliguria: Dopamine.
  • Hypoadrenal shock: Corticosteroids.
  • Septic shock: Broad-spectrum antibiotics, Noradrenaline.

Incorrect Options:

Start dopamine (Option A): Less preferred due to higher risk of arrhythmias and worse outcomes compared to noradrenaline.

Repeat crystalloid fluid (Option C): Already received appropriate volume; additional fluid may cause fluid overload without improving perfusion.

Start vasopressin (Option D): Vasopressin is used as an adjunct to noradrenaline in refractory cases, not as initial therapy.

questions.text: What is the minimum age at which a woman can give valid consent for Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 18 years

Explanation:

  • In India, the minimum age at which a woman can provide valid consent for a Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) is 18 years.
  • According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, 1971, a woman aged 18 years or older can consent to an abortion independently.
  • Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act: The original act was passed in 1971 and amended in 2021.
  • Indications:
    • Maternal Risk
    • Fetal Risk: Spina bifida, Down syndrome.
    • Eugenic Conditions: Risks to both mother and fetus.
    • Humanitarian Cause: Pregnancy resulting from rape.
    • Contraceptive Failure.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with severe headache, vomiting & photophobia. On examination, neck rigidity and Brudzinski's sign are positive. A CT scan of the brain shows hydrocephalus and no haemorrhage. CSF examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Subarachnoid Haemorrhage

Explanation:

  • SAH often presents with sudden severe headache, vomiting, photophobia, and meningeal signs. CT may miss early or small bleeds, and CSF can be normal if bleeding is minimal or delayed. Hydrocephalus suggests impaired CSF drainage due to subarachnoid blood.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH): Blood accumulation in the subarachnoid space.
  • Causes: Often due to aneurysm rupture (~85%) or trauma.
  • Non-traumatic SAH is most commonly caused by the rupture of a saccular aneurysm.
  • Clinical Impact: High mortality and morbidity; often presents with a sudden, severe headache (worst headache of life).
  • Complications: Seizures, vasospasm, hydrocephalus, and delayed cerebral ischemia (DCI).

Epidemiology:

  • Age/ Gender: Most of the SAH occurs between age of 40-60, mean rupture age 50-55 and slightly more prevalent in females.
  • Risk Factors: Smoking and history of ruptured aneurysms increase SAH risk.

Etiology:

  • Aneurysmal SAH (aSAH):
    • Risk Factors: Hypertension, smoking, family history, alcohol use, sympathomimetic drugs, and estrogen deficiency.
    • Rupture Risk: (Option D)
      • Age >60
      • Posterior circulation aneurysms
      • Atherosclerosis
      • Aneurysm size
        • Aneurysms <10 mm: ~0.1% annual rupture risk.
        • Aneurysms ≥10 mm: 0.5–1% annual rupture risk.
        • Giant aneurysms (>2.5 cm): ~6% rupture risk in first year.
      • Family history
      • Previous SAH
      • ADPKD
  • Nonaneurysmal SAH (NASAH):
    • Perimesencephalic NASAH: Localized blood in perimesencephalic cisterns, normal angiography, benign course.
    • Occult Aneurysm: Small aneurysms missed on initial angiography, detectable on repeat imaging.
    • Vascular Malformations: Includes arteriovenous malformations (AVM) and dural arteriovenous fistulae. Treated with surgery or endovascular interventions.
    • Intracranial Arterial Dissection: Diagnosed by angiography, causes severe bleeding, treated with surgery or endovascular methods.
    • Other Causes: Cocaine abuse, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, cerebral venous thrombosis, sickle cell disorders, moyamoya disease, cerebral vasculitis, bleeding disorders.

Pathophysiology:

  • Hemodynamic Stress: Central to intracranial aneurysm formation, especially at arterial bifurcations.
  • Aneurysm Rupture: Causes neurological damage through compression of adjacent brain tissue and ischemia from reduced blood flow.
    • Mechanisms: Hemodynamic stress and inflammation (matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-mediated degradation of extracellular matrix) weaken the arterial wall, promoting aneurysm formation and rupture.
    • Inflammatory Response: Macrophages and smooth muscle cells drive these degenerative processes.

Clinical features:

  • Sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache (hallmark)
  • Loss of consciousness: Increase in intracranial pressure.
    • It presses the reticular activating system.
    • Leads to the development of stupor and coma.
  • Worst headache of the life
  • Nuchal rigidity is due to blood but no fever.
  • Vomiting
  • Sentinel bleed: microbleeds from the berry Aneurysm

Investigations:

  • Non-contrast CT head: "Hyperdense" blood in the subarachnoid space ("SAH star")
  • Lumbar puncture: Xanthochromia (yellowish discoloration) of CSF after 12 hours
  • Cerebral angiography: Identifies aneurysms or AVMs
  • CT angiography or MR angiography: Non-invasive methods to detect vascular abnormalities

Incorrect Options:

Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) (Option A): Presents with triad: dementia, gait disturbance, urinary incontinence—not acute meningeal symptoms.

Bacterial Meningitis (Option B): Would show abnormal CSF: high protein, low glucose, and neutrophilic pleocytosis.

Viral Encephalitis (Option C): Presents with altered sensorium, seizures, and abnormal CSF (lymphocytic pleocytosis), not just headache and normal CSF.

questions.text: Which of the following features is characteristic of chronic mercury poisoning?

choices.text: Lead lines are visible on X-ray
Basophilic stippling of red blood cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) ﻿﻿﻿Mad hatter's (intentional) tremor

Explanation:

  • Chronic mercury poisoning, especially from inorganic or vaporized elemental mercury, particularly in industries like hat-making and glass-blowing leads to a classical neuropsychiatric condition known as “Mad Hatter tremor” or Hatter’s shake.
  • It features intention tremors that worsen during voluntary movements, starting in the hands and progressing to other body parts.

Chronic mercury poisoning

Specific features

Details

Minamata Disease

Organic (Methyl) Mercury exposure from shellfish in Japan

Erethism

Shyness, depression, anxiety, loss of confidence, suicidal thoughts

Danberry Tremor

Coarse tremors in hands, lips, tongue; slurred speech; early symptom is worsening handwriting

Hatter’s Shake

Affects mobility (walking, dressing)

Glass-Blower Shake

Similar to Hatter’s Shake; it appears later

Concussio Mercurialis

Most severe form; bed-ridden with no activity

Mercurialentis

Brown discoloration of anterior lens capsule; seen via slit lamp; Visual Acuity is Intact

Acrodynia (Pink Disease)

Puffy, painful hands/feet; pinkish color; pruritus, perspiration; skin peeling similar to Kawasaki disease

Hyperkeratosis and Mees' lines (Option A) are classic signs of chronic arsenic poisoning, not mercury poisoning. Mees' lines are transverse white bands across the nails caused by disruption in nail matrix keratinization. Hyperkeratosis, especially on the palms and soles, and "raindrop" hyperpigmentation on the skin, are hallmark features of long-term arsenic exposure

Lead lines are visible on X-ray (Option B) is a feature of chronic lead poisoning. "Lead lines" appear as dense metaphyseal bands at the ends of long bones on X-ray. It is caused by disrupted bone remodeling due to inhibition of osteoclastic activity by lead

﻿﻿﻿Basophilic stippling of red blood cells (Option D) is seen in lead poisoning. It refers to the presence of small blue granules in RBCs, representing aggregated ribosomes. It occurs due to inhibition of pyrimidine 5’-nucleotidase by lead. It is a classic hematologic finding in lead toxicity

questions.text: Ascent to high altitude causes ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Respiratory alkalosis

Explanation:

At high altitudes, hypoxia triggers hyperventilation, leading to enhanced CO₂ removal and results in respiratory alkalosis.

Changes during Acclimatization

Respiratory
  • At high altitudes, lower oxygen levels stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors, increasing pulmonary ventilation.
  • This leads to enhanced CO2 removal, causing respiratory alkalosis.
  • Kidneys respond by excreting more bicarbonate to stabilize blood pH, causing a sustained increase in ventilation and supporting prolonged acclimatization.

Haematological
  • At high altitudes, lower PO2 boosts erythropoietin production, increasing red blood cell count.
  • This also raises 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) levels in red blood cells.
  • Initially, alkalosis shifts the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to the left but increased 2,3-DPG shifts it to the right, improving oxygen release to tissues.

Cardiovascular

  • Hypoxia activates the sympathoadrenal axis, increasing heart rate, cardiac output, and blood pressure.
  • Increased cardiac output leads to an increase in blood flow, and hypoxia causes vasodilation in the systemic circulation, further contributing to increased blood flow and oxygen supply to the tissues.

Tissue
  • In acclimatization, skeletal muscles undergo several changes, including an increase in the number of capillaries and mitochondria and an increase in myoglobin content.
  • Further, chemicals released from the hypoxic tissues stimulate angiogenesis.

 

Metabolic acidosis (Option A) involves decreased bicarbonate levels due to conditions like diarrhea or renal failure, not high altitude.

 

Metabolic alkalosis (Option B) can occur later as a compensatory renal response to respiratory alkalosis but is not the initial effect.

 

Respiratory acidosis (Option C) results from hypoventilation and CO₂ retention.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with pain and swelling around his right knee. There is no history of trauma. On examination, there is localised tenderness over the distal femur. X-ray reveals sclerotic changes in the metaphyseal region, with features such as sequestrum and involucrum. Laboratory investigations show mild leukocytosis and elevated ESR. Which of the following is the least expected causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Klebsiella pneumoniae

Explanation:

  • The presentation and imaging findings suggest chronic bacterial osteomyelitis of the metaphyseal region of the distal femur, which is common in children due to hematogenous spread of infection.
  • Klebsiella pneumoniae is rarely a cause of chronic osteomyelitis in healthy pediatric patients.
  • It more commonly causes infections in hospitalized, immunocompromised, or adult patients with underlying conditions.
  • Chronic Osteomyelitis:
    • According to Waldvogel's classification, it is an osteomyelitis persisting for more than 4 weeks.
    • Most common cause - Staphylococcus aureus (Same in both acute and subacute osteomyelitis)
    • In foreign body implants - Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common
  • Streptococcus pyogenes can cause both acute and chronic osteomyelitis. (Option A)
  • Escherichia coli & Mycobacterium tuberculosis also cause chronic osteomyelitis but not as commonly as Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. (Option B & C)

questions.text: A middle-aged lady choked while eating fish and has associated symptoms of coughing, hoarseness of voice, and a foreign body sensation in the throat. On examination, the pyriform fossa is found to be inflamed. Which of the following nerves supplies this region?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Internal Laryngeal Nerve (ILN)

  • Pyriform fossa sensation: The pyriform fossa (or piriform sinus) is a depression on each side of the laryngeal inlet. It is exquisitely sensitive to foreign bodies and is innervated by the internal laryngeal nerve

Explanation:

  • Internal Laryngeal Nerve (ILN) (Option A): The internal laryngeal nerve is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (which in turn is a branch of the vagus nerve). It is responsible for sensory innervation above the vocal cords, including the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and the pyriform fossa.
  • External Laryngeal Nerve (ELN) (Option B ruled out): The external laryngeal nerve is primarily motor, supplying the cricothyroid muscle (which tenses the vocal cords). It has very little sensory function, and not to the pyriform fossa.
  • Glossopharyngeal Nerve (Option C ruled out): The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) provides sensory innervation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, tonsils, and part of the pharynx, but not directly to the pyriform fossa.
  • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (Option D ruled out): The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is primarily motor to most intrinsic laryngeal muscles (except the cricothyroid) and provides sensory innervation below the vocal cords. It does not supply the pyriform

questions.text: IGF-1 and IGF-2 (Insulin-like Growth Factors) are structurally most similar to which of the following molecules?
questions.solution:
Correct answers- Option A) Insulin

 

Insulin-like Growth Factors (IGF-1 and IGF-2) are structurally most similar to Insulin (Option A)

Explanation: All three molecules share a similar protein fold and have significant sequence homology, meaning they share a large portion of their amino acid sequence.

Why other options are incorrect:

 

Proinsulin (Option B ruled out)
While proinsulin is the precursor to insulin, it is structurally closer to the mature insulin molecule than to IGFs. Proinsulin contains the A, B, and C peptides, which are all eventually cleaved to form mature insulin. IGFs, on the other hand, are single-chain proteins and do not undergo the same processing.

 

C peptide (Option C ruled out)
The C peptide is a part of proinsulin that is cleaved off during the maturation process to form insulin. Since IGFs are structurally different from proinsulin, they also have no structural similarity to the C peptide.

 

Preproinsulin (Option D ruled out)
Preproinsulin is the precursor to proinsulin, containing a signal peptide in addition to the A, B, and C peptides. While IGFs share structural similarities with insulin, they are not precursors to it and thus not structurally most similar to preproinsulin

questions.text:
Which of the following antimalarial drugs are commonly used in clinical treatment?

a. Artemisinin

b. Sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine

c. Chloroquine

d. Primaquine
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) a, b, c

Explanation: Primaquine is not effective for clinical cure but is the drug of choice for achieving radical cure in Malaria.

Clinical Cure

Radical Cure

Erythrocytic schizonts are killed to prevent an episode of malarial fever.

Hypnozoites(dormant stage) are killed to prevent relapse of malarial fever.

Seen in all plasmodium species

Seen in P. Ovale and P. Vivax

All drugs are effective except primaquine (Option d ruled out)

DOC: Primaquine and Tafenoquine

questions.text: Identify the procedure given below in the image?

choices.text: Transposition flap is used for scar revision

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Transposition flap used for scar revision

Explanation:

  • The given image is that of Z-plasty, a surgical technique used to realign scars with natural skin folds or relaxed tension lines and to lengthen contracted scars.
  • It involves creating two triangular flaps of equal size, which are then transposed to redirect and release the scar.
  • Z-plasty is a type of random flap used for grafting purposes, and the other type of random flap is V-Y plasty.

Split-thickness skin grafting (Option B) is a surgical technique used to repair skin defects by transferring a thin layer of skin from a donor site to the recipient site. The graft includes the epidermis and a variable thickness of the underlying dermis. It is not a random flap technique.

Repositioning flap without transposition (Option C) involves moving a flap directly forward to cover a defect, without rotating or pivoting it across adjacent tissue, but Z-plasty requires transposition.

Tissue transplantation (Option D) is a procedure that involves replacing damaged or missing tissues or organs with healthy ones from a donor. The types of grafts used can be an Autograft, Allograft, Xenograft or Isograft.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and presents with nephrotic-range proteinuria. Renal biopsy reveals "wire loop lesions. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option B) IV Steroids + cyclophosphamide

  • IV Steroids + cyclophosphamide: This is a standard and effective induction regimen for severe lupus nephritis.

Explanation:

  • IV Steroids only: This is generally insufficient for active, proliferative lupus nephritis like Class IV, especially with nephrotic-range proteinuria.(Option A ruled out)
  • Mycophenolate mofetil: While MMF is a valid option for induction, it's usually given in combination with steroids, not as monotherapy for initial severe cases. The option doesn't specify "IV steroids + MMF." (Option C ruled out)
  • Cyclophosphamide only: This is also not typically used as monotherapy for induction; it's combined with steroids. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Tight junctions are primarily located at which part of the cell?
questions.solution:
Correct answers- a) Apical

Tight Junctions (Zonula Occludens):

  • Structure: Sealing strands of transmembrane adhesion proteins (Occludin, Claudins, JAMs) that directly join to occlude intercellular space.
  • Location: Primarily at the apical (Option A) margins of epithelial and endothelial cells, forming a continuous belt. NOT in connective tissue.
  • Function:
    • Limit/regulate permeability of epithelial cells to ions and solutes (prevent leakage via paracellular pathway).
    • Essential for endothelial barrier function and vasodilation.
    • Contribute to cell polarity by limiting protein movement within the membrane.
  • Permeability: While primarily seals, they can permit selective passage of some ions/small molecules via controlled paracellular channels, not free passage.

questions.text: In a village of 100 children, 10 children have a past history of measles (i.e, they are not at risk now), 20 new cases of measles were reported this year. What is the incidence of measles in this population for the year?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 22.22%

Explanation:

In the above scenario,

Total population: 100 (10 children have a past history of measles)

Population at risk: 100-10 = 90

Number of new cases: 20

Incidence = (No. of new cases of specific disease during a given time period / Population at risk during that period) × 1000

Incidence: = (20 / 90) × 1000 = 222.222 per 1000 population

Percentage will be: 22.22%

Uses of incidence rates:

  • Identifying and monitoring disease trends over time
  • Evaluating the effectiveness of public health interventions
  • Helps to determine the efficacy of primary prevention of the disease
  • Used as a health status indicator.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man complains of early morning vomiting that occurs after turning in bed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)

Explanation:

Option A: BPPV is a common inner ear problem causing brief, intense episodes of vertigo (a spinning sensation). These episodes are specifically triggered by changes in head position, like:

  • Rolling over in bed
  • Getting out of bed
  • Looking up or down

The symptoms often include significant nausea and vomiting, especially with severe episodes. The patient's complaint perfectly matches the classic presentation of BPPV, where dislodged crystals in the inner ear shift with movement after settling overnight.

Incorrect Options:

Meniere's disease (Option B ruled out): While it causes vertigo, episodes are typically longer (hours) and also involve fluctuating hearing loss and ringing in the ears (tinnitus). It's not primarily triggered by specific head movements.

Vestibular neuritis (Option C ruled out): This causes a sudden, severe, and sustained episode of vertigo lasting days, without hearing loss. It's a single, prolonged event, not position-triggered episodes.

Labyrinthitis (Option D ruled out): Similar to vestibular neuritis, but also includes hearing loss. The vertigo is typically sustained, not triggered by specific positions.

questions.text: Name the graph and mention its application.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Plasma resonance, Ab affinity

Explanation:

The given graph is Plasma resonance or Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR), which is used to determine the determine the strength (affinity) and speed (kinetics) of antibody-antigen interactions.

 

ELISA (Option A, B) for antibody concentration typically produces a standard curve with a sigmoidal shape, plotting absorbance against antibody concentration. This method uses colorimetric detection to quantify the amount of antibody or antigen present in a sample, making it a reliable and widely used tool in diagnostics and research

questions.text: Which of the following techniques are correctly matched with their uses:

choices.text: Southern blot - RNA Identification, Northern blot - DNA Identification, Western blot - Protein Identification
Southern blot - DNA Identification, Northern blot - Protein Identification, Western blot - RNA Identification
Southern blot - Protein Identification, Northern blot - RNA Identification, Western blot - DNA Identification
Southern blot - DNA Identification, Northern blot - RNA Identification, Western blot - Protein Identification

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Southern blot - DNA Identification, Northern blot - RNA Identification, Western blot - Protein Identification

Explanation:

Correct match is Southern blot - DNA Identification, Northern blot - RNA Identification, Western blot - Protein Identification.

 

Types of blotting:

Types

Target

Features

Southern blotting

 

DNA sequences

It involves separating DNA fragments by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using labelled probes to identify specific sequences

Northern blotting

 

RNA sequences

The process is similar to DNA blotting but focuses on RNA.

Western blotting

 

Proteins

This technique specifically detects and analyses proteins in a complex mixture. It involves separating proteins by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using specific antibodies to detect the proteins.

Eastern blotting

 

Post-translational modifications

It refers to specialised Western blotting techniques that detect specific post-translational modifications of proteins, such as phosphorylation or glycosylation.

Southwestern blotting

DNA-binding proteins

Combines Southern and Western blotting elements to identify proteins that bind to specific DNA sequences.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects (NTDs)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Valproate

Explanation:

Of the options provided, Valproate is the drug most strongly linked to neural tube defects (NTDs).

  • Adverse effects of Valproate:
    • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, and indigestion.
    • Neurological: Tremor, sedation, dizziness, and ataxia.
    • Hepatic: Hepatotoxicity (mainly in children <2 years of age).
    • Hematologic: Thrombocytopenia and other blood dyscrasias.
    • Metabolic: Weight gain, hyperammonemia, and pancreatitis.
    • Teratogenicity: Risk of congenital malformations, such as neural tube defects (spina bifida oculta), if used during pregnancy.
    • Others: Hair loss (alopecia) and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

 

  • Drugs and their associated malformations:

Drug

Associated malformation

Valproate (Option A)

 
  • Neural tube defects
  • Cardiac defects
  • Cleft lip
  • Cleft palate
  • Developmental delay
  • ADHD

Phenytoin

(Option D ruled out)
  • Fetal Hydantoin syndrome
    • craniofacial anomalies
    • fingernail hypoplasia
    • developmental delay
    • cardiac anomalies

Phenobarbital
  • Cleft lip and palate
  • Cardiac anomalies
  • UT malformations

Levetiracetam
  • Skeletal abnormalities

Lamotrigine
  • Cleft lip/palate

Topiramate
  • Cleft lip/palate

Carbamazepine (Option B) is an antiepileptic drug that poses some risk of neural tube defects, but this risk is lower than that of valproate. Although teratogenic, its link to NTDs is weaker, making it a less likely correct choice.

Lithium (Option C), used mainly for bipolar disorder, is not an antiepileptic drug. Its main teratogenic risk is cardiac defects like Ebstein’s anomaly, with no significant link to neural tube defects, making it an incorrect choice here

questions.text:
During the Maha Kumbh Mela, mobile health units and medical bases were set up, along with multiple surveillance units for monitoring cases of fever, diarrhea, and respiratory illnesses.

What was the primary purpose of setting up these surveillance units?

choices.text: To reduce the need for medical professionals
For early diagnosis and detection of potential outbreak warning signs
For immediate quarantine of all symptomatic individuals

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - For early diagnosis and detection of potential outbreak warning signs

Explanation:

Surveillance units track illnesses like fever, diarrhea, and respiratory infections to enable early diagnosis and detect potential outbreak warning signs, helping to prevent widespread transmission.

  • It is the systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health data to plan, implement, and evaluate public health practice. (Option B)
  • Types:
    • Active surveillance: Involves proactive data collection with efforts to find cases.
    • Passive surveillance: Relies on routine reporting from healthcare providers or institutions.
    • Sentinel surveillance: Monitors specific sentinel sites or groups for early detection of trends.

Incorrect Options:

To reduce the need for medical professionals (Option A): Surveillance units support, not replace, medical professionals. They rely on trained staff to monitor and respond to health risks.

For immediate quarantine of all symptomatic individuals (Option C): Quarantine is based on confirmed risk, not just symptoms. Surveillance identifies potential outbreaks, but not all symptomatic people need isolation.

To provide curative treatment only (Option D): Surveillance focuses on monitoring and early detection. Treatment is provided by medical units, while surveillance aims to prevent outbreaks.

questions.text: All of the following muscles are supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Flexor carpi ulnaris

Explanation:

The flexor carpi ulnaris (FCU) muscle is innervated by the muscular branches ulnar nerve.

The deep branch of the ulnar nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the majority of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. These include:

  • Hypothenar muscles: These are the muscles that form the fleshy prominence on the medial side of the palm (at the base of the little finger). They include:
    • Abductor digiti minimi (Option C)
    • Flexor digiti minimi brevis
    • Opponens digiti minimi
  • Lumbricals (medial two): Specifically, the 3rd and 4th lumbricals (Option A) (which act on the ring and little fingers). The lateral two lumbricals are supplied by the median nerve.
  • Interossei muscles: Both the:(Option B)
    • Dorsal interossei (four muscles that abduct the fingers)
    • Palmar interossei (three muscles that adduct the fingers)
  • Adductor pollicis: This powerful muscle is responsible for adduction of the thumb.
  • Flexor pollicis brevis (deep head): While the superficial head of the flexor pollicis brevis is supplied by the median nerve, the deep head typically receives innervation from the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: Arrange the steps for the pap smear.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lithotomy, per speculum (PS), sample

Explanation:

The steps for performing a Pap Smear are as follows:

  • Position the patient in the lithotomy position
  • Perform a per speculum (PS) examination
  • Collect the cervical sample

Site
  • Transformation zone of the cervix, where the squamous epithelium (ectocervix) and columnar epithelium (endocervix) meet.
  • This is the most common site for cervical cancer to develop.

Instruments
  • Ayre spatula collects cells from the ectocervix
  • Cervical broom (also called a cytobrush) from transition zone
  • Endocervical brush from endocervix

Procedure
  • Steps: (Option A)
    • The Pap smear should be obtained before vaginal examination.
      • The fingers may remove desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report
      • Lubricant may prevent detection of organisms
      • Vaginal bleeding during examination may preclude a proper visualization of the cervix.
    • The patient should not have intercourse or touch for 24 hours before test.
    • The patient is placed in the lithotomyl position, with the labia parted
    • Speculum is gently introduced without the use of lubricant or jelly.
    • The squamocolumnar junction is now scraped with Ayre's spatula by rotating the spatula all around.
  • Conventional Pap smear: Cells are collected with a spatula or brush, smeared onto a slide, and immediately fixed with a spray fixative or by immersing in 95% ethanol with/without ether
  • Liquid-based cytology: Cells are collected and then rinsed into a liquid fixative vial. This is considered more sensitive than the conventional Pap smear as it provides a more uniform distribution of cells.

Indications
  • Cervical cancer screening: Routine screening for women aged 21-65 years, with the frequency and type of testing varying based on age and risk factors.
  • Evaluation of abnormal vaginal bleeding: While not a primary diagnostic tool, a Pap smear is performed as part of the workup, along with other tests.

Timing & Frequency
  • Age 21-29: Cytology (Pap smear) every 3 years.
  • Age 30-65: Co-testing (Pap smear + HPV testing) every 5 years.
  • >65: No further screening if they have had 3 consecutive negative cytology results or 2 consecutive negative co-test results and no history of high-grade precancerous lesions.
  • H/o of CIN 2 or higher: Annual screening for 20 years.
  • More frequent screening in HIV and Immunocompromised patients.

C/I

Avoid during menstruation (Relative Contraindication).

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause fetal bradycardia during labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Maternal fever

Explanation:

Among the given options, maternal fever does not cause Fetal Bradycardia during labor.

Fetal heart rate (FHR)

  • Normal: 110-160 bpm

Bradycardia

(<110 bpm)

Tachycardia

(>160 bpm)
  • Congenital heart block (m/c) (Option D ruled out)
  • Prolonged cord compression
  • Cord prolapse
  • Tetanic uterine contractions
  • Paracervical block
  • Serious fetal compromise
  • Maternal fever (Option A)
  • Fetal hypoxia
  • Fetal anemia
  • Amnionitis

 

 

Acceleration

Deceleration

  • Temporary increases in FHR above the baseline.
  • Reactive NST:
    • At least two accelerations in a 20-minute period.
    • Each acceleration should be 15 bpm above the baseline and last for at least 15 seconds (for fetuses older than 32 weeks).
  • Non-Reactive NST: Fewer than two accelerations in a 20-minute period.
  • Indicates:
    • Healthy fetus with intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular function.

Temporary drops in FHR below the baseline.

  • Early Decelerations: Usually benign, occurring with uterine contractions.
    • Fetal head compression (Option B ruled out)
  • Variable Decelerations:
    • Umbilical cord compression
  • Late Decelerations:
    • Fetal hypoxia
    • Uteroplacental insufficiency (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Dura when inflamed under the part marked by the arrow gets referred pain at the following site:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Back of the head/neck

Explanation:

The arrow likely points to the posterior cranial fossa, specifically the tentorium cerebelli (a dural fold), as this area is clinically significant for referred pain.

  • The dura mater in the posterior cranial fossa (innervated by the meningeal branches of the upper cervical nerves, particularly C1-C3) refers pain to the occipital region (back of the head) and neck.
  • This is because the sensory innervation of the dura in this region shares spinal cord segments (C1-C3) with cutaneous nerves supplying the occiput and neck, leading to referred pain in these areas.

Referred pain sites:

Vertex (Option B) - Pain from supratentorial dura (innervated by the trigeminal nerve, V1-V3).

Ear (Option C) Middle cranial fossa dura (trigeminal or glossopharyngeal innervation).

Shoulder (Option D) Lower cervical dura (C4-C5), not typical for posterior fossa.

questions.text: Identify the condition associated with the image shown below:

choices.text: Transient edema of the sacroiliac joint

questions.solution:
Correct answer Option B) Sacral insufficiency fracture

Explanation

1. Plain Radiographs (X-rays):

  • Often Normal: Plain X-rays are notoriously insensitive for detecting acute sacral insufficiency fractures, especially in the early stages. The subtle nature of the fracture and overlying bowel gas can obscure them.
  • Subtle Sclerosis: In later stages or chronic cases, a vague vertical band of increased bone density (sclerosis) may be noted in the sacral ala (wing) parallel to the sacroiliac joint. This represents healing bone or callus formation.

2. Bone Scintigraphy (Nuclear Medicine Bone Scan):

  • Highly Sensitive: Bone scans (using technetium-99m methylene diphosphonate, 99mTc-MDP) are very sensitive for detecting SIFs, often showing uptake earlier than other modalities.
  • "H-Sign" or "Honda Sign": This is a classic and highly characteristic finding, though not present in all cases (occurs in 20-78% of cases). It refers to a pattern of increased radionuclide uptake resembling the letter "H".

3. Computed Tomography (CT Scan):

  • Better for Bony Detail: CT is superior to plain X-rays for visualizing subtle cortical breaks and fracture lines.
  • Fracture Line: A low-attenuation (dark) fracture line may be seen, often with surrounding ill-defined sclerosis representing callus formation.
  • Sclerosis: Broad regions of sclerosis adjacent to the fracture line can be present.

questions.text: Based on the X-ray image provided, determine the type of thyroid malignancy:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)Follicular carcinoma

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario is a case of follicular carcinoma, in which the most common site of metastasis is bone, and the route is hematogenous.
  • Lymphatic spread is not seen.

Papillary carcinoma, Hürthle cell carcinoma, Thyroid lymphoma (Options A,B,D) are less likely to be spread hematogenously to bone

Follicular carcinoma (Option C): This is well-established as having a propensity for hematogenous spread, with the lungs and bones being common sites for distant metastases. Bone metastases from follicular carcinoma are relatively frequent compared to other thyroid cancers.

Incorrect Options:

Hürthle cell carcinoma (Option B ruled out): Often considered a more aggressive variant of follicular carcinoma, Hürthle cell carcinoma also commonly spreads hematogenously to distant sites, including the lungs and bones. But less likely than follicular carcinoma.

Papillary carcinoma (Option A ruled out): While papillary carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer and often spreads via the lymphatic system to regional lymph nodes, hematogenous spread to distant sites like bone is less common compared to follicular or Hürthle cell carcinoma. However, it can occur, especially in aggressive subtypes.

Thyroid lymphoma (Option D ruled out): Thyroid lymphoma primarily involves the lymph nodes and can spread to other lymphatic tissues. While distant spread can occur, bone metastasis is not a typical or common route of spread for thyroid lymphoma compared to the other thyroid carcinoma types.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Bempedoic acid are correct?

a. It is a non-competitive inhibitor of ATP citrate lyase

b. It is used along with diet and statins for hypercholesterolemia

c. It is a dicarboxylic acid

d. It inhibits cholesterol biosynthesis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) b, c, d

Explanation:

Bempedoic Acid is a competitive inhibitor of ATP citrate lyase.

  • It is a dicarboxylic acid. (Statement c)
  • Class: Hypolipidemic drug - Cholesterol-lowering drugs.
  • MOA:
    • It is a prodrug, transforms into its active state (bempedoic acid-CoA), which competitively blocks ATP Citrate Lyase. (Statement a ruled out)
    • Diminishes the production of hepatic cholesterol synthesis by limiting the flow of acetyl-CoA to HMG-CoA reductase. (Statement d)
  • Use:
    • Adjunct to diet and maximally tolerated statin therapy to further lower LDL-C in patients with HeFH or established ASCVD. (Statement b)
      • Bempedoic acid + Ezetimibe
    • Statin-intolerant patients

questions.text: After a high-carbohydrate meal, weight gain is explained by all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mitochondrial carnitine

Explanation:

After a high-carbohydrate meal, excess glucose is converted into fatty acids and stored as fat, contributing to weight gain.

 

This process involves:

  • Malonyl CoA: An intermediate in fatty acid synthesis that inhibits fatty acid oxidation.
  • Tricarboxylate transporter: Transports citrate from mitochondria to cytosol, providing acetyl-CoA for fatty acid synthesis.
  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase: The key enzyme that converts acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA, initiating fatty acid synthesis.

 

Mitochondrial carnitine (Option D) transports fatty acids into mitochondria for β-oxidation (fat breakdown). After a high-carb meal, fat oxidation is inhibited, so mitochondrial carnitine doesn't contribute to weight gain.

questions.text:
Which of the following treatments are appropriate for scabies in infants?

a. 5% Permethrin cream

b. 10% Crotamitron

c. Ivermectin

d. 25% Benzyl benzoate lotion
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) a, b, d

Explanation:

  • Ivermectin is contraindicated in children under 5 years of age; however, all the other mentioned drugs can be safely used to treat scabies in infants.

Drugs for scabies 

Permethrin (1st line) (Option a)

A highly effective pyrethroid insecticide, with nearly 100% cure rates in scabies after a single application.

Lindane (2nd line)

A broad-spectrum insecticide, but less effective than permethrin and has a higher risk of systemic toxicity, particularly in children.

Benzyl Benzoate (2nd line) (Option d)

Minimally absorbed through the skin and has low systemic toxicity but can cause neurological symptoms in children.

Crotamiton (2nd line) (Option b)

Less prone to cause skin irritation and has low systemic toxicity but has produced lower cure rates in scabies.

Sulfur

The oldest scabicide but has several disadvantages, including messy application, unpleasant odour, and the need for repeated applications.

Dicophane (DDT)

Can be absorbed through the skin and cause systemic toxicity, rarely used due to potential side effects and safer alternatives.

Ivermectin

An oral medication that is highly effective in treating scabies.

Not to be given to children <5 yrs old, pregnant, or breastfeeding women. (Option c ruled out)

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for complicated gonorrhea caused by penicillin-resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ceftriaxone

Explanation:

  • Ceftriaxone is the first choice of drug for gonorrhoea caused by penicillinase-producing organisms.

Neisseria Gonorrhoeae:

Clinical Features

Men

Urethritis, purulent urethral discharge, dysuria, epididymitis, prostatitis.

Women

Cervicitis, vaginal discharge, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding.

Rarely can cause Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Pharyngeal Infection

Often asymptomatic, sore throat, pharyngitis.

Rectal Infection

Proctitis, rectal discharge, pain, and tenesmus, may be asymptomatic.

Disseminated Gonococcal Infection (DGI)

Fever, dermatitis, polyarthralgia, septic arthritis.

Neonates

Ophthalmia neonatorum, conjunctivitis, potential for blindness if untreated.

Diagnosis

Gram Stain

Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes (particularly useful in men).

Culture

Thayer-Martin or other selective media, oxidase-positive, and carbohydrate utilization tests.

NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test)

Highly sensitive and specific, recommended for urogenital, pharyngeal, and rectal specimens.

Serological Tests

Not commonly used due to lower sensitivity and specificity compared to NAAT and culture.

Treatment- Green STD kit

First-Line Therapy

Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM as a single dose PLUS doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (if chlamydial co-infection is not excluded). (Option A)

Alternative Therapy

Gentamicin 240 mg IM as a single dose PLUS azithromycin 2 g orally as a single dose (if ceftriaxone is not available).

Amoxicillin (Option B) is a beta-lactam antibiotic from the penicillin class. Once used for gonorrhea, it is now largely ineffective due to widespread resistance from penicillinase-producing N. gonorrhoeae strains. Cross-resistance with penicillin makes it an unreliable treatment option.

Tetracycline (Option C), once used for gonorrhea, is now ineffective due to widespread resistance in N. gonorrhoeae. Its reduced efficacy makes it unsuitable as monotherapy and it no longer meets current treatment standards.

Vancomycin (Option D) targets Gram-positive bacteria and cannot effectively penetrate the outer membrane of Gram-negative N. gonorrhoeae, making it ineffective and unsuitable for treating gonorrhea.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is incorrect?


	Cannabis can cause self-driven (repetitive) behaviour
	﻿﻿﻿Volatile inhalational agents are toxic to humans
	﻿﻿﻿Opioids are commonly used as analgesics
	﻿﻿﻿Alcohol acts as a stimulant at low doses and a depressant at high doses
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 4

﻿Explanation:

  • Statement 1 is incorrect as stereotyped or repetitive behaviours are generally associated with stimulant use (e.g., MDMA, cocaine), not cannabis.
  • Clinical Features of cannabis Intoxication:
    • Tachycardia
    • Conjunctival injection
    • Anxiety or euphoria
    • Slowness of time
    • Impaired cognition and motor coordination
    • Dry mouth
    • Increased appetite
    • Nystagmus
    • Postural hypotension
    • Delirium (especially at high doses)
  • Statement 4 is also incorrect as, pharmacologically, alcohol is always a CNS depressant, but clinically, at low doses, alcohol causes disinhibition, increased sociability, which can mimic stimulation.
  • But Alcohol does not act as a stimulant at low doses and a depressant at high doses
  • Volatile inhalants (e.g., toluene, paint thinners) are indeed toxic, causing: (Statement 2)
    • CNS damage
    • Cardiac arrhythmias
    • Liver/kidney damage
    • Sudden sniffing death
  • Opioids are widely used in both acute and chronic pain management. (Statement 3)

questions.text:
A histopathological image of an ovarian mass in a lady is shown below. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?




	Sex cord stromal tumor
	Call-Exner bodies are seen
	CA125 is high
	Inhibin is a marker
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2, 4

Explanation:

  • The ovarian tumor showing Call-Exner bodies on histopathology is most consistent with a Granulosa Cell Tumor, a type of Sex Cord-Stromal Tumors, for which inhibin serves as an important diagnostic marker.

Feature

Sertoli-Leydig tumour,

Pure Leydig tumour (or Hilus cell tumour)

Fibroma, Thecoma, Fibrothecoma

 

Granulosa Cell Tumor

 

 

Derived from

Sertoli or Leydig cells

Ovarian stroma

Granulosa cells of ovarian follicle

Age of Occurrence

Second and third decades

Any age

Postmenopausal (adult type), any age (juvenile type)

Associated symptoms

Abnormal sexual development or Virilization

Associated with Meigs syndrome and basal nevus syndrome

Precocious sexual development in juveniles or abnormal uterine bleeding, endometrial hyperplasia (carcinoma) in adults

Histological features

Reinke crystalloids (in pure Leydig cell tumours)

 

 

Well-differentiated fibroblasts (fibroma),
plump spindle cells with lipid droplets (thecomas)

Call-Exner bodies, Coffee bean nuclei

(Statement 2)

Mutations & Markers

Mutations in DICER1 (which encodes endonuclease)

Vimentin +,
Thecoma: Oil Red O +ve
Fibroma: Oil Red O -ve

Elevated inhibin levels, CD99+, and FOXL2 mutations (in adult cases)

(Statement 4)

 

Prognosis

Low recurrence or metastasis rate (<5%)

Benign; Rarely malignant (fibrosarcomas)

Potentially malignant with unpredictable behaviour;

10-year survival rate 85%

questions.text: Which of the following infections is most commonly transmitted during the third trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Toxoplasmosis:

Explanation:

Toxoplasmosis is one of the TORCH infections associated with Vertical Transmission during the third trimester of pregnancy.

  • It refers to the transplacental transmission of infectious agents from the mother to the fetus.
  • TORCH infections include toxoplasmosis, rubella, CMV, Herpes and HIV.

Trimester

Transmitted Diseases

1st trimester

Rubella, Chickenpox/varicella (Option A ruled out)

2nd trimester

Parvovirus (Option B ruled out)

3rd trimester

Toxoplasmosis, CMV, Hepatitis B and Syphilis. (Option C)

During delivery

HIV and herpes (Option D ruled out)

Other agents that are non-living can also be transferred vertically:

  • Thalidomide
  • Diethylstilbestrol

questions.text: Identify the part of the respiratory tract based on the image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct answer Option A) Respiratory bronchiole

Airway Region

Epithelium

Wall Components

Functions

Bronchi

Respiratory Epithelium

Hyaline cartilage plates, smooth muscle

Conduct air

Bronchioles

Simple cuboidal to columnar (cilia, club)

No cartilage, smooth muscle (first region without)

Conduct air; constrict/dilate

Terminal Bronchioles

Thinner smooth muscle

Conduct air; produce protective/surfactant-like secretions

Respiratory Bronchioles

Simple cuboidal (cilia, club), alveolar regions

(Option A)

Small smooth muscle bundles

Alveolar Ducts

questions.text: Which one of the following cranial nerves is not involved in olfaction ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypoglossal nerve

Explanation: Hypoglossal nerve is a purely a motor nerve supplying muscles of the tongue and has no sensory or olfactory role. It innervates all the tongue muscles (intrinsic and extrinsic) except for the palatoglossus, which receives motor innervation from the vagal nerve (CN X). The muscular/lingual branch is a general somatic efferent (GSE) which controls most tongue actions, including protruding, retracting, depressing the tongue, and changing the tongue’s shape.

Olfaction (sense of smell) is primarily carried by Cranial Nerve I (Olfactory Nerve).

However, cranial nerves V (Trigeminal) (Option D), VII (Facial), IX (Glossopharyngeal) (Option C), and X (Vagus) (Option B) are involved in detecting irritating or pungent odors, contributing to reflex responses like sneezing or coughing.

questions.text: A patient presents with ascites and omental caking. Imaging reveals solid components in an adnexal mass, and there is a long-standing history of symptoms. CA-125 is positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Serous ovarian tumor

Explanation:

  • The presence of ascites, omental caking, a solid adnexal mass, elevated CA-125, and chronic vague symptoms strongly points to serous ovarian tumor.

Types of Epithelial Ovarian Tumor:

Type of Epithelial Ovarian Tumor

Characteristics

Clinical Presentation

Serous Tumors

Serous Cystadenoma: Benign, unilateral, cystic spaces with serous epithelium.

Large cystic mass, unilateral.
 

Serous Cystadenocarcinoma: Malignant, often bilateral, cystic and solid components.

Bilateral involvement in 30%, elevated CA-125.

Mucinous Tumors

Mucinous Cystadenoma: Benign, unilateral, filled with mucinous fluid.

Large, unilateral mass.
 

Mucinous Cystadenocarcinoma: Malignant, unilateral, mucinous epithelial lining.

May rupture and spread to the peritoneum.

Endometrioid Tumors (Option C ruled out)

Endometrioid Carcinoma: Arises from endometrial-like tissue, solid and cystic.

Solid and cystic components, associated with endometriosis.

Clear Cell Tumors

Clear Cell Carcinoma: Clear cytoplasm due to glycogen accumulation.

Advanced stage, associated with endometriosis.

Brenner Tumors (Transitional Cell)

Brenner Tumor: Transitional epithelial cells resembling urinary tract epithelium.

Rare, usually benign.

Mucinous ovarian tumor (Option B) typically presents as a large, unilateral, multiloculated cystic mass and is less commonly associated with peritoneal spread or omental caking. CA-125 elevation is not as prominent unless the disease is advanced, and it lacks the classic imaging and spread pattern seen in serous carcinoma.

Granulosa cell tumors (Option D) are sex cord-stromal tumors that secrete estrogen and often cause hormonal symptoms like abnormal uterine bleeding; they rarely cause ascites or omental caking, and CA-125 is typically not elevated.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to concerns that the child cannot sit without support. The child is otherwise able to roll over, says "mama" and "dada", and demonstrates stranger anxiety. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassure the parents, as this is normal for the age
No further action needed at this time

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Refer for developmental assessment

Explanation: At 9 months, a child should be able to sit without support. Failure to do so indicates a possible gross motor delay. Since other milestones are on track, a developmental assessment is the most appropriate next step to evaluate and address any delays early.

Incorrect options:

  • Option B - Imaging is only done if neurological abnormalities are found on assessment.
  • Option C - Sitting unsupported should occur by 6–8 months, so this delay is not normal.
  • Option D - Delay in a key milestone like sitting warrants evaluation, not watchful waiting.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient undergoes colonoscopy for evaluation oc altered bowel habits. A 6cm colonic mass is identified and biopsied. Histopathology confirms adenocarcinoma that is confined to the mucosal layer, with no evidence of invasion into the submucosa or beyond. Imaging studies show no lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. Based on this information, what is the most appropriate TNM stage of this tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Stage 0

Explanation:

  • ​​This patient's colon cancer is confined to the mucosal layer (also known as carcinoma in situ) and does not invade the submucosa. According to the TNM (Tumor, Node, Metastasis) staging system, it is Stage 0.

TNM classification of colon cancer

T (Tumor)

Tis

Carcinoma in situ/tumor confined to mucosa

T1

Tumor invades the submucosa

T2

Tumor invades the muscularis propria

T3

Tumor invades through subserosa or into pericolorectal tissues

T4a

Tumors breaches visceral peritoneum

T4b

Tumor directly invades or is adherent to other organs or structures.

N (Lymph Node)

N1a

Metastasis in 1 regional lymph node.

N1b

Metastasis in 2-3 regional lymph nodes.

N1c

Tumor deposits in the subserosa, mesentery, or non-peritonealized pericolic or perirectal tissues without regional nodal metastasis.

N2a

Metastasis in 4-6 regional lymph nodes.

N2b

Metastasis in 7 or more regional lymph nodes.

M (Metastasis)

M1a

Metastasis confined to one organ or site

M1b

Metastasis to more than one organ/site or the peritoneum.

M1c

Metastasis to the peritoneum with or without other organ involvement.

 

Stage 0: Tis N0 M0

Stage 1: T1/T2 N0 M0 (Option A)

Stage IIA: T3 N0 M0 (Option B)

Stage IIB: T4a N0 M0 (Option C)

Stage IIC: T4a N0 M0

Stage IIIA: T1/T2 N1/N1c M0 or T3/T4 N2a M0

Stage IIIB: T3/T4a N1/N1c M0 or T2/T3 N2a M0 or T1-T2 N2b M0

Stage IIIC: T4a N2a M or T3/T4a N2b M0 or T4b N1/N2 M0

Stage IVA: anyT anyN M1a

Stage IVB: anyT anyN M1b

Stage IVC: anyT anyN M1c

questions.text: Cancer cells consume more glucose by which of the following process:

choices.text: Increased conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA
Increased lactate is produced even in the presence of oxygen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increased lactate is produced even in the presence of oxygen

 

Explanation:

Cancer cells exhibit a phenomenon known as the Warburg effect, where they consume more glucose and convert it to lactate even when oxygen is plentiful (aerobic glycolysis). This process allows cancer cells to generate energy and biosynthetic precursors rapidly to support their uncontrolled growth, despite the inefficiency of producing only 2 ATPs per glucose molecule compared to the 36-38 ATPs from oxidative phosphorylation in normal cells.

 

 

Increased GLUT-2 transporters, oxidative phosphorylation (Option A) - While increased glucose uptake via GLUT transporters is a feature of cancer cells, oxidative phosphorylation is reduced in cancer cells due to the Warburg effect. They rely more on glycolysis and lactate production rather than oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Increased conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA (Option B) - In normal cells, pyruvate is converted to Acetyl CoA for entry into the citric acid cycle under aerobic conditions. However, in cancer cells, pyruvate is preferentially converted to lactate due to the Warburg effect, not to Acetyl CoA.

 

Increased fatty acid oxidation (Option D) - Fatty acid oxidation is more characteristic of normal cells or certain cancer types under specific conditions, but it is not the primary process for increased glucose consumption in cancer cells.

questions.text: A patient presents after a fall on an outstretched hand. The X-ray is normal, but there is fullness in the anatomical snuff box. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: MRI to evaluate soft tissues and ligaments
Cast immobilization and follow-up with repeat imaging after 2 weeks
Bone scan for early fracture detection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cast immobilization and follow-up with repeat imaging after 2 weeks

Explanation:

  • In a patient who presents after a fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) and has tenderness or fullness in the anatomical snuff box, the primary clinical concern is a scaphoid fracture.
  • These fractures are can be radiographically occult in the early phase and due to its limited blood supply from the distal portion, the proximal pole is at higher risk for avascular necrosis.
  • Hence the next best step in management is cast immobilization and repeat imaging after 10–14 days.

 

Scaphoid fracture

Site

  • Waist of scaphoid (most common) (Option D)
  • Distal pole (Least common)
  • Proximal pole (high risk for avascular necrosis)

Mechanism of injury

Typically caused by a fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) with the wrist in dorsiflexion.

Clinical features

  • It is more common in young adults, particularly athletes.
  • Pain and tenderness localised to the anatomical snuffbox (the depression between the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and the abductor pollicis longus/extensor pollicis brevis).
  • Swelling and reduced range of motion at the wrist.

X-ray

There is a visible fracture line at the waist of the scaphoid, with possible cortical disruption or displacement; avascular necrosis may later appear as sclerosis in the proximal pole.

Management

Immobilisation by scaphoid cast (3-4 months)

Complications

  • Avascular necrosis (more common in the proximal pole) (Option D)
  • Humpback deformity (displaced Scaphoid fracture)
  • Delayed and non-union
  • Wrist osteoarthritis

 

MRI to evaluate soft tissues and ligaments ﻿﻿﻿(Option A): MRI has high sensitivity for occult fractures but is not routinely the next step unless urgent diagnosis is needed (e.g., athlete) or follow-up is not possible.

Immediate CT scan (Option B) is good for detecting displacement and fracture union but is less sensitive for non-displaced occult fractures for early detection.

Bone scan for early fracture detection (Option D): Bone scans can be used if the diagnosis remains unclear, as they are more sensitive in detecting fractures, but similar to MRI is not routinely the next step unless urgent diagnosis is needed or follow-up is not possible.
